<p><a id="cr701.31c"><b>701.31c</b></a> If a permanent’s ability instructs a player to “monstrosity X,” other abilities of that permanent may also refer to X. The value of X in those abilities is equal to the value of X as that permanent became monstrous.</p>
<p><a id="cr701.32"><b>701.32.</b></a> Vote</p>
<p><a id="cr701.32a"><b>701.32a</b></a> Some spells and abilities instruct players to vote for one choice from a list of options to determine some aspect of the effect of that spell or ability. To vote, each player, starting with a specified player and proceeding in turn order, chooses one of those choices.</p>
<p><a id="cr701.32b"><b>701.32b</b></a> The listed choices may be objects, words with no rules meaning that are each connected to a different effect, or other variables relevant to the resolution of the spell or ability.</p>
<p><a id="cr701.32c"><b>701.32c</b></a> If the text of a spell or ability refers to “voting,” it refers only to an actual vote, not to any spell or ability that involves the players making choices or decisions without using the word “vote.”</p>
<p><a id="cr701.32d"><b>701.32d</b></a> If an effect gives a player multiple votes, those votes all happen at the same time the player would otherwise have voted.</p>
<p><a id="cr701.33"><b>701.33.</b></a> Bolster</p>
<p><a id="cr701.33a"><b>701.33a</b></a> “Bolster N” means “Choose a creature you control with the least toughness or tied for least toughness among creatures you control. Put N +1/+1 counters on that creature.”</p>
<p><a id="cr701.34"><b>701.34.</b></a> Manifest</p>
<p><a id="cr701.34a"><b>701.34a</b></a> To manifest a card, turn it face down. It becomes a 2/2 face-down creature card with no text, no name, no subtypes, and no mana cost. Put that card onto the battlefield face down. That permanent is a manifested permanent as long as it remains face down. The effect defining its characteristics works while the card is face down and ends when it’s turned face up.</p>
<p><a id="cr701.34b"><b>701.34b</b></a> Any time you have priority, you may turn a manifested permanent you control face up. This is a special action that doesn’t use the stack (see rule <a href="#cr116.2b">116.2b</a>). To do this, show all players that the card representing that permanent is a creature card and what that card’s mana cost is, pay that cost, then turn the permanent face up. The effect defining its characteristics while it was face down ends, and it regains its normal characteristics. (If the card representing that permanent isn’t a creature card or it doesn’t have a mana cost, it can’t be turned face up this way.)</p>
<p><a id="cr701.34c"><b>701.34c</b></a> If a card with morph is manifested, its controller may turn that card face up using either the procedure described in rule <a href="#cr702.37f">702.37f</a> to turn a face-down permanent with morph face up or the procedure described above to turn a manifested permanent face up.</p>
<p><a id="cr701.34d"><b>701.34d</b></a> If an effect instructs a player to manifest multiple cards from their library, those cards are manifested one at a time.</p>
<p><a id="cr701.34e"><b>701.34e</b></a> If an effect instructs a player to manifest a card and a rule or effect prohibits the face-down object from entering the battlefield, that card isn’t manifested. Its characteristics remain unmodified and it remains in its previous zone. If it was face up, it remains face up.</p>
<p><a id="cr701.34f"><b>701.34f</b></a> If a manifested permanent that’s represented by an instant or sorcery card would turn face up, its controller reveals it and leaves it face down. Abilities that trigger whenever a permanent is turned face up won’t trigger.</p>
<p><a id="cr701.34g"><b>701.34g</b></a> See rule <a href="#cr708">708</a>, “Face-Down Spells and Permanents,” for more information.</p>
<p><a id="cr701.35"><b>701.35.</b></a> Support</p>
<p><a id="cr701.35a"><b>701.35a</b></a> “Support N” on a permanent means “Put a +1/+1 counter on each of up to N other target creatures.” “Support N” on an instant or sorcery spell means “Put a +1/+1 counter on each of up to N target creatures.”</p>
<p><a id="cr701.36"><b>701.36.</b></a> Investigate</p>
<p><a id="cr701.36a"><b>701.36a</b></a> “Investigate” means “Create a Clue token.” See rule <a href="#cr111.10f">111.10f</a>.</p>
<p><a id="cr701.37"><b>701.37.</b></a> Meld</p>
<p><a id="cr701.37a"><b>701.37a</b></a> Meld is a keyword action that appears in an ability on one card in a meld pair. (See rule <a href="#cr713">713</a>, “Meld Cards.”) To meld the two cards in a meld pair, put them onto the battlefield with their back faces up and combined. The resulting permanent is a single object represented by two cards.</p>
<p><a id="cr701.37b"><b>701.37b</b></a> Only two cards belonging to the same meld pair can be melded. Tokens, cards that aren’t meld cards, or meld cards that don’t form a meld pair can’t be melded.</p>
<p><a id="cr701.37c"><b>701.37c</b></a> If an effect instructs a player to meld objects that can’t be melded, they stay in their current zone.<br><b><i>Example:</b></i> A player owns and controls Midnight Scavengers and a token that’s a copy of Graf Rats. At the beginning of combat, both are exiled but can’t be melded. Midnight Scavengers remains exiled and the exiled token ceases to exist.</p>
<p><a id="cr701.38"><b>701.38.</b></a> Goad</p>
<p><a id="cr701.38a"><b>701.38a</b></a> Certain spells and abilities can goad a creature. Until the next turn of the controller of that spell or ability, that creature is goaded.</p>
<p><a id="cr701.38b"><b>701.38b</b></a> Goaded is a designation a permanent can have. A goaded creature attacks each combat if able and attacks a player other than the controller of the permanent, spell, or ability that caused it to be goaded if able. Goaded is neither an ability nor part of the permanent’s copiable values.</p>
<p><a id="cr701.38c"><b>701.38c</b></a> A creature can be goaded by multiple players. Doing so creates additional combat requirements.</p>
<p><a id="cr701.38d"><b>701.38d</b></a> Once a player has goaded a creature, the same player goading it again has no effect. Doing so doesn’t create additional combat requirements.</p>
<p><a id="cr701.39"><b>701.39.</b></a> Exert</p>
<p><a id="cr701.39a"><b>701.39a</b></a> To exert a permanent, you choose to have it not untap during your next untap step.</p>
<p><a id="cr701.39b"><b>701.39b</b></a> A permanent can be exerted even if it’s not tapped or has already been exerted in a turn. If you exert a permanent more than once before your next untap step, each effect causing it not to untap expires during the same untap step.</p>
<p><a id="cr701.39c"><b>701.39c</b></a> An object that isn’t on the battlefield can’t be exerted.</p>
<p><a id="cr701.39d"><b>701.39d</b></a> “You may exert [this creature] as it attacks” is an optional cost to attack (see rule <a href="#cr508.1g">508.1g</a>). Some objects with this static ability have a triggered ability that triggers “when you do” printed in the same paragraph. These abilities are linked. (See rule <a href="#cr607.2h">607.2h</a>.)</p>
<p><a id="cr701.40"><b>701.40.</b></a> Explore</p>
<p><a id="cr701.40a"><b>701.40a</b></a> Certain abilities instruct a permanent to explore. To do so, that permanent’s controller reveals the top card of their library. If a land card is revealed this way, that player puts that card into their hand. Otherwise, that player puts a +1/+1 counter on the exploring permanent and may put the revealed card into their graveyard.</p>
<p><a id="cr701.40b"><b>701.40b</b></a> A permanent “explores” after the process described in rule <a href="#cr701.40a">701.40a</a> is complete, even if some or all of those actions were impossible.</p>
<p><a id="cr701.40c"><b>701.40c</b></a> If a permanent changes zones before an effect causes it to explore, its last known information is used to determine which object explored and who controlled it.</p>
<p><a id="cr701.41"><b>701.41.</b></a> Assemble</p>
<p><a id="cr701.41a"><b>701.41a</b></a> Assemble is a keyword action in the Unstable set that puts Contraptions onto the battlefield. Outside of silver-bordered cards, only one card (Steamflogger Boss) refers to assembling a Contraption. Cards and mechanics from the Unstable set aren’t included in these rules. See the Unstable FAQ for more information.</p>
<p><a id="cr701.42"><b>701.42.</b></a> Surveil</p>
<p><a id="cr701.42a"><b>701.42a</b></a> To “surveil N” means to look at the top N cards of your library, then put any number of them into your graveyard and the rest on top of your library in any order.</p>
<p><a id="cr701.42b"><b>701.42b</b></a> If an effect allows you to look at additional cards while you surveil, those cards are included among the cards you may put into your graveyard and on top of your library in any order.</p>
<p><a id="cr701.43"><b>701.43.</b></a> Adapt</p>
<p><a id="cr701.43a"><b>701.43a</b></a> “Adapt N” means “If this permanent has no +1/+1 counters on it, put N +1/+1 counters on it.”</p>
<p><a id="cr701.44"><b>701.44.</b></a> Amass</p>
<p><a id="cr701.44a"><b>701.44a</b></a> To amass N means “If you don’t control an Army creature, create a 0/0 black Zombie Army creature token. Choose an Army creature you control. Put N +1/+1 counters on that creature.”</p>
<p><a id="cr701.44b"><b>701.44b</b></a> The phrase “the [subtype] you amassed” refers to the creature you chose, whether or not it received counters.</p>
<p><a id="cr701.45"><b>701.45.</b></a> Learn</p>
<p><a id="cr701.45a"><b>701.45a</b></a> “Learn” means “You may discard a card. If you do, draw a card. If you didn’t discard a card, you may reveal a Lesson card you own from outside the game and put it into your hand.”</p>
<p><a id="cr701.46"><b>701.46.</b></a> Venture into the Dungeon</p>
<p><a id="cr701.46a"><b>701.46a</b></a> If a player is instructed to venture into the dungeon while they don’t own a dungeon card in the command zone, they choose a dungeon card they own from outside the game and put it into the command zone. They put their venture marker on the topmost room. See rule <a href="#cr309">309</a>, “Dungeons.”</p>
<p><a id="cr701.46b"><b>701.46b</b></a> If a player is instructed to venture into the dungeon while their venture marker is in any room except the dungeon card’s bottommost room, they choose an adjacent room, following the direction of an arrow pointing away from their current room. If there are multiple arrows pointing away from the room the player’s venture marker is in, they choose one of them to follow. They move their venture marker to that adjacent room.</p>
<p><a id="cr701.46c"><b>701.46c</b></a> If a player is instructed to venture into the dungeon while their venture marker is in the bottommost room of a dungeon card, they remove that dungeon card from the game. Doing so causes the player to complete that dungeon (see rule <a href="#cr309.7">309.7</a>). They then complete the procedure outlined in rule <a href="#cr701.46a">701.46a</a> again.</p>
<p><a id="cr701.47"><b>701.47.</b></a> Connive</p>
<p><a id="cr701.47a"><b>701.47a</b></a> Certain abilities instruct a permanent to connive. To do so, that permanent’s controller draws a card, then discards a card. If a nonland card is discarded this way, that player puts a +1/+1 counter on the conniving permanent.</p>
<p><a id="cr701.47b"><b>701.47b</b></a> A permanent “connives” after the process described in rule <a href="#cr701.47a">701.47a</a> is complete, even if some or all of those actions were impossible.</p>
<p><a id="cr701.47c"><b>701.47c</b></a> If a permanent changes zones before an effect causes it to connive, its last known information is used to determine which object connived and who controlled it.</p>
<p><a id="cr701.47d"><b>701.47d</b></a>  If multiple permanents are instructed to connive at the same time, the first player in APNAP order who controls one or more of those permanents chooses one of them and it connives. Then if any permanents remain on the battlefield which have been instructed to connive and have not done so, this process is repeated.</p>
<p><a id="cr701.47e"><b>701.47e</b></a> Connive N is a variant of connive. The permanent’s controller draws N cards, discards N cards, then puts a number of +1/+1 counters on the permanent equal to the number of nonland cards discarded this way.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr701.48"><b>701.48.</b></a> Adjudicate</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr701.48a"><b>701.48a</b></a> Adjudicate is a keyword action that means “Create a white Aura enchantment token with enchant creature and 'Sacrifice this token: Untap enchanted creature' and attach it to target creature.”</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr701.48b"><b>701.48b</b></a> If the token can't be attached to the target creature, for example if it has protection from enchantments, the token will never enter the battlefield.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr701.48c"><b>701.48c</b></a> Adjudicate type is a variant of the adjudicate action. “Adjudicate [type]” means “Create a white Aura enchantment token with enchant [type] and 'Sacrifice this token: Untap enchanted permanent' and attach it to target [type] permanent.”</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr701.49"><b>701.49.</b></a> Catalyze</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr701.49a"><b>701.49a</b></a> Certain spells and abilities cause a player to catalyze. The next spell that player casts this turn costs (1) less to cast.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr701.49b"><b>701.49b</b></a> Multiple instances of catalyze stack, but will all apply to the same spell, even if the spell costs less than the number of active catalyzes.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr701.50"><b>701.50.</b></a> Idolize</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr701.50a"><b>701.50a</b></a> Idolize is an keyword action that means “Create a colorless Idol artifact token with '(2), Sacrifice this artifact: Put a +1/+1 counter on target creature.'”</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr701.50b"><b>701.50b</b></a> An Idol can still be sacrificed if it somehow stops being an artifact.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr701.51"><b>701.51.</b></a> Invigorate</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr701.51a"><b>701.51a</b></a> Invigorate N is a keyword action that means “Choose a creature you control with the least power or tied for the least power among creatures you control. Put N +1/+1 counters on that creature.”</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr701.51b"><b>701.51b</b></a> Conditional invigorate is a variant of the invigorate ability. “Invigorate N [condition]” means “Choose a creature you control with the least power or tied for the least power among [condition] creatures yo control. Put a +1/+1 counter on that creature.”</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr701.52"><b>701.52.</b></a> Purge</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr701.52a"><b>701.52a</b></a> Purge is a keyword action that means “Exile two cards that share a card type from graveyards. If you exile two cards this way, draw a card.”</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr701.53"><b>701.53.</b></a> Submerge</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr701.53a"><b>701.53a</b></a> To submerge a card, exile it face up, then put it onto the battlefield face down under its owner's control as a 2/2 face-down creature card with no text, no name, no subtypes, and no mana cost. That permanent is a submerged permanent as long as it remains face down. The effect defining its characteristics works while the card is face down and ends when it’s turned face up.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr701.53b"><b>701.53b</b></a> Unlike manifest, a submerged card can not turn face up again on its own.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr701.54"><b>701.54.</b></a> Post a bounty</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr701.54a"><b>701.54a</b></a> To post a bounty on a permanent means to put a bounty counter on that permanent. For as long as that permanent has a bounty counter on it, it has “When this permanent is put into a graveyard from the battlefield, each opponent draws a card.”</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr701.54b"><b>701.54b</b></a> A new triggered ability is gained each time a bounty is placed on a permanent.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr701.54c"><b>701.54c</b></a> The permanent will only gain the ability once per time a bounty is posted, even if it would get more than one bounty counter from it, such as through Doubling Season.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr701.54d"><b>701.54d</b></a> If some bounty counters are removed but not all of them, the permanent will still have the ability as many times as a bounty was posted on it.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr701.55"><b>701.55.</b></a> Arm</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr701.55a"><b>701.55a</b></a> To arm a creature, create a colorless Equipment artifact token with “Equipped creature gets +1/+0” and equip {2}, then attach that token to that creature.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr701.55b"><b>701.55b</b></a> If the creature that is being armed can't be equipped by the Equipment token (for example, it isn't on the battlefield anymore), the token is created but isn't attached to anything.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr701.56"><b>701.56.</b></a> Nourish</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr701.56a"><b>701.56a</b></a> “Nourish N” means “You may put N +1/+1 counters on this permanent. If you don't, create N 1/1 white Citizen creature tokens.”</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr701.57"><b>701.57.</b></a> Abound</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr701.57a"><b>701.57a</b></a> Abound is a keyword action. “Abound” means “You may cast a spell from your hand with a lesser mana value than this spell or permanent without paying its mana cost.”</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr701.57b"><b>701.57b</b></a> If an triggered or activated ability instructs you to abound, use the mana value of the source of that ability to determine the mana value. If the ability somehow doesn't have a source, its mana value is 0 and you will be unable to cast a spell with a lesser mana value.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr701.58"><b>701.58.</b></a> Journey</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr701.58a"><b>701.58a</b></a> Journey is a keyword action. To journey, exile the top card of your library face up and it becomes journeyed.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr701.58b"><b>701.58b</b></a> There is an inherent triggered ability associated with owning journeyed cards in exile. This triggered ability has no source and is controlled by the player whose creature triggered it. The full text of this ability is “Whenever a creature you control deals combat damage to an opponent, put a journeyed card you own from exile into your hand.”</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr701.58c"><b>701.58c</b></a> The triggered ability will trigger once for each creature that dealt combat damage, regardless of how many journeyed cards that player owns in exile.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr701.59"><b>701.59.</b></a> Conjure</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr701.59a"><b>701.59a</b></a> Conjure is a keyword action. “Conjure (number) cards named (name) to (zone)” means “Put (number) cards named (name) into (zone).”</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr701.59b"><b>701.59b</b></a> “Conjure (number) of a random (quality) card to (zone)” means “Put (number) cards of a single (quality) card chosen at random into (zone).”</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr701.59c"><b>701.59c</b></a> “Conjure a random (quality) card to (zone) (number) times” means “Repeat this process (number) times. Put a (quality) card chosen at random into (zone)”</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr701.59d"><b>701.59d</b></a> Conjured cards are not moved from any zone or a player's sideboard.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr701.59e"><b>701.59e</b></a> Conjured cards are cards and not tokens, even if they are represented by token or checklists cards.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr701.59f"><b>701.59f</b></a> Conjured cards are known to all players, even if they are conjured to a hidden zone.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr701.59g"><b>701.59g</b></a> The owner of a conjured card is the player who conjured it, regardless of who controlled the effect that caused that player to conjure it.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr701.59h"><b>701.59h</b></a> When a game ends, cards that were conjured during that game are removed from decks.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr701.59i"><b>701.59i</b></a> When a game is restarted, cards that were conjured during that game remain in decks.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr701.60"><b>701.60.</b></a> Harmonize</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr701.60a"><b>701.60a</b></a> Harmonize is a keyword action. “Harmonize” means “Choose up to one harmony ability of a permanent you control.” Choosing an ability this way causes that ability to trigger.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr701.61"><b>701.61.</b></a> Germinate</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr701.61a"><b>701.61a</b></a> “Germinate” means “You may put a +1/+1 counter on a creature. If you don't, create a 1/1 green Saproling creature token.”</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr701.62"><b>701.62.</b></a> Profit</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr701.62a"><b>701.62a</b></a> To profit, create a colorless Gold artifact token with “Sacrifice this artifact: Add one mana of any color.”</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr701.63"><b>701.63.</b></a> Substantiate</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr701.63a"><b>701.63a</b></a> To substantiate a card, put it onto the battlefield face down under your control as a 2/2 face-down creature card with no text, no name, no subtypes, and no mana cost. That permanent is a substantiated permanent as long as it remains face down. The effect defining its characteristics works while the card is face down and ends when it’s turned face up.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr701.63b"><b>701.63b</b></a> Any time you have priority, you may exile and cast a substantiated permanent you control face up. This is a special action that doesn’t use the stack (see rule <a href="#cr116.2b">116.2b</a>). To do this, show all players that the card representing that permanent is a noncreature card, then cast that card. You still pay its costs, but this is not an alternate cost, so alternate costs can be paid. The effect defining its characteristics while it was face down ends, and it regains its normal characteristics. (If the card representing that permanent is a creature card, it doesn’t have a mana cost, or you are unable to cast it, it can’t be turned face up this way.)</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr701.64"><b>701.64.</b></a> Aetherize</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr701.64a"><b>701.64a</b></a> Aetherize is a keyword action. To aetherize a card, create a token that’s a copy of that card, then exile that token.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr701.64b"><b>701.64b</b></a> Abilities that trigger as a result of that token leaving the battlefield will resolve before before abilities that trigger as a result of token entering the battlefield.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr701.64c"><b>701.64c</b></a> If an effect such as Doubling Season causes you to create more than one token, all the tokens created by the aetherize action will be exiled.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr701.65"><b>701.65.</b></a> Reappropriate</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr701.65a"><b>701.65a</b></a> To reappropriate, exile exactly two cards from your hand and/or graveyard.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr701.65b"><b>701.65b</b></a> If you are instructed to reappropriate while your hand and graveyard have only one card total, you will be unable to. Any abilities that would trigger due to that reappropriate action don't.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr701.66"><b>701.66.</b></a> Rediscover</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr701.66a"><b>701.66a</b></a> To rediscover a [quality] card, look at the top card of your library. You may reveal it and put it into your hand if it's a [quality] card. Otherwise, put it into your graveyard or back on top of your library.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr701.67"><b>701.67.</b></a> Torment</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr701.67a"><b>701.67a</b></a> Torment is a keyword action. The tormented player loses 3 life unless they discard a card or sacrifice a nonland permanent.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr701.68"><b>701.68.</b></a> Permutate</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr701.68a"><b>701.68a</b></a> Permutate is a keyword action. To permutate, you may remove a counter from a creature you control. If you do, put two +1/+1 counters on a different creature you control.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr701.69"><b>701.69.</b></a> Consume</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr701.69a"><b>701.69a</b></a> Consume is a keyword action. To have a creature consume, sacrifice a creature other than the creature consuming, or exile a creature card from your graveyard.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr701.69b"><b>701.69b</b></a> The creature that consumed may have linked abilities related to the cards it consumed.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr701.69c"><b>701.69c</b></a> Consume a type is a variant of the consume action. To have a creature “consume a [type],” sacrifice a permanent of that type other than the creature consuming, or exile a card of that type from your graveyard.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr701.70"><b>701.70.</b></a> Forebode</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr701.70a"><b>701.70a</b></a> To forebode, create a tapped colorless Omen artifact token with “T, Discard a card, Sacrifice this artifact: Draw a card.”</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr701.71"><b>701.71.</b></a> Salvage</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr701.71a"><b>701.71a</b></a> Salvage is a keyword action. To salvage a [quality] card, exile a card with that quality from your graveyard until the permanent that was the source of the salvage ability leaves the battlefield. That card is “salvaged” by that permanent.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr701.71b"><b>701.71b</b></a> Whenever a creature that has one or more salvaged cards in exile deals combat damage to a player, that creature's controller puts one of those salvaged cards into its owner's hand.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr701.72"><b>701.72.</b></a> Voyage</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr701.72a"><b>701.72a</b></a> Voyage is a keyword action. “(a permanent) voyages” means “If this permanent isn't blocking or the target of a spell or ability other than this one, it phases out and becomes a voyaging permanent until it phases in.”</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr701.72b"><b>701.72b</b></a> A voyaging permanent “returns from voyage” when it phases in.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr701.73"><b>701.73.</b></a> Cackle</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr701.73a"><b>701.73a</b></a> “Cackle” means “If this creature has menace, it deals 1 damage to each opponent. Otherwise, put a menace counter on it.”</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr701.74"><b>701.74.</b></a> Upgrade</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr701.74a"><b>701.74a</b></a> Upgrade is a keyword action and modal ability. “upgrade a permanent. [bulleted list]” means “Choose one that's not a kind of counter this permanent has on it. Put a counter of that kind on this permanent. [bulleted list].”</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr701.75"><b>701.75.</b></a> Judge</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr701.75a"><b>701.75a</b></a> Judge is a keyword action. To judge a permanent, honor it or condemn it. If you honor it, put a +1/+1 counter on it. If you condemn it, sacrifice it, then draw a card.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr701.75b"><b>701.75b</b></a> Honoring or condemning a permanent has no rules meaning, and only acts a designation that spells and abilities can identify.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr701.76"><b>701.76.</b></a> Recruit</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr701.76a"><b>701.76a</b></a> Recruit is a keyword action. To recruit, create a 0/0 white Soldier Army creature token, then put a +1/+1 counter on each Army you control.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr701.77"><b>701.77.</b></a> Soar</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr701.77a"><b>701.77a</b></a> “Soar” means “If this creature has flying, put a +1/+1 counter on it. Otherwise, put a flying counter on it.”</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr701.78"><b>701.78.</b></a> Autocrat</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr701.78a"><b>701.78a</b></a> “Autocrat N” means “If you don’t control an autocrat, put X +1/+1 counters on this. It becomes an autocrat until it has no +1/+1 counters on it.”</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr701.78b"><b>701.78b</b></a> “An autocrat” is a designation that has no rules meaning other than to act as a marker that the autocrat action and other spells and abilities can identify. Only permanents can be or become an autocrat. Once a permanent becomes an autocrat, it stays an autocrat until it leaves the battlefield or has no +1/+1 counters on it. Being an autocrat is neither an ability nor part of the permanent’s copiable values.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr701.78c"><b>701.78c</b></a> If a permanent’s ability instructs a player to “autocrat X,” other abilities of that permanent may also refer to X. The value of X in those abilities is equal to the value of X as that permanent became an autocrat.</p>
<p><a id="cr702"><b>702. Keyword Abilities</b></a></p>
<p><a id="cr702.1"><b>702.1.</b></a> Most abilities describe exactly what they do in the card’s rules text. Some, though, are very common or would require too much space to define on the card. In these cases, the object lists only the name of the ability as a “keyword”; sometimes reminder text summarizes the game rule.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.1a"><b>702.1a</b></a> If an effect refers to a “[keyword ability] cost,” it refers only to the variable costs for that keyword.<br><b><i>Example:</b></i> Varolz, the Scar-Striped has an ability that says “Each creature card in your graveyard has scavenge. The scavenge cost is equal to its mana cost.” A creature card’s scavenge cost is an amount of mana equal to its mana cost, and the activation cost of the scavenge ability is that amount of mana plus “Exile this card from your graveyard.”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.1b"><b>702.1b</b></a> An effect that grants an object a keyword ability may define a variable in that ability based on characteristics of that object or other information about the game state. For these abilities, the value of that variable is constantly reevaluated.<br><b><i>Example:</b></i> Volcano Hellion has the ability “Volcano Hellion has echo {X}, where X is your life total.” If your life total is 10 when Volcano Hellion’s echo ability triggers but 5 when it resolves, the echo cost to pay is {5}.<br><b><i>Example:</b></i> Fire//Ice is a split card whose halves have the mana costs {1}{R} and {1}{U}. Past in Flames reads “Each instant and sorcery card in your graveyard gains flashback until end of turn. The flashback cost is equal to its mana cost.” Fire//Ice has “Flashback {2}{U}{R}” while it is in your graveyard, but if you choose to cast Fire, the resulting spell has “Flashback {1}{R}.”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.1c"><b>702.1c</b></a> An effect may state that “the same is true for” a list of keyword abilities or similar. If one of those keyword abilities has variants or variables and the effect grants that keyword or counters of that keyword to one or more objects and/or players, it grants each appropriate variant and variable of that keyword.<br><b><i>Example:</b></i> Concerted Effort is an enchantment that reads “At the beginning of each upkeep, creatures you control gain flying until end of turn if a creature you control has flying. The same is true for fear, first strike, double strike, landwalk, protection, trample, and vigilance.” As that triggered ability resolves, each landwalk and protection ability from among creatures you control is granted to each creature you control.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.1d"><b>702.1d</b></a> An effect may refer to an object “with [keyword ability]” or “that has [keyword ability].” This means the same thing as an object “with a [keyword ability] ability” or an object “that has a [keyword ability] ability.”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.2"><b>702.2.</b></a> Deathtouch</p>
<p><a id="cr702.2a"><b>702.2a</b></a> Deathtouch is a static ability.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.2b"><b>702.2b</b></a> A creature with toughness greater than 0 that’s been dealt damage by a source with deathtouch since the last time state-based actions were checked is destroyed as a state-based action. See rule <a href="#cr704.">704.</a></p>
<p><a id="cr702.2c"><b>702.2c</b></a> Any nonzero amount of combat damage assigned to a creature by a source with deathtouch is considered to be lethal damage for the purposes of determining if a proposed combat damage assignment is valid, regardless of that creature’s toughness. See rules <a href="#cr510.1c">510.1c</a>–d.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.2d"><b>702.2d</b></a> The deathtouch rules function no matter what zone an object with deathtouch deals damage from.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.2e"><b>702.2e</b></a> If an object changes zones before an effect causes it to deal damage, its last known information is used to determine whether it had deathtouch.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.2f"><b>702.2f</b></a> Multiple instances of deathtouch on the same object are redundant.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.3"><b>702.3.</b></a> Defender</p>
<p><a id="cr702.3a"><b>702.3a</b></a> Defender is a static ability.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.3b"><b>702.3b</b></a> A creature with defender can’t attack.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.3c"><b>702.3c</b></a> Multiple instances of defender on the same creature are redundant.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.4"><b>702.4.</b></a> Double Strike</p>
<p><a id="cr702.4a"><b>702.4a</b></a> Double strike is a static ability that modifies the rules for the combat damage step. (See rule <a href="#cr510">510</a>, “Combat Damage Step.”)</p>
<p><a id="cr702.4b"><b>702.4b</b></a> If at least one attacking or blocking creature has first strike (see rule <a href="#cr702.7">702.7</a>) or double strike as the combat damage step begins, the only creatures that assign combat damage in that step are those with first strike or double strike. After that step, instead of proceeding to the end of combat step, the phase gets a second combat damage step. The only creatures that assign combat damage in that step are the remaining attackers and blockers that had neither first strike nor double strike as the first combat damage step began, as well as the remaining attackers and blockers that currently have double strike. After that step, the phase proceeds to the end of combat step.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.4c"><b>702.4c</b></a> Removing double strike from a creature during the first combat damage step will stop it from assigning combat damage in the second combat damage step.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.4d"><b>702.4d</b></a> Giving double strike to a creature with first strike after it has already dealt combat damage in the first combat damage step will allow the creature to assign combat damage in the second combat damage step.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.4e"><b>702.4e</b></a> Multiple instances of double strike on the same creature are redundant.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.5"><b>702.5.</b></a> Enchant</p>
<p><a id="cr702.5a"><b>702.5a</b></a> Enchant is a static ability, written “Enchant [object or player].” The enchant ability restricts what an Aura spell can target and what an Aura can enchant.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.5b"><b>702.5b</b></a> For more information about Auras, see rule <a href="#cr303">303</a>, “Enchantments.”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.5c"><b>702.5c</b></a> If an Aura has multiple instances of enchant, all of them apply. The Aura’s target must follow the restrictions from all the instances of enchant. The Aura can enchant only objects or players that match all of its enchant abilities.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.5d"><b>702.5d</b></a> Auras that can enchant a player can target and be attached to players. Such Auras can’t target permanents and can’t be attached to permanents.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.6"><b>702.6.</b></a> Equip</p>
<p><a id="cr702.6a"><b>702.6a</b></a> Equip is an activated ability of Equipment cards. “Equip [cost]” means “[Cost]: Attach this permanent to target creature you control. Activate only as a sorcery.”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.6b"><b>702.6b</b></a> For more information about Equipment, see rule <a href="#cr301">301</a>, “Artifacts.”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.6c"><b>702.6c</b></a> Equip abilities may further restrict what creatures may be chosen as legal targets. Such restrictions usually appear in the form “Equip [quality]” or “Equip [quality] creature.” These equip abilities may legally target only a creature that’s controlled by the player activating the ability and that has the chosen quality. Additional restrictions for an equip ability don’t restrict what the Equipment may be attached to.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.6d"><b>702.6d</b></a> If a permanent has multiple equip abilities, any of its equip abilities may be activated.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.6e"><b>702.6e</b></a> “Equip planeswalker” is a variant of the equip ability. “Equip planeswalker [cost]” means “[Cost]: Attach this permanent to target planeswalker you control as though that planeswalker were a creature. Activate only as a sorcery.”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.7"><b>702.7.</b></a> First Strike</p>
<p><a id="cr702.7a"><b>702.7a</b></a> First strike is a static ability that modifies the rules for the combat damage step. (See rule <a href="#cr510">510</a>, “Combat Damage Step.”)</p>
<p><a id="cr702.7b"><b>702.7b</b></a> If at least one attacking or blocking creature has first strike or double strike (see rule <a href="#cr702.4">702.4</a>) as the combat damage step begins, the only creatures that assign combat damage in that step are those with first strike or double strike. After that step, instead of proceeding to the end of combat step, the phase gets a second combat damage step. The only creatures that assign combat damage in that step are the remaining attackers and blockers that had neither first strike nor double strike as the first combat damage step began, as well as the remaining attackers and blockers that currently have double strike. After that step, the phase proceeds to the end of combat step.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.7c"><b>702.7c</b></a> Giving first strike to a creature without it after combat damage has already been dealt in the first combat damage step won’t preclude that creature from assigning combat damage in the second combat damage step. Removing first strike from a creature after it has already dealt combat damage in the first combat damage step won’t allow it to also assign combat damage in the second combat damage step (unless the creature has double strike).</p>
<p><a id="cr702.7d"><b>702.7d</b></a> Multiple instances of first strike on the same creature are redundant.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.8"><b>702.8.</b></a> Flash</p>
<p><a id="cr702.8a"><b>702.8a</b></a> Flash is a static ability that functions in any zone from which you could play the card it’s on. “Flash” means “You may play this card any time you could cast an instant.”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.8b"><b>702.8b</b></a> Multiple instances of flash on the same object are redundant.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.9"><b>702.9.</b></a> Flying</p>
<p><a id="cr702.9a"><b>702.9a</b></a> Flying is an evasion ability.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.9b"><b>702.9b</b></a> A creature with flying can’t be blocked except by creatures with flying and/or reach. A creature with flying can block a creature with or without flying. (See rule <a href="#cr509">509</a>, “Declare Blockers Step,” and rule <a href="#cr702.17">702.17</a>, “Reach.”)</p>
<p><a id="cr702.9c"><b>702.9c</b></a> Multiple instances of flying on the same creature are redundant.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.10"><b>702.10.</b></a> Haste</p>
<p><a id="cr702.10a"><b>702.10a</b></a> Haste is a static ability.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.10b"><b>702.10b</b></a> If a creature has haste, it can attack even if it hasn’t been controlled by its controller continuously since their most recent turn began. (See rule <a href="#cr302.6">302.6</a>.)</p>
<p><a id="cr702.10c"><b>702.10c</b></a> If a creature has haste, its controller can activate its activated abilities whose cost includes the tap symbol or the untap symbol even if that creature hasn’t been controlled by that player continuously since their most recent turn began. (See rule <a href="#cr302.6">302.6</a>.)</p>
<p><a id="cr702.10d"><b>702.10d</b></a> Multiple instances of haste on the same creature are redundant.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.11"><b>702.11.</b></a> Hexproof</p>
<p><a id="cr702.11a"><b>702.11a</b></a> Hexproof is a static ability.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.11b"><b>702.11b</b></a> “Hexproof” on a permanent means “This permanent can’t be the target of spells or abilities your opponents control.”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.11c"><b>702.11c</b></a> “Hexproof” on a player means “You can’t be the target of spells or abilities your opponents control.”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.11d"><b>702.11d</b></a> “Hexproof from [quality]” is a variant of the hexproof ability. “Hexproof from [quality]” on a permanent means “This permanent can’t be the target of [quality] spells your opponents control or abilities your opponents control from [quality] sources.” A “hexproof from [quality]” ability is a hexproof ability.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.11e"><b>702.11e</b></a> Any effect that causes an object to lose hexproof will cause an object to lose all “hexproof from [quality]” abilities. Any effect that allows a player to choose a creature with hexproof as a target as though it didn’t have hexproof will allow a player to choose a creature with a “hexproof from [quality]” ability. Any effect that looks for a card with hexproof will find a card with a “hexproof from [quality]” ability.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.11f"><b>702.11f</b></a> “Hexproof from [quality A] and from [quality B]” is shorthand for “hexproof from [quality A]” and “hexproof from [quality B]”; it behaves as two separate hexproof abilities. If an effect causes an object with such an ability to lose hexproof from [quality A], for example, that object would still have hexproof from [quality B].</p>
<p><a id="cr702.11g"><b>702.11g</b></a> Multiple instances of the same hexproof ability on the same permanent or player are redundant.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.12"><b>702.12.</b></a> Indestructible</p>
<p><a id="cr702.12a"><b>702.12a</b></a> Indestructible is a static ability.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.12b"><b>702.12b</b></a> A permanent with indestructible can’t be destroyed. Such permanents aren’t destroyed by lethal damage, and they ignore the state-based action that checks for lethal damage (see rule <a href="#cr704.5g">704.5g</a>).</p>
<p><a id="cr702.12c"><b>702.12c</b></a> Multiple instances of indestructible on the same permanent are redundant.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.13"><b>702.13.</b></a> Intimidate</p>
<p><a id="cr702.13a"><b>702.13a</b></a> Intimidate is an evasion ability.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.13b"><b>702.13b</b></a> A creature with intimidate can’t be blocked except by artifact creatures and/or creatures that share a color with it. (See rule <a href="#cr509">509</a>, “Declare Blockers Step.”)</p>
<p><a id="cr702.13c"><b>702.13c</b></a> Multiple instances of intimidate on the same creature are redundant.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.14"><b>702.14.</b></a> Landwalk</p>
<p><a id="cr702.14a"><b>702.14a</b></a> Landwalk is a generic term that appears within an object’s rules text as “[type]walk,” where [type] is usually a land type, but it can also be the card type land plus any combination of land types, card types, and/or supertypes.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.14b"><b>702.14b</b></a> Landwalk is an evasion ability.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.14c"><b>702.14c</b></a> A creature with landwalk can’t be blocked as long as the defending player controls at least one land with the specified land type (as in “islandwalk”), with the specified type or supertype (as in “artifact landwalk”), without the specified type or supertype (as in “nonbasic landwalk”), or with both the specified type or supertype and the specified subtype (as in “snow swampwalk”). (See rule <a href="#cr509">509</a>, “Declare Blockers Step.”)</p>
<p><a id="cr702.14d"><b>702.14d</b></a> Landwalk abilities don’t “cancel” one another.<br><b><i>Example:</b></i> If a player controls a snow Forest, that player can’t block an attacking creature with snow forestwalk even if they also control a creature with snow forestwalk.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.14e"><b>702.14e</b></a> Multiple instances of the same kind of landwalk on the same creature are redundant.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.15"><b>702.15.</b></a> Lifelink</p>
<p><a id="cr702.15a"><b>702.15a</b></a> Lifelink is a static ability.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.15b"><b>702.15b</b></a> Damage dealt by a source with lifelink causes that source’s controller, or its owner if it has no controller, to gain that much life (in addition to any other results that damage causes). See rule <a href="#cr120.3">120.3</a>.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.15c"><b>702.15c</b></a> If an object changes zones before an effect causes it to deal damage, its last known information is used to determine whether it had lifelink.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.15d"><b>702.15d</b></a> The lifelink rules function no matter what zone an object with lifelink deals damage from.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.15e"><b>702.15e</b></a> If multiple sources with lifelink deal damage at the same time, they cause separate life gain events (see rules <a href="#cr119.9">119.9</a>–10).<br><b><i>Example:</b></i> A player controls Ajani’s Pridemate, which reads “Whenever you gain life, put a +1/+1 counter on Ajani’s Pridemate,” and two creatures with lifelink. The creatures with lifelink deal combat damage simultaneously. Ajani’s Pridemate’s ability triggers twice.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.15f"><b>702.15f</b></a> Multiple instances of lifelink on the same object are redundant.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.16"><b>702.16.</b></a> Protection</p>
<p><a id="cr702.16a"><b>702.16a</b></a> Protection is a static ability, written “Protection from [quality].” This quality is usually a color (as in “protection from black”) but can be any characteristic value or information. If the quality happens to be a card name, it is treated as such only if the protection ability specifies that the quality is a name. If the quality is a card type, subtype, or supertype, the ability applies to sources that are permanents with that card type, subtype, or supertype and to any sources not on the battlefield that are of that card type, subtype, or supertype. This is an exception to rule <a href="#cr109.2">109.2</a>.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.16b"><b>702.16b</b></a> A permanent or player with protection can’t be targeted by spells with the stated quality and can’t be targeted by abilities from a source with the stated quality.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.16c"><b>702.16c</b></a> A permanent or player with protection can’t be enchanted by Auras that have the stated quality. Such Auras attached to the permanent or player with protection will be put into their owners’ graveyards as a state-based action. (See rule <a href="#cr704">704</a>, “State-Based Actions.”)</p>
<p><a id="cr702.16d"><b>702.16d</b></a> A permanent with protection can’t be equipped by Equipment that have the stated quality or fortified by Fortifications that have the stated quality. Such Equipment or Fortifications become unattached from that permanent as a state-based action, but remain on the battlefield. (See rule <a href="#cr704">704</a>, “State-Based Actions.”)</p>
<p><a id="cr702.16e"><b>702.16e</b></a> Any damage that would be dealt by sources that have the stated quality to a permanent or player with protection is prevented.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.16f"><b>702.16f</b></a> Attacking creatures with protection can’t be blocked by creatures that have the stated quality.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.16g"><b>702.16g</b></a> “Protection from [quality A] and from [quality B]” is shorthand for “protection from [quality A]” and “protection from [quality B]”; it behaves as two separate protection abilities. If an effect causes an object with such an ability to lose protection from [quality A], for example, that object would still have protection from [quality B].</p>
<p><a id="cr702.16h"><b>702.16h</b></a> “Protection from all [characteristic]” is shorthand for “protection from [quality A],” “protection from [quality B],” and so on for each possible quality the listed characteristic could have; it behaves as multiple separate protection abilities. If an effect causes an object with such an ability to lose protection from [quality A], for example, that object would still have protection from [quality B], [quality C], and so on.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.16i"><b>702.16i</b></a> “Protection from each [set of characteristics, qualities, or players]” is shorthand for “protection from [A],” “protection from [B],” and so on for each characteristic, quality, or player in the set. It behaves as multiple separate protection abilities.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.16j"><b>702.16j</b></a> “Protection from everything” is a variant of the protection ability. A permanent or player with protection from everything has protection from each object regardless of that object’s characteristic values. Such a permanent or player can’t be targeted by spells or abilities and can’t be enchanted by Auras. Such a permanent can’t be equipped by Equipment, fortified by Fortifications, or blocked by creatures. All damage that would be dealt to such a permanent or player is prevented.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.16k"><b>702.16k</b></a> “Protection from [a player]” is a variant of the protection ability. A permanent with protection from a specific player has protection from each object the player controls and protection from each object the player owns not controlled by another player, regardless of that object’s characteristic values. Such a permanent can’t be targeted by spells or abilities the player controls, enchanted by Auras the player controls, equipped by Equipment the player controls, fortified by Fortifications the player controls, or blocked by creatures the player controls, and all damage that would be dealt to it by sources controlled by the player or owned by the player but not controlled by another player is prevented.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.16m"><b>702.16m</b></a> Multiple instances of protection from the same quality on the same permanent or player are redundant.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.16n"><b>702.16n</b></a> Some Auras both give the enchanted creature protection from a quality and say “this effect doesn’t remove” either that specific Aura or all Auras. This means that the specified Auras aren’t put into their owners’ graveyards as a state-based action. If the creature has other instances of protection from the same quality, those instances affect Auras as normal.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.16p"><b>702.16p</b></a> One Aura (Benevolent Blessing) gives the enchanted creature protection from a quality and says the effect doesn’t remove certain permanents that are “already attached to” that creature. This means that, when the protection effect starts to apply, any objects with the stated quality that are already attached to that creature (including the Aura giving that creature protection) will not be put into their owners’ graveyards as a state-based action. Other permanents with the stated quality can’t become attached to the creature. If the creature has other instances of protection from the same quality, those instances affect attached permanents as normal.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.17"><b>702.17.</b></a> Reach</p>
<p><a id="cr702.17a"><b>702.17a</b></a> Reach is a static ability.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.17b"><b>702.17b</b></a> A creature with flying can’t be blocked except by creatures with flying and/or reach. (See rule <a href="#cr509">509</a>, “Declare Blockers Step,” and rule <a href="#cr702.9">702.9</a>, “Flying.”)</p>
<p><a id="cr702.17c"><b>702.17c</b></a> Multiple instances of reach on the same creature are redundant.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.18"><b>702.18.</b></a> Shroud</p>
<p><a id="cr702.18a"><b>702.18a</b></a> Shroud is a static ability. “Shroud” means “This permanent or player can’t be the target of spells or abilities.”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.18b"><b>702.18b</b></a> Multiple instances of shroud on the same permanent or player are redundant.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.19"><b>702.19.</b></a> Trample</p>
<p><a id="cr702.19a"><b>702.19a</b></a> Trample is a static ability that modifies the rules for assigning an attacking creature’s combat damage. The ability has no effect when a creature with trample is blocking or is dealing noncombat damage. (See rule <a href="#cr510">510</a>, “Combat Damage Step.”)</p>
<p><a id="cr702.19b"><b>702.19b</b></a> The controller of an attacking creature with trample first assigns damage to the creature(s) blocking it. Once all those blocking creatures are assigned lethal damage, any excess damage is assigned as its controller chooses among those blocking creatures and the player or planeswalker the creature is attacking. When checking for assigned lethal damage, take into account damage already marked on the creature and damage from other creatures that’s being assigned during the same combat damage step, but not any abilities or effects that might change the amount of damage that’s actually dealt. The attacking creature’s controller need not assign lethal damage to all those blocking creatures but in that case can’t assign any damage to the player or planeswalker it’s attacking.<br><b><i>Example:</b></i> A 2/2 creature that can block an additional creature blocks two attackers: a 1/1 with no abilities and a 3/3 with trample. The active player could assign 1 damage from the first attacker and 1 damage from the second to the blocking creature, and 2 damage to the defending player from the creature with trample.<br><b><i>Example:</b></i> A 6/6 green creature with trample is blocked by a 2/2 creature with protection from green. The attacking creature’s controller must assign at least 2 damage to the blocker, even though that damage will be prevented by the blocker’s protection ability. The attacking creature’s controller can divide the rest of the damage as they choose between the blocking creature and the defending player.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.19c"><b>702.19c</b></a> Trample over planeswalkers is a variant of trample that modifies the rules for assigning combat damage to planeswalkers. The controller of a creature with trample over planeswalkers assigns that creature’s combat damage as described in rule <a href="#cr702.19b">702.19b</a>, with one exception. If that creature is attacking a planeswalker, after lethal damage is assigned to all blocking creatures and damage at least equal to the loyalty of the planeswalker the creature is attacking is assigned to that planeswalker, further excess damage may be assigned as the attacking creature’s controller chooses among those blocking creatures, that planeswalker, and that planeswalker’s controller. When checking for assigned damage equal to a planeswalker’s loyalty, take into account damage from other creatures that’s being assigned during the same combat damage step, but not any abilities or effects that might change the amount of damage that’s actually dealt.<br><b><i>Example:</b></i> A player controls a planeswalker with three loyalty counters that is being attacked by a 1/1 with no abilities and a 7/7 with trample over planeswalkers. The active player could assign 1 damage from the first attacker and 2 damage from the second to the planeswalker and 5 damage to the defending player from the creature with trample over planeswalkers.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.19d"><b>702.19d</b></a> If an attacking creature with trample or trample over planeswalkers is blocked, but there are no creatures blocking it when damage is assigned, its damage is assigned to the defending player and/or planeswalker as though all blocking creatures have been assigned lethal damage.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.19e"><b>702.19e</b></a> If a creature with trample over planeswalkers is attacking a planeswalker and that planeswalker is removed from combat, the creature’s damage may be assigned to the defending player once all blocking creatures have been dealt lethal damage or, if there are no blocking creatures when damage is assigned, all its damage is assigned to the defending player. This does not cause the creature to be attacking that player.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.19f"><b>702.19f</b></a> If a creature without trample over planeswalkers is attacking a planeswalker, none of its combat damage can be assigned to the defending player, even if that planeswalker has been removed from combat or the damage the attacking creature could assign is greater than the planeswalker’s loyalty.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.19g"><b>702.19g</b></a> Multiple instances of trample on the same creature are redundant. Multiple instances of trample over planeswalkers on the same creature are redundant.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.20"><b>702.20.</b></a> Vigilance</p>
<p><a id="cr702.20a"><b>702.20a</b></a> Vigilance is a static ability that modifies the rules for the declare attackers step.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.20b"><b>702.20b</b></a> Attacking doesn’t cause creatures with vigilance to tap. (See rule <a href="#cr508">508</a>, “Declare Attackers Step.”)</p>
<p><a id="cr702.20c"><b>702.20c</b></a> Multiple instances of vigilance on the same creature are redundant.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.21"><b>702.21.</b></a> Ward</p>
<p><a id="cr702.21a"><b>702.21a</b></a> Ward is a triggered ability. Ward [cost] means “Whenever this permanent becomes the target of a spell or ability an opponent controls, counter that spell or ability unless that player pays [cost].”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.22"><b>702.22.</b></a> Banding</p>
<p><a id="cr702.22a"><b>702.22a</b></a> Banding is a static ability that modifies the rules for combat.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.22b"><b>702.22b</b></a> “Bands with other” is a special form of banding. If an effect causes a permanent to lose banding, the permanent loses all “bands with other” abilities as well.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.22c"><b>702.22c</b></a> As a player declares attackers, they may declare that one or more attacking creatures with banding and up to one attacking creature without banding (even if it has “bands with other”) are all in a “band.” They may also declare that one or more attacking [quality] creatures with “bands with other [quality]” and any number of other attacking [quality] creatures are all in a band. A player may declare as many attacking bands as they want, but each creature may be a member of only one of them. (Defending players can’t declare bands but may use banding in a different way; see rule <a href="#cr702.22j">702.22j</a>.)</p>
<p><a id="cr702.22d"><b>702.22d</b></a> All creatures in an attacking band must attack the same player or planeswalker.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.22e"><b>702.22e</b></a> Once an attacking band has been announced, it lasts for the rest of combat, even if something later removes banding or “bands with other” from one or more of the creatures in the band.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.22f"><b>702.22f</b></a> An attacking creature that’s removed from combat is also removed from the band it was in.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.22g"><b>702.22g</b></a> Banding doesn’t cause attacking creatures to share abilities, nor does it remove any abilities. The attacking creatures in a band are separate permanents.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.22h"><b>702.22h</b></a> If an attacking creature becomes blocked by a creature, each other creature in the same band as the attacking creature becomes blocked by that same blocking creature.<br><b><i>Example:</b></i> A player attacks with a band consisting of a creature with flying and a creature with swampwalk. The defending player, who controls a Swamp, can block the flying creature if able. If they do, then the creature with swampwalk will also become blocked by the blocking creature(s).</p>
<p><a id="cr702.22i"><b>702.22i</b></a> If one member of a band would become blocked due to an effect, the entire band becomes blocked.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.22j"><b>702.22j</b></a> During the combat damage step, if an attacking creature is being blocked by a creature with banding, or by both a [quality] creature with “bands with other [quality]” and another [quality] creature, the defending player (rather than the active player) chooses how the attacking creature’s damage is assigned. That player can divide that creature’s combat damage as they choose among any creatures blocking it. This is an exception to the procedure described in rule <a href="#cr510.1c">510.1c</a>.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.22k"><b>702.22k</b></a> During the combat damage step, if a blocking creature is blocking a creature with banding, or both a [quality] creature with “bands with other [quality]” and another [quality] creature, the active player (rather than the defending player) chooses how the blocking creature’s damage is assigned. That player can divide that creature’s combat damage as they choose among any creatures it’s blocking. This is an exception to the procedure described in rule <a href="#cr510.1d">510.1d</a>.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.22m"><b>702.22m</b></a> Multiple instances of banding on the same creature are redundant. Multiple instances of “bands with other” of the same kind on the same creature are redundant.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.23"><b>702.23.</b></a> Rampage</p>
<p><a id="cr702.23a"><b>702.23a</b></a> Rampage is a triggered ability. “Rampage N” means “Whenever this creature becomes blocked, it gets +N/+N until end of turn for each creature blocking it beyond the first.” (See rule <a href="#cr509">509</a>, “Declare Blockers Step.”)</p>
<p><a id="cr702.23b"><b>702.23b</b></a> The rampage bonus is calculated only once per combat, when the triggered ability resolves. Adding or removing blockers later in combat won’t change the bonus.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.23c"><b>702.23c</b></a> If a creature has multiple instances of rampage, each triggers separately.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.24"><b>702.24.</b></a> Cumulative Upkeep</p>
<p><a id="cr702.24a"><b>702.24a</b></a> Cumulative upkeep is a triggered ability that imposes an increasing cost on a permanent. “Cumulative upkeep [cost]” means “At the beginning of your upkeep, if this permanent is on the battlefield, put an age counter on this permanent. Then you may pay [cost] for each age counter on it. If you don’t, sacrifice it.” If [cost] has choices associated with it, each choice is made separately for each age counter, then either the entire set of costs is paid, or none of them is paid. Partial payments aren’t allowed.<br><b><i>Example:</b></i> A creature has “Cumulative upkeep {W} or {U}” and two age counters on it. When its ability next triggers and resolves, the creature’s controller puts an age counter on it and then may pay {W}{W}{W}, {W}{W}{U}, {W}{U}{U}, or {U}{U}{U} to keep the creature on the battlefield.<br><b><i>Example:</b></i> A creature has “Cumulative upkeep—Sacrifice a creature” and one age counter on it. When its ability next triggers and resolves, its controller can’t choose the same creature to sacrifice twice. Either two different creatures must be sacrificed, or the creature with cumulative upkeep must be sacrificed.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.24b"><b>702.24b</b></a> If a permanent has multiple instances of cumulative upkeep, each triggers separately. However, the age counters are not connected to any particular ability; each cumulative upkeep ability will count the total number of age counters on the permanent at the time that ability resolves.<br><b><i>Example:</b></i> A creature has two instances of “Cumulative upkeep—Pay 1 life.” The creature has no age counters, and both cumulative upkeep abilities trigger. When the first ability resolves, the controller adds a counter and then chooses to pay 1 life. When the second ability resolves, the controller adds another counter and then chooses to pay an additional 2 life.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.25"><b>702.25.</b></a> Flanking</p>
<p><a id="cr702.25a"><b>702.25a</b></a> Flanking is a triggered ability that triggers during the declare blockers step. (See rule <a href="#cr509">509</a>, “Declare Blockers Step.”) “Flanking” means “Whenever this creature becomes blocked by a creature without flanking, the blocking creature gets -1/-1 until end of turn.”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.25b"><b>702.25b</b></a> If a creature has multiple instances of flanking, each triggers separately.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.26"><b>702.26.</b></a> Phasing</p>
<p><a id="cr702.26a"><b>702.26a</b></a> Phasing is a static ability that modifies the rules of the untap step. During each player’s untap step, before the active player untaps permanents, all phased-in permanents with phasing that player controls “phase out.” Simultaneously, all phased-out permanents that had phased out under that player’s control “phase in.”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.26b"><b>702.26b</b></a> If a permanent phases out, its status changes to “phased out.” Except for rules and effects that specifically mention phased-out permanents, a phased-out permanent is treated as though it does not exist. It can’t affect or be affected by anything else in the game. A permanent that phases out is removed from combat. (See rule <a href="#cr506.4">506.4</a>.)<br><b><i>Example:</b></i> You control three creatures, one of which is phased out. You cast a spell that says “Draw a card for each creature you control.” You draw two cards.<br><b><i>Example:</b></i> You control a phased-out creature. You cast a spell that says “Destroy all creatures.” The phased-out creature is not destroyed.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.26c"><b>702.26c</b></a> If a permanent phases in, its status changes to “phased in.” The game once again treats it as though it exists.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.26d"><b>702.26d</b></a> The phasing event doesn’t actually cause a permanent to change zones or control, even though it’s treated as though it’s not on the battlefield and not under its controller’s control while it’s phased out. Zone-change triggers don’t trigger when a permanent phases in or out. Tokens continue to exist on the battlefield while phased out. Counters remain on a permanent while it’s phased out. Effects that check a phased-in permanent’s history won’t treat the phasing event as having caused the permanent to leave or enter the battlefield or its controller’s control.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.26e"><b>702.26e</b></a> If a continuous effect generated by the resolution of a spell or ability modifies the characteristics or changes the controller of any objects, a phased-out permanent won’t be included in the set of affected objects. This includes continuous effects that reference the permanent specifically, unless they also specifically refer to the permanent as phased out.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.26f"><b>702.26f</b></a> Continuous effects that affect a phased-out permanent may expire while that permanent is phased out. If so, they will no longer affect that permanent once it’s phased in. In particular, effects with “for as long as” durations that track that permanent (see rule <a href="#cr611.2b">611.2b</a>) end when that permanent phases out because they can no longer see it.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.26g"><b>702.26g</b></a> When a permanent phases out, any Auras, Equipment, or Fortifications attached to that permanent phase out at the same time. This alternate way of phasing out is known as phasing out “indirectly.” An Aura, Equipment, or Fortification that phased out indirectly won’t phase in by itself, but instead phases in along with the permanent it’s attached to.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.26h"><b>702.26h</b></a> If an object would simultaneously phase out directly and indirectly, it just phases out indirectly.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.26i"><b>702.26i</b></a> An Aura, Equipment, or Fortification that phased out directly will phase in attached to the object or player it was attached to when it phased out, if that object is still in the same zone or that player is still in the game. If not, that Aura, Equipment, or Fortification phases in unattached. State-based actions apply as appropriate. (See rules <a href="#cr704.5m">704.5m</a> and <a href="#cr704.5n">704.5n</a>.)</p>
<p><a id="cr702.26j"><b>702.26j</b></a> Abilities that trigger when a permanent becomes attached or unattached from an object or player don’t trigger when that permanent phases in or out.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.26k"><b>702.26k</b></a> Phased-out permanents owned by a player who leaves the game also leave the game. This doesn’t trigger zone-change triggers. See rule <a href="#cr800.4">800.4</a>.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.26m"><b>702.26m</b></a> If an effect causes a player to skip their untap step, the phasing event simply doesn’t occur that turn.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.26n"><b>702.26n</b></a> In a multiplayer game, game rules may cause a phased-out permanent to leave the game or to be exiled once a player leaves the game. (See rules <a href="#cr800.4a">800.4a</a> and <a href="#cr800.4c">800.4c</a>.) If a phased-out permanent phased out under the control of a player who has left the game, that permanent phases in during the next untap step after that player’s next turn would have begun.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.26p"><b>702.26p</b></a> Multiple instances of phasing on the same permanent are redundant.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.27"><b>702.27.</b></a> Buyback</p>
<p><a id="cr702.27a"><b>702.27a</b></a> Buyback appears on some instants and sorceries. It represents two static abilities that function while the spell is on the stack. “Buyback [cost]” means “You may pay an additional [cost] as you cast this spell” and “If the buyback cost was paid, put this spell into its owner’s hand instead of into that player’s graveyard as it resolves.” Paying a spell’s buyback cost follows the rules for paying additional costs in rules <a href="#cr601.2b">601.2b</a> and <a href="#cr601.2f">601.2f</a>–h.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.28"><b>702.28.</b></a> Shadow</p>
<p><a id="cr702.28a"><b>702.28a</b></a> Shadow is an evasion ability.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.28b"><b>702.28b</b></a> A creature with shadow can’t be blocked by creatures without shadow, and a creature without shadow can’t be blocked by creatures with shadow. (See rule <a href="#cr509">509</a>, “Declare Blockers Step.”)</p>
<p><a id="cr702.28c"><b>702.28c</b></a> Multiple instances of shadow on the same creature are redundant.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.29"><b>702.29.</b></a> Cycling</p>
<p><a id="cr702.29a"><b>702.29a</b></a> Cycling is an activated ability that functions only while the card with cycling is in a player’s hand. “Cycling [cost]” means “[Cost], Discard this card: Draw a card.”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.29b"><b>702.29b</b></a> Although the cycling ability can be activated only if the card is in a player’s hand, it continues to exist while the object is on the battlefield and in all other zones. Therefore objects with cycling will be affected by effects that depend on objects having one or more activated abilities.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.29c"><b>702.29c</b></a> Some cards with cycling have abilities that trigger when they’re cycled. “When you cycle [this card]” means “When you discard [this card] to pay an activation cost of a cycling ability.” These abilities trigger from whatever zone the card winds up in after it’s cycled.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.29d"><b>702.29d</b></a> Some cards have abilities that trigger whenever a player “cycles or discards” a card. These abilities trigger only once when a card is cycled.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.29e"><b>702.29e</b></a> Typecycling is a variant of the cycling ability. “[Type]cycling [cost]” means “[Cost], Discard this card: Search your library for a [type] card, reveal it, and put it into your hand. Then shuffle your library.” This type is usually a subtype (as in “mountaincycling”) but can be any card type, subtype, supertype, or combination thereof (as in “basic landcycling”).</p>
<p><a id="cr702.29f"><b>702.29f</b></a> Typecycling abilities are cycling abilities, and typecycling costs are cycling costs. Any cards that trigger when a player cycles a card will trigger when a card is discarded to pay an activation cost of a typecycling ability. Any effect that stops players from cycling cards will stop players from activating cards’ typecycling abilities. Any effect that increases or reduces a cycling cost will increase or reduce a typecycling cost. Any effect that looks for a card with cycling will find a card with typecycling.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.30"><b>702.30.</b></a> Echo</p>
<p><a id="cr702.30a"><b>702.30a</b></a> Echo is a triggered ability. “Echo [cost]” means “At the beginning of your upkeep, if this permanent came under your control since the beginning of your last upkeep, sacrifice it unless you pay [cost].”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.30b"><b>702.30b</b></a> Urza block cards with the echo ability were printed without an echo cost. These cards have been given errata in the Oracle card reference; each one now has an echo cost equal to its mana cost.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.31"><b>702.31.</b></a> Horsemanship</p>
<p><a id="cr702.31a"><b>702.31a</b></a> Horsemanship is an evasion ability.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.31b"><b>702.31b</b></a> A creature with horsemanship can’t be blocked by creatures without horsemanship. A creature with horsemanship can block a creature with or without horsemanship. (See rule <a href="#cr509">509</a>, “Declare Blockers Step.”)</p>
<p><a id="cr702.31c"><b>702.31c</b></a> Multiple instances of horsemanship on the same creature are redundant.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.32"><b>702.32.</b></a> Fading</p>
<p><a id="cr702.32a"><b>702.32a</b></a> Fading is a keyword that represents two abilities. “Fading N” means “This permanent enters the battlefield with N fade counters on it” and “At the beginning of your upkeep, remove a fade counter from this permanent. If you can’t, sacrifice the permanent.”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.33"><b>702.33.</b></a> Kicker</p>
<p><a id="cr702.33a"><b>702.33a</b></a> Kicker is a static ability that functions while the spell with kicker is on the stack. “Kicker [cost]” means “You may pay an additional [cost] as you cast this spell.” Paying a spell’s kicker cost(s) follows the rules for paying additional costs in rules <a href="#cr601.2b">601.2b</a> and <a href="#cr601.2f">601.2f</a>–h.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.33b"><b>702.33b</b></a> The phrase “Kicker [cost 1] and/or [cost 2]” means the same thing as “Kicker [cost 1], kicker [cost 2].”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.33c"><b>702.33c</b></a> Multikicker is a variant of the kicker ability. “Multikicker [cost]” means “You may pay an additional [cost] any number of times as you cast this spell.” A multikicker cost is a kicker cost.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.33d"><b>702.33d</b></a> If a spell’s controller declares the intention to pay any of that spell’s kicker costs, that spell has been “kicked.” If a spell has two kicker costs or has multikicker, it may be kicked multiple times. See rule <a href="#cr601.2b">601.2b</a>.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.33e"><b>702.33e</b></a> Objects with kicker or multikicker have additional abilities that specify what happens if they are kicked. These abilities are linked to the kicker or multikicker abilities printed on that object: they can refer only to those specific kicker or multikicker abilities. See rule <a href="#cr607">607</a>, “Linked Abilities.”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.33f"><b>702.33f</b></a> Objects with more than one kicker cost have abilities that each correspond to a specific kicker cost. They contain the phrases “if it was kicked with its [A] kicker” and “if it was kicked with its [B] kicker,” where A and B are the first and second kicker costs listed on the card, respectively. Each of those abilities is linked to the appropriate kicker ability.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.33g"><b>702.33g</b></a> If part of a spell’s ability has its effect only if that spell was kicked, and that part of the ability includes any targets, the spell’s controller chooses those targets only if that spell was kicked. Otherwise, the spell is cast as if it did not have those targets. See rule <a href="#cr601.2c">601.2c</a>.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.34"><b>702.34.</b></a> Flashback</p>
<p><a id="cr702.34a"><b>702.34a</b></a> Flashback appears on some instants and sorceries. It represents two static abilities: one that functions while the card is in a player’s graveyard and another that functions while the card is on the stack. “Flashback [cost]” means “You may cast this card from your graveyard if the resulting spell is an instant or sorcery spell by paying [cost] rather than paying its mana cost” and “If the flashback cost was paid, exile this card instead of putting it anywhere else any time it would leave the stack.” Casting a spell using its flashback ability follows the rules for paying alternative costs in rules <a href="#cr601.2b">601.2b</a> and <a href="#cr601.2f">601.2f</a>–h.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.35"><b>702.35.</b></a> Madness</p>
<p><a id="cr702.35a"><b>702.35a</b></a> Madness is a keyword that represents two abilities. The first is a static ability that functions while the card with madness is in a player’s hand. The second is a triggered ability that functions when the first ability is applied. “Madness [cost]” means “If a player would discard this card, that player discards it, but exiles it instead of putting it into their graveyard” and “When this card is exiled this way, its owner may cast it by paying [cost] rather than paying its mana cost. If that player doesn’t, they put this card into their graveyard.”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.35b"><b>702.35b</b></a> Casting a spell using its madness ability follows the rules for paying alternative costs in rules <a href="#cr601.2b">601.2b</a> and <a href="#cr601.2f">601.2f</a>–h.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.35c"><b>702.35c</b></a> After resolving a madness triggered ability, if the exiled card wasn’t cast and was moved to a public zone, effects referencing the discarded card can find that card. See rule <a href="#cr400.7i">400.7i</a>.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.36"><b>702.36.</b></a> Fear</p>
<p><a id="cr702.36a"><b>702.36a</b></a> Fear is an evasion ability.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.36b"><b>702.36b</b></a> A creature with fear can’t be blocked except by artifact creatures and/or black creatures. (See rule <a href="#cr509">509</a>, “Declare Blockers Step.”)</p>
<p><a id="cr702.36c"><b>702.36c</b></a> Multiple instances of fear on the same creature are redundant.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.37"><b>702.37.</b></a> Morph</p>
<p><a id="cr702.37a"><b>702.37a</b></a> Morph is a static ability that functions in any zone from which you could play the card it’s on, and the morph effect works any time the card is face down. “Morph [cost]” means “You may cast this card as a 2/2 face-down creature with no text, no name, no subtypes, and no mana cost by paying {3} rather than paying its mana cost.” (See rule <a href="#cr708">708</a>, “Face-Down Spells and Permanents.”)</p>
<p><a id="cr702.37b"><b>702.37b</b></a> Megamorph is a variant of the morph ability. “Megamorph [cost]” means “You may cast this card as a 2/2 face-down creature with no text, no name, no subtypes, and no mana cost by paying {3} rather than paying its mana cost” and “As this permanent is turned face up, put a +1/+1 counter on it if its megamorph cost was paid to turn it face up.” A megamorph cost is a morph cost.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.37c"><b>702.37c</b></a> Metamorph is a variant of the morph ability. “Metamorph (cost)” means “You may cast this card as a 2/2 face-down creature with no text, no name, no subtypes, and no mana cost by paying (3) rather than paying its mana cost.” and “As this permanent is turned face up, cast it without paying its mana cost if its metamorph cost was paid to turn it face up.” A metamorph cost is a morph cost. There is never a time where a face up card with metamorph is on the battlefield.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.37d"><b>702.37d</b></a> To cast a card using its morph ability, turn it face down. It becomes a 2/2 face-down creature card with no text, no name, no subtypes, and no mana cost. Any effects or prohibitions that would apply to casting a card with these characteristics (and not the face-up card’s characteristics) are applied to casting this card. These values are the copiable values of that object’s characteristics. (See rule <a href="#cr613">613</a>, “Interaction of Continuous Effects,” and rule <a href="#cr707">707</a>, “Copying Objects.”) Put it onto the stack (as a face-down spell with the same characteristics), and pay {3} rather than pay its mana cost. This follows the rules for paying alternative costs. You can use a morph ability to cast a card from any zone from which you could normally play it. When the spell resolves, it enters the battlefield with the same characteristics the spell had. The morph effect applies to the face-down object wherever it is, and it ends when the permanent is turned face up.</p>
