<p><a id="cr702.37e"><b>702.37e</b></a> You can’t normally cast a card face down. A morph ability allows you to do so.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.37f"><b>702.37f</b></a> Any time you have priority, you may turn a face-down permanent you control with a morph ability face up. This is a special action; it doesn’t use the stack (see rule <a href="#cr116">116</a>). To do this, show all players what the permanent’s morph cost would be if it were face up, pay that cost, then turn the permanent face up. (If the permanent wouldn’t have a morph cost if it were face up, it can’t be turned face up this way.) The morph effect on it ends, and it regains its normal characteristics. Any abilities relating to the permanent entering the battlefield don’t trigger when it’s turned face up and don’t have any effect, because the permanent has already entered the battlefield.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.37g"><b>702.37g</b></a> If a permanent’s morph cost includes X, other abilities of that permanent may also refer to X. The value of X in those abilities is equal to the value of X chosen as the morph special action was taken.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.37h"><b>702.37h</b></a> See rule <a href="#cr708">708</a>, “Face-Down Spells and Permanents,” for more information about how to cast cards with a morph ability.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.38"><b>702.38.</b></a> Amplify</p>
<p><a id="cr702.38a"><b>702.38a</b></a> Amplify is a static ability. “Amplify N” means “As this object enters the battlefield, reveal any number of cards from your hand that share a creature type with it. This permanent enters the battlefield with N +1/+1 counters on it for each card revealed this way. You can’t reveal this card or any other cards that are entering the battlefield at the same time as this card.”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.38b"><b>702.38b</b></a> If a creature has multiple instances of amplify, each one works separately.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.39"><b>702.39.</b></a> Provoke</p>
<p><a id="cr702.39a"><b>702.39a</b></a> Provoke is a triggered ability. “Provoke” means “Whenever this creature attacks, you may choose to have target creature defending player controls block this creature this combat if able. If you do, untap that creature.”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.39b"><b>702.39b</b></a> If a creature has multiple instances of provoke, each triggers separately.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.40"><b>702.40.</b></a> Storm</p>
<p><a id="cr702.40a"><b>702.40a</b></a> Storm is a triggered ability that functions on the stack. “Storm” means “When you cast this spell, copy it for each other spell that was cast before it this turn. If the spell has any targets, you may choose new targets for any of the copies.”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.40b"><b>702.40b</b></a> If a spell has multiple instances of storm, each triggers separately.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.41"><b>702.41.</b></a> Affinity</p>
<p><a id="cr702.41a"><b>702.41a</b></a> Affinity is a static ability that functions while the spell with affinity is on the stack. “Affinity for [text]” means “This spell costs you {1} less to cast for each [text] you control.”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.41b"><b>702.41b</b></a> If a spell has multiple instances of affinity, each of them applies.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.42"><b>702.42.</b></a> Entwine</p>
<p><a id="cr702.42a"><b>702.42a</b></a> Entwine is a static ability of modal spells (see rule <a href="#cr700.2">700.2</a>) that functions while the spell is on the stack. “Entwine [cost]” means “You may choose all modes of this spell instead of just the number specified. If you do, you pay an additional [cost].” Using the entwine ability follows the rules for choosing modes and paying additional costs in rules <a href="#cr601.2b">601.2b</a> and <a href="#cr601.2f">601.2f</a>–h.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.42b"><b>702.42b</b></a> If the entwine cost was paid, follow the text of each of the modes in the order written on the card when the spell resolves.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.43"><b>702.43.</b></a> Modular</p>
<p><a id="cr702.43a"><b>702.43a</b></a> Modular represents both a static ability and a triggered ability. “Modular N” means “This permanent enters the battlefield with N +1/+1 counters on it” and “When this permanent is put into a graveyard from the battlefield, you may put a +1/+1 counter on target artifact creature for each +1/+1 counter on this permanent.”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.43b"><b>702.43b</b></a> If a creature has multiple instances of modular, each one works separately.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.44"><b>702.44.</b></a> Sunburst</p>
<p><a id="cr702.44a"><b>702.44a</b></a> Sunburst is a static ability that functions as an object is entering the battlefield. “Sunburst” means “If this object is entering the battlefield as a creature, ignoring any type-changing effects that would affect it, it enters the battlefield with a +1/+1 counter on it for each color of mana spent to cast it. Otherwise, it enters the battlefield with a charge counter on it for each color of mana spent to cast it.”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.44b"><b>702.44b</b></a> Sunburst adds counters only if the object with sunburst is entering the battlefield from the stack as a resolving spell and only if one or more colored mana was spent on its costs, including additional or alternative costs.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.44c"><b>702.44c</b></a> Sunburst can also be used to set a variable number for another ability. If the keyword is used in this way, it doesn’t matter whether the ability is on a creature spell or on a noncreature spell.<br><b><i>Example:</b></i> The ability “Modular—Sunburst” means “This permanent enters the battlefield with a +1/+1 counter on it for each color of mana spent to cast it” and “When this permanent is put into a graveyard from the battlefield, you may put a +1/+1 counter on target artifact creature for each +1/+1 counter on this permanent.”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.44d"><b>702.44d</b></a> If an object has multiple instances of sunburst, each one works separately.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.45"><b>702.45.</b></a> Bushido</p>
<p><a id="cr702.45a"><b>702.45a</b></a> Bushido is a triggered ability. “Bushido N” means “Whenever this creature blocks or becomes blocked, it gets +N/+N until end of turn.” (See rule <a href="#cr509">509</a>, “Declare Blockers Step.”)</p>
<p><a id="cr702.45b"><b>702.45b</b></a> If a creature has multiple instances of bushido, each triggers separately.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.46"><b>702.46.</b></a> Soulshift</p>
<p><a id="cr702.46a"><b>702.46a</b></a> Soulshift is a triggered ability. “Soulshift N” means “When this permanent is put into a graveyard from the battlefield, you may return target Spirit card with mana value N or less from your graveyard to your hand.”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.46b"><b>702.46b</b></a> If a permanent has multiple instances of soulshift, each triggers separately.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.47"><b>702.47.</b></a> Splice</p>
<p><a id="cr702.47a"><b>702.47a</b></a> Splice is a static ability that functions while a card is in your hand. “Splice onto [quality] [cost]” means “You may reveal this card from your hand as you cast a [quality] spell. If you do, that spell gains the text of this card’s rules text and you pay [cost] as an additional cost to cast that spell.” Paying a card’s splice cost follows the rules for paying additional costs in rules <a href="#cr601.2b">601.2b</a> and <a href="#cr601.2f">601.2f</a>–h.<br><b><i>Example:</b></i> Since the card with splice remains in the player’s hand, it can later be cast normally or spliced onto another spell. It can even be discarded to pay a “discard a card” cost of the spell it’s spliced onto.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.47b"><b>702.47b</b></a> You can’t choose to use a splice ability if you can’t make the required choices (targets, etc.) for that card’s rules text. You can’t splice any one card onto the same spell more than once. If you’re splicing more than one card onto a spell, reveal them all at once and choose the order in which their effects will happen. The effects of the main spell must happen first.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.47c"><b>702.47c</b></a> The spell has the characteristics of the main spell, plus the rules text of each of the spliced cards. This is a text-changing effect (see rule <a href="#cr612">612</a>, “Text-Changing Effects”). The spell doesn’t gain any other characteristics (name, mana cost, color, supertypes, card types, subtypes, etc.) of the spliced cards. Text gained by the spell that refers to a card by name refers to the spell on the stack, not the card from which the text was copied.<br><b><i>Example:</b></i> Glacial Ray is a red card with splice onto Arcane that reads, “Glacial Ray deals 2 damage to any target.” Suppose Glacial Ray is spliced onto Reach Through Mists, a blue spell. The spell is still blue, and Reach Through Mists deals the damage. This means that the ability can target a creature with protection from red and deal 2 damage to that creature.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.47d"><b>702.47d</b></a> Choose targets for the added text normally (see rule <a href="#cr601.2c">601.2c</a>). Note that a spell with one or more targets won’t resolve if all of its targets are illegal on resolution.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.47e"><b>702.47e</b></a> The spell loses any splice changes once it leaves the stack for any reason.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.48"><b>702.48.</b></a> Offering</p>
<p><a id="cr702.48a"><b>702.48a</b></a> Offering is a static ability that functions while the spell with offering is on the stack. “[Subtype] offering” means “As an additional cost to cast this spell, you may sacrifice a [subtype] permanent. If you chose to pay the additional cost, this spell’s total cost is reduced by the sacrificed permanent’s mana cost, and you may cast this spell any time you could cast an instant.”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.48b"><b>702.48b</b></a> You choose which permanent to sacrifice as you make choices for the spell (see rule <a href="#cr601.2b">601.2b</a>), and you sacrifice that permanent as you pay the total cost (see rule <a href="#cr601.2h">601.2h</a>).</p>
<p><a id="cr702.48c"><b>702.48c</b></a> Generic mana in the sacrificed permanent’s mana cost reduces generic mana in the spell’s total cost. Colored and colorless mana in the sacrificed permanent’s mana cost reduces mana of the same type in spell’s total cost, and any excess reduces that much generic mana in spell’s total cost. (See rule <a href="#cr118.7">118.7</a>.)</p>
<p><a id="cr702.49"><b>702.49.</b></a> Ninjutsu</p>
<p><a id="cr702.49a"><b>702.49a</b></a> Ninjutsu is an activated ability that functions only while the card with ninjutsu is in a player’s hand. “Ninjutsu [cost]” means “[Cost], Reveal this card from your hand, Return an unblocked attacking creature you control to its owner’s hand: Put this card onto the battlefield from your hand tapped and attacking.”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.49b"><b>702.49b</b></a> The card with ninjutsu remains revealed from the time the ability is announced until the ability leaves the stack.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.49c"><b>702.49c</b></a> A ninjutsu ability may be activated only while a creature on the battlefield is unblocked (see rule <a href="#cr509.1h">509.1h</a>). The creature with ninjutsu is put onto the battlefield unblocked. It will be attacking the same player or planeswalker as the creature that was returned to its owner’s hand.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.49d"><b>702.49d</b></a> Commander ninjutsu is a variant of the ninjutsu ability that also functions while the card with commander ninjutsu is in the command zone. “Commander ninjutsu [cost]” means “[Cost], Reveal this card from your hand or from the command zone, Return an unblocked attacking creature you control to its owner’s hand: Put this card onto the battlefield tapped and attacking.”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.50"><b>702.50.</b></a> Epic</p>
<p><a id="cr702.50a"><b>702.50a</b></a> Epic represents two spell abilities, one of which creates a delayed triggered ability. “Epic” means “For the rest of the game, you can’t cast spells,” and “At the beginning of each of your upkeeps for the rest of the game, copy this spell except for its epic ability. If the spell has any targets, you may choose new targets for the copy.” See rule <a href="#cr707.10">707.10</a>.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.50b"><b>702.50b</b></a> A player can’t cast spells once a spell with epic they control resolves, but effects (such as the epic ability itself) can still put copies of spells onto the stack.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.51"><b>702.51.</b></a> Convoke</p>
<p><a id="cr702.51a"><b>702.51a</b></a> Convoke is a static ability that functions while the spell with convoke is on the stack. “Convoke” means “For each colored mana in this spell’s total cost, you may tap an untapped creature of that color you control rather than pay that mana. For each generic mana in this spell’s total cost, you may tap an untapped creature you control rather than pay that mana.”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.51b"><b>702.51b</b></a> The convoke ability isn’t an additional or alternative cost and applies only after the total cost of the spell with convoke is determined.<br><b><i>Example:</b></i> Heartless Summoning says, in part, “Creature spells you cast cost {2} less to cast.” You control Heartless Summoning and cast Siege Wurm, a spell with convoke that costs {5}{G}{G}. The total cost to cast Siege Wurm is {3}{G}{G}. After activating mana abilities, you pay that total cost. You may tap up to two green creatures and up to three other creatures to pay that cost, and the remainder is paid with mana.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.51c"><b>702.51c</b></a> A creature tapped to pay for mana in a spell’s total cost this way is said to have “convoked” that spell.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.51d"><b>702.51d</b></a> Multiple instances of convoke on the same spell are redundant.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.52"><b>702.52.</b></a> Dredge</p>
<p><a id="cr702.52a"><b>702.52a</b></a> Dredge is a static ability that functions only while the card with dredge is in a player’s graveyard. “Dredge N” means “As long as you have at least N cards in your library, if you would draw a card, you may instead mill N cards and return this card from your graveyard to your hand.”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.52b"><b>702.52b</b></a> A player with fewer cards in their library than the number required by a dredge ability can’t mill any of them this way.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.53"><b>702.53.</b></a> Transmute</p>
<p><a id="cr702.53a"><b>702.53a</b></a> Transmute is an activated ability that functions only while the card with transmute is in a player’s hand. “Transmute [cost]” means “[Cost], Discard this card: Search your library for a card with the same mana value as the discarded card, reveal that card, and put it into your hand. Then shuffle your library. Activate only as a sorcery.”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.53b"><b>702.53b</b></a> Although the transmute ability can be activated only if the card is in a player’s hand, it continues to exist while the object is on the battlefield and in all other zones. Therefore objects with transmute will be affected by effects that depend on objects having one or more activated abilities.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.54"><b>702.54.</b></a> Bloodthirst</p>
<p><a id="cr702.54a"><b>702.54a</b></a> Bloodthirst is a static ability. “Bloodthirst N” means “If an opponent was dealt damage this turn, this permanent enters the battlefield with N +1/+1 counters on it.”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.54b"><b>702.54b</b></a> “Bloodthirst X” is a special form of bloodthirst. “Bloodthirst X” means “This permanent enters the battlefield with X +1/+1 counters on it, where X is the total damage your opponents have been dealt this turn.”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.54c"><b>702.54c</b></a> If an object has multiple instances of bloodthirst, each applies separately.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.55"><b>702.55.</b></a> Haunt</p>
<p><a id="cr702.55a"><b>702.55a</b></a> Haunt is a triggered ability. “Haunt” on a permanent means “When this permanent is put into a graveyard from the battlefield, exile it haunting target creature.” “Haunt” on an instant or sorcery spell means “When this spell is put into a graveyard during its resolution, exile it haunting target creature.”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.55b"><b>702.55b</b></a> Cards that are in the exile zone as the result of a haunt ability “haunt” the creature targeted by that ability. The phrase “creature it haunts” refers to the object targeted by the haunt ability, regardless of whether or not that object is still a creature.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.55c"><b>702.55c</b></a> Triggered abilities of cards with haunt that refer to the haunted creature can trigger in the exile zone.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.56"><b>702.56.</b></a> Replicate</p>
<p><a id="cr702.56a"><b>702.56a</b></a> Replicate is a keyword that represents two abilities. The first is a static ability that functions while the spell with replicate is on the stack. The second is a triggered ability that functions while the spell with replicate is on the stack. “Replicate [cost]” means “As an additional cost to cast this spell, you may pay [cost] any number of times” and “When you cast this spell, if a replicate cost was paid for it, copy it for each time its replicate cost was paid. If the spell has any targets, you may choose new targets for any of the copies.” Paying a spell’s replicate cost follows the rules for paying additional costs in rules <a href="#cr601.2b">601.2b</a> and <a href="#cr601.2f">601.2f</a>–h.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.56b"><b>702.56b</b></a> If a spell has multiple instances of replicate, each is paid separately and triggers based on the payments made for it, not any other instance of replicate.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.57"><b>702.57.</b></a> Forecast</p>
<p><a id="cr702.57a"><b>702.57a</b></a> A forecast ability is a special kind of activated ability that can be activated only from a player’s hand. It’s written “Forecast — [Activated ability].”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.57b"><b>702.57b</b></a> A forecast ability may be activated only during the upkeep step of the card’s owner and only once each turn. The controller of the forecast ability reveals the card with that ability from their hand as the ability is activated. That player plays with that card revealed in their hand until it leaves the player’s hand or until a step or phase that isn’t an upkeep step begins, whichever comes first.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.58"><b>702.58.</b></a> Graft</p>
<p><a id="cr702.58a"><b>702.58a</b></a> Graft represents both a static ability and a triggered ability. “Graft N” means “This permanent enters the battlefield with N +1/+1 counters on it” and “Whenever another creature enters the battlefield, if this permanent has a +1/+1 counter on it, you may move a +1/+1 counter from this permanent onto that creature.”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.58b"><b>702.58b</b></a> If a permanent has multiple instances of graft, each one works separately.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.59"><b>702.59.</b></a> Recover</p>
<p><a id="cr702.59a"><b>702.59a</b></a> Recover is a triggered ability that functions only while the card with recover is in a player’s graveyard. “Recover [cost]” means “When a creature is put into your graveyard from the battlefield, you may pay [cost]. If you do, return this card from your graveyard to your hand. Otherwise, exile this card.”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.60"><b>702.60.</b></a> Ripple</p>
<p><a id="cr702.60a"><b>702.60a</b></a> Ripple is a triggered ability that functions only while the card with ripple is on the stack. “Ripple N” means “When you cast this spell, you may reveal the top N cards of your library, or, if there are fewer than N cards in your library, you may reveal all the cards in your library. If you reveal cards from your library this way, you may cast any of those cards with the same name as this spell without paying their mana costs, then put all revealed cards not cast this way on the bottom of your library in any order.”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.60b"><b>702.60b</b></a> If a spell has multiple instances of ripple, each triggers separately.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.61"><b>702.61.</b></a> Split Second</p>
<p><a id="cr702.61a"><b>702.61a</b></a> Split second is a static ability that functions only while the spell with split second is on the stack. “Split second” means “As long as this spell is on the stack, players can’t cast other spells or activate abilities that aren’t mana abilities.”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.61b"><b>702.61b</b></a> Players may activate mana abilities and take special actions while a spell with split second is on the stack. Triggered abilities trigger and are put on the stack as normal while a spell with split second is on the stack.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.61c"><b>702.61c</b></a> Multiple instances of split second on the same spell are redundant.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.62"><b>702.62.</b></a> Suspend</p>
<p><a id="cr702.62a"><b>702.62a</b></a> Suspend is a keyword that represents three abilities. The first is a static ability that functions while the card with suspend is in a player’s hand. The second and third are triggered abilities that function in the exile zone. “Suspend N—[cost]” means “If you could begin to cast this card by putting it onto the stack from your hand, you may pay [cost] and exile it with N time counters on it. This action doesn’t use the stack,” and “At the beginning of your upkeep, if this card is suspended, remove a time counter from it,” and “When the last time counter is removed from this card, if it’s exiled, play it without paying its mana cost if able. If you can’t, it remains exiled. If you cast a creature spell this way, it gains haste until you lose control of the spell or the permanent it becomes.”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.62b"><b>702.62b</b></a> A card is “suspended” if it’s in the exile zone, has suspend, and has a time counter on it.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.62c"><b>702.62c</b></a> While determining if you could begin to cast a card with suspend, take into consideration any effects that would prohibit that card from being cast.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.62d"><b>702.62d</b></a> Casting a spell as an effect of its suspend ability follows the rules for paying alternative costs in rules <a href="#cr601.2b">601.2b</a> and <a href="#cr601.2f">601.2f</a>–h.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.63"><b>702.63.</b></a> Vanishing</p>
<p><a id="cr702.63a"><b>702.63a</b></a> Vanishing is a keyword that represents three abilities. “Vanishing N” means “This permanent enters the battlefield with N time counters on it,” “At the beginning of your upkeep, if this permanent has a time counter on it, remove a time counter from it,” and “When the last time counter is removed from this permanent, sacrifice it.”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.63b"><b>702.63b</b></a> Vanishing without a number means “At the beginning of your upkeep, if this permanent has a time counter on it, remove a time counter from it” and “When the last time counter is removed from this permanent, sacrifice it.”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.63c"><b>702.63c</b></a> If a permanent has multiple instances of vanishing, each works separately.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.64"><b>702.64.</b></a> Absorb</p>
<p><a id="cr702.64a"><b>702.64a</b></a> Absorb is a static ability. “Absorb N” means “If a source would deal damage to this creature, prevent N of that damage.”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.64b"><b>702.64b</b></a> Each absorb ability can prevent only N damage from any one source at any one time. It will apply separately to damage from other sources, or to damage dealt by the same source at a different time.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.64c"><b>702.64c</b></a> If an object has multiple instances of absorb, each applies separately.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.65"><b>702.65.</b></a> Aura Swap</p>
<p><a id="cr702.65a"><b>702.65a</b></a> Aura swap is an activated ability of some Aura cards. “Aura swap [cost]” means “[Cost]: You may exchange this permanent with an Aura card in your hand.”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.65b"><b>702.65b</b></a> If either half of the exchange can’t be completed, the ability has no effect.<br><b><i>Example:</b></i> You activate the aura swap ability of an Aura. The only Aura card in your hand can’t enchant the permanent that’s enchanted by the Aura with aura swap. The ability has no effect.<br><b><i>Example:</b></i> You activate the aura swap ability of an Aura that you control but you don’t own. The ability has no effect.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.66"><b>702.66.</b></a> Delve</p>
<p><a id="cr702.66a"><b>702.66a</b></a> Delve is a static ability that functions while the spell with delve is on the stack. “Delve” means “For each generic mana in this spell’s total cost, you may exile a card from your graveyard rather than pay that mana.”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.66b"><b>702.66b</b></a> The delve ability isn’t an additional or alternative cost and applies only after the total cost of the spell with delve is determined.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.66c"><b>702.66c</b></a> Multiple instances of delve on the same spell are redundant.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.67"><b>702.67.</b></a> Fortify</p>
<p><a id="cr702.67a"><b>702.67a</b></a> Fortify is an activated ability of Fortification cards. “Fortify [cost]” means “[Cost]: Attach this Fortification to target land you control. Activate only as a sorcery.”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.67b"><b>702.67b</b></a> For more information about Fortifications, see rule <a href="#cr301">301</a>, “Artifacts.”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.67c"><b>702.67c</b></a> If a Fortification has multiple instances of fortify, any of its fortify abilities may be used.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.68"><b>702.68.</b></a> Frenzy</p>
<p><a id="cr702.68a"><b>702.68a</b></a> Frenzy is a triggered ability. “Frenzy N” means “Whenever this creature attacks and isn’t blocked, it gets +N/+0 until end of turn.”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.68b"><b>702.68b</b></a> If a creature has multiple instances of frenzy, each triggers separately.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.69"><b>702.69.</b></a> Gravestorm</p>
<p><a id="cr702.69a"><b>702.69a</b></a> Gravestorm is a triggered ability that functions on the stack. “Gravestorm” means “When you cast this spell, copy it for each permanent that was put into a graveyard from the battlefield this turn. If the spell has any targets, you may choose new targets for any of the copies.”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.69b"><b>702.69b</b></a> If a spell has multiple instances of gravestorm, each triggers separately.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.70"><b>702.70.</b></a> Poisonous</p>
<p><a id="cr702.70a"><b>702.70a</b></a> Poisonous is a triggered ability. “Poisonous N” means “Whenever this creature deals combat damage to a player, that player gets N poison counters.” (For information about poison counters, see rule <a href="#cr104.3d">104.3d</a>.)</p>
<p><a id="cr702.70b"><b>702.70b</b></a> If a creature has multiple instances of poisonous, each triggers separately.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.71"><b>702.71.</b></a> Transfigure</p>
<p><a id="cr702.71a"><b>702.71a</b></a> Transfigure is an activated ability. “Transfigure [cost]” means “[Cost], Sacrifice this permanent: Search your library for a creature card with the same mana value as this permanent and put it onto the battlefield. Then shuffle your library. Activate only as a sorcery.”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.72"><b>702.72.</b></a> Champion</p>
<p><a id="cr702.72a"><b>702.72a</b></a> Champion represents two triggered abilities. “Champion an [object]” means “When this permanent enters the battlefield, sacrifice it unless you exile another [object] you control” and “When this permanent leaves the battlefield, return the exiled card to the battlefield under its owner’s control.”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.72b"><b>702.72b</b></a> The two abilities represented by champion are linked. See rule <a href="#cr607">607</a>, “Linked Abilities.”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.72c"><b>702.72c</b></a> A permanent is “championed” by another permanent if the latter exiles the former as the direct result of a champion ability.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.73"><b>702.73.</b></a> Changeling</p>
<p><a id="cr702.73a"><b>702.73a</b></a> Changeling is a characteristic-defining ability. “Changeling” means “This object is every creature type.” This ability works everywhere, even outside the game. See rule <a href="#cr604.3">604.3</a>.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.74"><b>702.74.</b></a> Evoke</p>
<p><a id="cr702.74a"><b>702.74a</b></a> Evoke represents two abilities: a static ability that functions in any zone from which the card with evoke can be cast and a triggered ability that functions on the battlefield. “Evoke [cost]” means “You may cast this card by paying [cost] rather than paying its mana cost” and “When this permanent enters the battlefield, if its evoke cost was paid, its controller sacrifices it.” Casting a spell for its evoke cost follows the rules for paying alternative costs in rules <a href="#cr601.2b">601.2b</a> and <a href="#cr601.2f">601.2f</a>–h.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.75"><b>702.75.</b></a> Hideaway</p>
<p><a id="cr702.75a"><b>702.75a</b></a> Hideaway is a triggered ability. “Hideaway N” means “When this permanent enters the battlefield, look at the top N cards of your library. Exile one of them face down and put the rest on the bottom of your library in a random order. The exiled card gains ‘The player who controls the permanent that exiled this card may look at this card in the exile zone.’”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.75b"><b>702.75b</b></a> Previously, the rules for the hideaway ability caused the permanent to enter the battlefield tapped, and the number of cards the player looked at was fixed at four. Cards printed before this rules change had the printed text “Hideaway” with no numeral after the word. Those older cards have received errata in the Oracle card reference to have “Hideaway 4” and the additional ability “[This permanent] enters the battlefield tapped.”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.76"><b>702.76.</b></a> Prowl</p>
<p><a id="cr702.76a"><b>702.76a</b></a> Prowl is a static ability that functions on the stack. “Prowl [cost]” means “You may pay [cost] rather than pay this spell’s mana cost if a player was dealt combat damage this turn by a source that, at the time it dealt that damage, was under your control and had any of this spell’s creature types.” Casting a spell for its prowl cost follows the rules for paying alternative costs in rules <a href="#cr601.2b">601.2b</a> and <a href="#cr601.2f">601.2f</a>–h.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.77"><b>702.77.</b></a> Reinforce</p>
<p><a id="cr702.77a"><b>702.77a</b></a> Reinforce is an activated ability that functions only while the card with reinforce is in a player’s hand. “Reinforce N—[cost]” means “[Cost], Discard this card: Put N +1/+1 counters on target creature.”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.77b"><b>702.77b</b></a> Although the reinforce ability can be activated only if the card is in a player’s hand, it continues to exist while the object is on the battlefield and in all other zones. Therefore objects with reinforce will be affected by effects that depend on objects having one or more activated abilities.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.78"><b>702.78.</b></a> Conspire</p>
<p><a id="cr702.78a"><b>702.78a</b></a> Conspire is a keyword that represents two abilities. The first is a static ability that functions while the spell with conspire is on the stack. The second is a triggered ability that functions while the spell with conspire is on the stack. “Conspire” means “As an additional cost to cast this spell, you may tap two untapped creatures you control that each share a color with it” and “When you cast this spell, if its conspire cost was paid, copy it. If the spell has any targets, you may choose new targets for the copy.” Paying a spell’s conspire cost follows the rules for paying additional costs in rules <a href="#cr601.2b">601.2b</a> and <a href="#cr601.2f">601.2f</a>–h.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.78b"><b>702.78b</b></a> If a spell has multiple instances of conspire, each is paid separately and triggers based on its own payment, not any other instance of conspire.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.79"><b>702.79.</b></a> Persist</p>
<p><a id="cr702.79a"><b>702.79a</b></a> Persist is a triggered ability. “Persist” means “When this permanent is put into a graveyard from the battlefield, if it had no -1/-1 counters on it, return it to the battlefield under its owner’s control with a -1/-1 counter on it.”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.80"><b>702.80.</b></a> Wither</p>
<p><a id="cr702.80a"><b>702.80a</b></a> Wither is a static ability. Damage dealt to a creature by a source with wither isn’t marked on that creature. Rather, it causes that source’s controller to put that many -1/-1 counters on that creature. See rule <a href="#cr120.3">120.3</a>.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.80b"><b>702.80b</b></a> If an object changes zones before an effect causes it to deal damage, its last known information is used to determine whether it had wither.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.80c"><b>702.80c</b></a> The wither rules function no matter what zone an object with wither deals damage from.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.80d"><b>702.80d</b></a> Multiple instances of wither on the same object are redundant.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.81"><b>702.81.</b></a> Retrace</p>
<p><a id="cr702.81a"><b>702.81a</b></a> Retrace appears on some instants and sorceries. It represents a static ability that functions while the card with retrace is in a player’s graveyard. “Retrace” means “You may cast this card from your graveyard by discarding a land card as an additional cost to cast it.” Casting a spell using its retrace ability follows the rules for paying additional costs in rules <a href="#cr601.2b">601.2b</a> and <a href="#cr601.2f">601.2f</a>–h.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.82"><b>702.82.</b></a> Devour</p>
<p><a id="cr702.82a"><b>702.82a</b></a> Devour is a static ability. “Devour N” means “As this object enters the battlefield, you may sacrifice any number of creatures. This permanent enters the battlefield with N +1/+1 counters on it for each creature sacrificed this way.”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.82b"><b>702.82b</b></a> Some objects have abilities that refer to the number of creatures the permanent devoured. “It devoured” means “sacrificed as a result of its devour ability as it entered the battlefield.”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.82c"><b>702.82c</b></a> Devour [type] is a variant of devour. “Devour [type] N” means “As this object enters the battlefield, you may sacrifice any number of [type] permanents. This permanent enters the battlefield with N +1/+1 counters on it for each permanent sacrificed this way.”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.83"><b>702.83.</b></a> Exalted</p>
<p><a id="cr702.83a"><b>702.83a</b></a> Exalted is a triggered ability. “Exalted” means “Whenever a creature you control attacks alone, that creature gets +1/+1 until end of turn.”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.83b"><b>702.83b</b></a> A creature “attacks alone” if it’s the only creature declared as an attacker in a given combat phase. See rule <a href="#cr506.5">506.5</a>.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.84"><b>702.84.</b></a> Unearth</p>
<p><a id="cr702.84a"><b>702.84a</b></a> Unearth is an activated ability that functions while the card with unearth is in a graveyard. “Unearth [cost]” means “[Cost]: Return this card from your graveyard to the battlefield. It gains haste. Exile it at the beginning of the next end step. If it would leave the battlefield, exile it instead of putting it anywhere else. Activate only as a sorcery.”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.85"><b>702.85.</b></a> Cascade</p>
<p><a id="cr702.85a"><b>702.85a</b></a> Cascade is a triggered ability that functions only while the spell with cascade is on the stack. “Cascade” means “When you cast this spell, exile cards from the top of your library until you exile a nonland card whose mana value is less than this spell’s mana value. You may cast that card without paying its mana cost if the resulting spell’s mana value is less than this spell’s mana value. Then put all cards exiled this way that weren’t cast on the bottom of your library in a random order.”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.85b"><b>702.85b</b></a> If an effect allows a player to take an action with one or more of the exiled cards “as you cascade,” the player may take that action after they have finished exiling cards due to the cascade ability. This action is taken before choosing whether to cast the last exiled card or, if no appropriate card was exiled, before putting the exiled cards on the bottom of their library in a random order.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.85c"><b>702.85c</b></a> If a spell has multiple instances of cascade, each triggers separately.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.85d"><b>702.85d</b></a> Quality cascade is a variant of the cascade ability. “[quality] Cascade” means “When you cast this spell, exile cards from the top of your library until you exile a nonland [quality] card whose mana value is less than this spell’s mana value. You may cast that card without paying its mana cost if the resulting spell’s mana value is less than this spell’s mana value. Then put all cards exiled this way that weren’t cast on the bottom of your library in a random order.”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.86"><b>702.86.</b></a> Annihilator</p>
<p><a id="cr702.86a"><b>702.86a</b></a> Annihilator is a triggered ability. “Annihilator N” means “Whenever this creature attacks, defending player sacrifices N permanents.”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.86b"><b>702.86b</b></a> If a creature has multiple instances of annihilator, each triggers separately.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.87"><b>702.87.</b></a> Level Up</p>
<p><a id="cr702.87a"><b>702.87a</b></a> Level up is an activated ability. “Level up [cost]” means “[Cost]: Put a level counter on this permanent. Activate only as a sorcery.”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.87b"><b>702.87b</b></a> Each card printed with a level up ability is known as a leveler card. It has a nonstandard layout and includes two level symbols that are themselves keyword abilities. See rule <a href="#cr711">711</a>, “Leveler Cards.”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.87c"><b>702.87c</b></a> Some enchantments have the subtype Class and associated abilities that give them a class level. These are not the same as level up abilities and class levels do not interact with level counters. See rule <a href="#cr717">717</a>, “Class Cards.”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.88"><b>702.88.</b></a> Rebound</p>
<p><a id="cr702.88a"><b>702.88a</b></a> Rebound appears on some instants and sorceries. It represents a static ability that functions while the spell is on the stack and may create a delayed triggered ability. “Rebound” means “If this spell was cast from your hand, instead of putting it into your graveyard as it resolves, exile it and, at the beginning of your next upkeep, you may cast this card from exile without paying its mana cost.”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.88b"><b>702.88b</b></a> Casting a spell as an effect of its rebound ability follows the rules for paying alternative costs in rules <a href="#cr601.2b">601.2b</a> and <a href="#cr601.2f">601.2f</a>–h.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.88c"><b>702.88c</b></a> Multiple instances of rebound on the same spell are redundant.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.89"><b>702.89.</b></a> Totem Armor</p>
<p><a id="cr702.89a"><b>702.89a</b></a> Totem armor is a static ability that appears on some Auras. “Totem armor” means “If enchanted permanent would be destroyed, instead remove all damage marked on it and destroy this Aura.”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.90"><b>702.90.</b></a> Infect</p>
<p><a id="cr702.90a"><b>702.90a</b></a> Infect is a static ability.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.90b"><b>702.90b</b></a> Damage dealt to a player by a source with infect doesn’t cause that player to lose life. Rather, it causes that source’s controller to give the player that many poison counters. See rule <a href="#cr120.3">120.3</a>.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.90c"><b>702.90c</b></a> Damage dealt to a creature by a source with infect isn’t marked on that creature. Rather, it causes that source’s controller to put that many -1/-1 counters on that creature. See rule <a href="#cr120.3">120.3</a>.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.90d"><b>702.90d</b></a> If an object changes zones before an effect causes it to deal damage, its last known information is used to determine whether it had infect.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.90e"><b>702.90e</b></a> The infect rules function no matter what zone an object with infect deals damage from.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.90f"><b>702.90f</b></a> Multiple instances of infect on the same object are redundant.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.91"><b>702.91.</b></a> Battle Cry</p>
<p><a id="cr702.91a"><b>702.91a</b></a> Battle cry is a triggered ability. “Battle cry” means “Whenever this creature attacks, each other attacking creature gets +1/+0 until end of turn.”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.91b"><b>702.91b</b></a> If a creature has multiple instances of battle cry, each triggers separately.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.92"><b>702.92.</b></a> Living Weapon</p>
<p><a id="cr702.92a"><b>702.92a</b></a> Living weapon is a triggered ability. “Living weapon” means “When this Equipment enters the battlefield, create a 0/0 black Phyrexian Germ creature token, then attach this Equipment to it.”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.93"><b>702.93.</b></a> Undying</p>
<p><a id="cr702.93a"><b>702.93a</b></a> Undying is a triggered ability. “Undying” means “When this permanent is put into a graveyard from the battlefield, if it had no +1/+1 counters on it, return it to the battlefield under its owner’s control with a +1/+1 counter on it.”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.94"><b>702.94.</b></a> Miracle</p>
<p><a id="cr702.94a"><b>702.94a</b></a> Miracle is a static ability linked to a triggered ability. (See rule <a href="#cr603.11">603.11</a>.) “Miracle [cost]” means “You may reveal this card from your hand as you draw it if it’s the first card you’ve drawn this turn. When you reveal this card this way, you may cast it by paying [cost] rather than its mana cost.”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.94b"><b>702.94b</b></a> If a player chooses to reveal a card using its miracle ability, they play with that card revealed until that card leaves their hand, that ability resolves, or that ability otherwise leaves the stack. (See rule <a href="#cr701.16a">701.16a</a>.)</p>
<p><a id="cr702.95"><b>702.95.</b></a> Soulbond</p>
<p><a id="cr702.95a"><b>702.95a</b></a> Soulbond is a keyword that represents two triggered abilities. “Soulbond” means “When this creature enters the battlefield, if you control both this creature and another creature and both are unpaired, you may pair this creature with another unpaired creature you control for as long as both remain creatures on the battlefield under your control” and “Whenever another creature enters the battlefield under your control, if you control both that creature and this one and both are unpaired, you may pair that creature with this creature for as long as both remain creatures on the battlefield under your control.”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.95b"><b>702.95b</b></a> A creature becomes “paired” with another as the result of a soulbond ability. Abilities may refer to a paired creature, the creature another creature is paired with, or whether a creature is paired. An “unpaired” creature is one that is not paired.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.95c"><b>702.95c</b></a> When the soulbond ability resolves, if either object that would be paired is no longer a creature, no longer on the battlefield, or no longer under the control of the player who controls the soulbond ability, neither object becomes paired.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.95d"><b>702.95d</b></a> A creature can be paired with only one other creature.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.95e"><b>702.95e</b></a> A paired creature becomes unpaired if any of the following occur: another player gains control of it or the creature it’s paired with; it or the creature it’s paired with stops being a creature; or it or the creature it’s paired with leaves the battlefield.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.96"><b>702.96.</b></a> Overload</p>
<p><a id="cr702.96a"><b>702.96a</b></a> Overload is a keyword that represents two static abilities that function while the spell with overload is on the stack. Overload [cost] means “You may choose to pay [cost] rather than pay this spell’s mana cost” and “If you chose to pay this spell’s overload cost, change its text by replacing all instances of the word ‘target’ with the word ‘each.’” Casting a spell using its overload ability follows the rules for paying alternative costs in rules <a href="#cr601.2b">601.2b</a> and <a href="#cr601.2f">601.2f</a>–h.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.96b"><b>702.96b</b></a> If a player chooses to pay the overload cost of a spell, that spell won’t require any targets. It may affect objects that couldn’t be chosen as legal targets if the spell were cast without its overload cost being paid.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.96c"><b>702.96c</b></a> Overload’s second ability creates a text-changing effect. See rule <a href="#cr612">612</a>, “Text-Changing Effects.”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.97"><b>702.97.</b></a> Scavenge</p>
<p><a id="cr702.97a"><b>702.97a</b></a> Scavenge is an activated ability that functions only while the card with scavenge is in a graveyard. “Scavenge [cost]” means “[Cost], Exile this card from your graveyard: Put a number of +1/+1 counters equal to the power of the card you exiled on target creature. Activate only as a sorcery.”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.98"><b>702.98.</b></a> Unleash</p>
<p><a id="cr702.98a"><b>702.98a</b></a> Unleash is a keyword that represents two static abilities. “Unleash” means “You may have this permanent enter the battlefield with an additional +1/+1 counter on it” and “This permanent can’t block as long as it has a +1/+1 counter on it.”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.99"><b>702.99.</b></a> Cipher</p>
<p><a id="cr702.99a"><b>702.99a</b></a> Cipher appears on some instants and sorceries. It represents two abilities. The first is a spell ability that functions while the spell with cipher is on the stack. The second is a static ability that functions while the card with cipher is in the exile zone. “Cipher” means “If this spell is represented by a card, you may exile this card encoded on a creature you control” and “For as long as this card is encoded on that creature, that creature has ‘Whenever this creature deals combat damage to a player, you may copy the encoded card and you may cast the copy without paying its mana cost.’”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.99b"><b>702.99b</b></a> The term “encoded” describes the relationship between the card with cipher while in the exile zone and the creature chosen when the spell represented by that card resolves.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.99c"><b>702.99c</b></a> The card with cipher remains encoded on the chosen creature as long as the card with cipher remains exiled and the creature remains on the battlefield. The card remains encoded on that object even if it changes controller or stops being a creature, as long as it remains on the battlefield.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.100"><b>702.100.</b></a> Evolve</p>
<p><a id="cr702.100a"><b>702.100a</b></a> Evolve is a triggered ability. “Evolve” means “Whenever a creature enters the battlefield under your control, if that creature’s power is greater than this creature’s power and/or that creature’s toughness is greater than this creature’s toughness, put a +1/+1 counter on this creature.”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.100b"><b>702.100b</b></a> A creature “evolves” when one or more +1/+1 counters are put on it as a result of its evolve ability resolving.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.100c"><b>702.100c</b></a> A creature can’t have a greater power or toughness than a noncreature permanent.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.100d"><b>702.100d</b></a> If a creature has multiple instances of evolve, each triggers separately.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.101"><b>702.101.</b></a> Extort</p>
<p><a id="cr702.101a"><b>702.101a</b></a> Extort is a triggered ability. “Extort” means “Whenever you cast a spell, you may pay {W/B}. If you do, each opponent loses 1 life and you gain life equal to the total life lost this way.”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.101b"><b>702.101b</b></a> If a permanent has multiple instances of extort, each triggers separately.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.101c"><b>702.101c</b></a> A permanent “extorts” a spell whenever its extort ability is paid, and a spell is “extorted” when an extort ability it triggered is paid. This can occur many times per permanent or spell. Any abilities that trigger due to this payment occur after the life loss and gain.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.102"><b>702.102.</b></a> Fuse</p>
<p><a id="cr702.102a"><b>702.102a</b></a> Fuse is a static ability found on some split cards (see rule <a href="#cr709">709</a>, “Split Cards”) that applies while the card with fuse is in a player’s hand. If a player casts a split card with fuse from their hand, the player may choose to cast both halves of that split card rather than choose one half. This choice is made before putting the split card with fuse onto the stack. The resulting spell is a fused split spell.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.102b"><b>702.102b</b></a> A fused split spell has the combined characteristics of its two halves. (See rule <a href="#cr709.4">709.4</a>.)</p>
<p><a id="cr702.102c"><b>702.102c</b></a> The total cost of a fused split spell includes the mana cost of each half.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.102d"><b>702.102d</b></a> As a fused split spell resolves, the controller of the spell follows the instructions of the left half and then follows the instructions of the right half.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.103"><b>702.103.</b></a> Bestow</p>
<p><a id="cr702.103a"><b>702.103a</b></a> Bestow represents a static ability that functions in any zone from which you could play the card it’s on. “Bestow [cost]” means “As you cast this spell, you may choose to cast it bestowed. If you do, you pay [cost] rather than its mana cost.” Casting a spell using its bestow ability follows the rules for paying alternative costs (see 601.2b and <a href="#cr601.2f">601.2f</a>–h).</p>
<p><a id="cr702.103b"><b>702.103b</b></a> As a spell cast bestowed is put onto the stack, it becomes an Aura enchantment and gains enchant creature. It is a bestowed Aura spell, and the permanent it becomes as it resolves will be a bestowed Aura. These effects last until the spell or the permanent it becomes ceases to be bestowed (see rules <a href="#cr702.103e">702.103e</a>–g). Because the spell is an Aura spell, its controller must choose a legal target for that spell as defined by its enchant creature ability and rule <a href="#cr601.2c">601.2c</a>. See also rule <a href="#cr303.4">303.4</a>.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.103c"><b>702.103c</b></a> If a bestowed Aura spell is copied, the copy is also a bestowed Aura spell. Any rule that refers to a spell cast bestowed applies to the copy as well.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.103d"><b>702.103d</b></a> When casting a spell bestowed, only its characteristics as modified by the bestow ability are evaluated to determine if it can be cast.<br><b><i>Example:</b></i> Aether Storm is an enchantment with the ability “Creature spells can’t be cast.” This effect doesn’t stop a creature card with bestow from being cast bestowed.<br><b><i>Example:</b></i> Garruk’s Horde says, in part, “You may cast creature spells from the top of your library.” If you control Garruk’s Horde and the top card of your library is a creature card with bestow, you can cast it as a creature spell, but you can’t cast it bestowed.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.103e"><b>702.103e</b></a> As a bestowed Aura spell begins resolving, if its target is illegal, it ceases to be bestowed and the effect making it an Aura spell ends. It continues resolving as a creature spell. This is an exception to rule <a href="#cr608.3a">608.3a</a>.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.103f"><b>702.103f</b></a> If a bestowed Aura becomes unattached, it ceases to be bestowed. If a bestowed Aura is attached to an illegal object or player, it becomes unattached and ceases to be bestowed. This is an exception to rule <a href="#cr704.5m">704.5m</a>.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.103g"><b>702.103g</b></a> If a bestowed Aura phases in unattached, it ceases to be bestowed. See rule <a href="#cr702.26">702.26</a>, “Phasing.”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.104"><b>702.104.</b></a> Tribute</p>
<p><a id="cr702.104a"><b>702.104a</b></a> Tribute is a static ability that functions as the creature with tribute is entering the battlefield. “Tribute N” means “As this creature enters the battlefield, choose an opponent. That player may put an additional N +1/+1 counters on it as it enters the battlefield.”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.104b"><b>702.104b</b></a> Objects with tribute have triggered abilities that check “if tribute wasn’t paid.” This condition is true if the opponent chosen as a result of the tribute ability didn’t have the creature enter the battlefield with +1/+1 counters as specified by the creature’s tribute ability.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.105"><b>702.105.</b></a> Dethrone</p>
<p><a id="cr702.105a"><b>702.105a</b></a> Dethrone is a triggered ability. “Dethrone” means “Whenever this creature attacks the player with the most life or tied for most life, put a +1/+1 counter on this creature.”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.105b"><b>702.105b</b></a> If a creature has multiple instances of dethrone, each triggers separately.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.106"><b>702.106.</b></a> Hidden Agenda</p>
<p><a id="cr702.106a"><b>702.106a</b></a> Hidden agenda is a static ability that functions as a conspiracy card with hidden agenda is put into the command zone. “Hidden agenda” means “As you put this conspiracy card into the command zone, turn it face down and secretly choose a card name.”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.106b"><b>702.106b</b></a> To secretly choose a card name, note that name on a piece of paper kept with the face-down conspiracy card.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.106c"><b>702.106c</b></a> Any time you have priority, you may turn a face-down conspiracy card you control in the command zone face up. This is a special action. Doing so will reveal the chosen name. See rule <a href="#cr116.2j">116.2j</a>.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.106d"><b>702.106d</b></a> Hidden agenda and another ability of the object with hidden agenda that refers to “the chosen name” are linked. The second ability refers only to the card name chosen as a result of that object’s hidden agenda ability. See rule <a href="#cr607.2d">607.2d</a>.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.106e"><b>702.106e</b></a> If a player leaves the game, all face-down conspiracy cards controlled by that player must be revealed to all players. At the end of each game, all face-down conspiracy cards must be revealed to all players.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.106f"><b>702.106f</b></a> Double agenda is a variant of the hidden agenda ability. As you put a conspiracy card with double agenda into the command zone, you secretly name two different cards rather than one. You don’t reveal that more than one name was secretly chosen until you reveal the chosen names.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.107"><b>702.107.</b></a> Outlast</p>
<p><a id="cr702.107a"><b>702.107a</b></a> Outlast is an activated ability. “Outlast [cost]” means “[Cost], {T}: Put a +1/+1 counter on this creature. Activate only as a sorcery.”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.108"><b>702.108.</b></a> Prowess</p>
<p><a id="cr702.108a"><b>702.108a</b></a> Prowess is a triggered ability. “Prowess” means “Whenever you cast a noncreature spell, this creature gets +1/+1 until end of turn.”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.108b"><b>702.108b</b></a> If a creature has multiple instances of prowess, each triggers separately.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.109"><b>702.109.</b></a> Dash</p>
<p><a id="cr702.109a"><b>702.109a</b></a> Dash represents three abilities: two static abilities that function while the card with dash is on the stack, one of which may create a delayed triggered ability, and a static ability that functions while the object with dash is on the battlefield. “Dash [cost]” means “You may cast this card by paying [cost] rather than its mana cost,” “If this spell’s dash cost was paid, return the permanent this spell becomes to its owner’s hand at the beginning of the next end step,” and “As long as this permanent’s dash cost was paid, it has haste.” Casting a spell for its dash cost follows the rules for paying alternative costs in rules <a href="#cr601.2b">601.2b</a> and <a href="#cr601.2f">601.2f</a>–h.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.110"><b>702.110.</b></a> Exploit</p>
<p><a id="cr702.110a"><b>702.110a</b></a> Exploit is a triggered ability. “Exploit” means “When this creature enters the battlefield, you may sacrifice a creature.”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.110b"><b>702.110b</b></a> A creature with exploit “exploits a creature” when the controller of the exploit ability sacrifices a creature as that ability resolves.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.111"><b>702.111.</b></a> Menace</p>
<p><a id="cr702.111a"><b>702.111a</b></a> Menace is an evasion ability.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.111b"><b>702.111b</b></a> A creature with menace can’t be blocked except by two or more creatures. (See rule <a href="#cr509">509</a>, “Declare Blockers Step.”)</p>
<p><a id="cr702.111c"><b>702.111c</b></a> Multiple instances of menace on the same creature are redundant.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.112"><b>702.112.</b></a> Renown</p>
<p><a id="cr702.112a"><b>702.112a</b></a> Renown is a triggered ability. “Renown N” means “When this creature deals combat damage to a player, if it isn’t renowned, put N +1/+1 counters on it and it becomes renowned.”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.112b"><b>702.112b</b></a> Renowned is a designation that has no rules meaning other than to act as a marker that the renown ability and other spells and abilities can identify. Only permanents can be or become renowned. Once a permanent becomes renowned, it stays renowned until it leaves the battlefield. Renowned is neither an ability nor part of the permanent’s copiable values.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.112c"><b>702.112c</b></a> If a creature has multiple instances of renown, each triggers separately. The first such ability to resolve will cause the creature to become renowned, and subsequent abilities will have no effect. (See rule <a href="#cr603.4">603.4</a>)</p>
<p><a id="cr702.113"><b>702.113.</b></a> Awaken</p>
<p><a id="cr702.113a"><b>702.113a</b></a> Awaken appears on some instants and sorceries. It represents two abilities: a static ability that functions while the spell with awaken is on the stack and a spell ability. “Awaken N—[cost]” means “You may pay [cost] rather than pay this spell’s mana cost as you cast this spell” and “If this spell’s awaken cost was paid, put N +1/+1 counters on target land you control. That land becomes a 0/0 Elemental creature with haste. It’s still a land.” Casting a spell using its awaken ability follows the rules for paying alternative costs in rules <a href="#cr601.2b">601.2b</a> and <a href="#cr601.2f">601.2f</a>–h.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.113b"><b>702.113b</b></a> The controller of a spell with awaken chooses the target of the awaken spell ability only if that player chose to pay the spell’s awaken cost. Otherwise the spell is cast as if it didn’t have that target.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.114"><b>702.114.</b></a> Devoid</p>
<p><a id="cr702.114a"><b>702.114a</b></a> Devoid is a characteristic-defining ability. “Devoid” means “This object is colorless.” This ability functions everywhere, even outside the game. See rule <a href="#cr604.3">604.3</a>.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.115"><b>702.115.</b></a> Ingest</p>
<p><a id="cr702.115a"><b>702.115a</b></a> Ingest is a triggered ability. “Ingest” means “Whenever this creature deals combat damage to a player, that player exiles the top card of their library.”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.115b"><b>702.115b</b></a> If a creature has multiple instances of ingest, each triggers separately.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.116"><b>702.116.</b></a> Myriad</p>
<p><a id="cr702.116a"><b>702.116a</b></a> Myriad is a triggered ability that may also create a delayed triggered ability. “Myriad” means “Whenever this creature attacks, for each opponent other than defending player, you may create a token that’s a copy of this creature that’s tapped and attacking that player or a planeswalker they control. If one or more tokens are created this way, exile the tokens at end of combat.”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.116b"><b>702.116b</b></a> If a creature has multiple instances of myriad, each triggers separately.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.117"><b>702.117.</b></a> Surge</p>
<p><a id="cr702.117a"><b>702.117a</b></a> Surge is a static ability that functions while the spell with surge is on the stack. “Surge [cost]” means “You may pay [cost] rather than pay this spell’s mana cost as you cast this spell if you or one of your teammates has cast another spell this turn.” Casting a spell for its surge cost follows the rules for paying alternative costs in rules <a href="#cr601.2b">601.2b</a> and <a href="#cr601.2f">601.2f</a>–h.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.118"><b>702.118.</b></a> Skulk</p>
<p><a id="cr702.118a"><b>702.118a</b></a> Skulk is an evasion ability.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.118b"><b>702.118b</b></a> A creature with skulk can’t be blocked by creatures with greater power. (See rule <a href="#cr509">509</a>, “Declare Blockers Step.”)</p>
<p><a id="cr702.118c"><b>702.118c</b></a> Multiple instances of skulk on the same creature are redundant.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.119"><b>702.119.</b></a> Emerge</p>
<p><a id="cr702.119a"><b>702.119a</b></a> Emerge represents two static abilities that function while the spell with emerge is on the stack. “Emerge [cost]” means “You may cast this spell by paying [cost] and sacrificing a creature rather than paying its mana cost” and “If you chose to pay this spell’s emerge cost, its total cost is reduced by an amount of generic mana equal to the sacrificed creature’s mana value.” Casting a spell using its emerge ability follows the rules for paying alternative costs in rules <a href="#cr601.2b">601.2b</a> and <a href="#cr601.2f">601.2f</a>–h.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.119b"><b>702.119b</b></a> You choose which creature to sacrifice as you choose to pay a spell’s emerge cost (see rule <a href="#cr601.2b">601.2b</a>), and you sacrifice that creature as you pay the total cost (see rule <a href="#cr601.2h">601.2h</a>).</p>
<p><a id="cr702.120"><b>702.120.</b></a> Escalate</p>
<p><a id="cr702.120a"><b>702.120a</b></a> Escalate is a static ability of modal spells (see rule <a href="#cr700.2">700.2</a>) that functions while the spell with escalate is on the stack. “Escalate [cost]” means “For each mode you choose beyond the first as you cast this spell, you pay an additional [cost].” Paying a spell’s escalate cost follows the rules for paying additional costs in rules <a href="#cr601.2f">601.2f</a>–h.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.121"><b>702.121.</b></a> Melee</p>
<p><a id="cr702.121a"><b>702.121a</b></a> Melee is a triggered ability. “Melee” means “Whenever this creature attacks, it gets +1/+1 until end of turn for each opponent you attacked with a creature this combat.”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.121b"><b>702.121b</b></a> If a creature has multiple instances of melee, each triggers separately.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.122"><b>702.122.</b></a> Crew</p>
<p><a id="cr702.122a"><b>702.122a</b></a> Crew is an activated ability of Vehicle cards. “Crew N” means “Tap any number of other untapped creatures you control with total power N or greater: This permanent becomes an artifact creature until end of turn.”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.122b"><b>702.122b</b></a> A creature “crews a Vehicle” when it’s tapped to pay the cost to activate a Vehicle’s crew ability.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.122c"><b>702.122c</b></a> If an effect states that a creature “can’t crew Vehicles,” that creature can’t be tapped to pay the crew cost of a Vehicle.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.122d"><b>702.122d</b></a> Some Vehicles have abilities that trigger when they become crewed. “Whenever [this Vehicle] becomes crewed” means “Whenever a crew ability of [this Vehicle] resolves.”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.123"><b>702.123.</b></a> Fabricate</p>
<p><a id="cr702.123a"><b>702.123a</b></a> Fabricate is a triggered ability. “Fabricate N” means “When this permanent enters the battlefield, you may put N +1/+1 counters on it. If you don’t, create N 1/1 colorless Servo artifact creature tokens.”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.123b"><b>702.123b</b></a> If a permanent has multiple instances of fabricate, each triggers separately.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.124"><b>702.124.</b></a> Partner</p>
<p><a id="cr702.124a"><b>702.124a</b></a> Partner is an ability that modifies the rules for deck construction in the Commander variant (see rule <a href="#cr903">903</a>), and it functions before the game begins. Rather than a single legendary creature card, you may designate two legendary creature cards as your commander if each has partner.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.124b"><b>702.124b</b></a> Your deck must contain exactly 100 cards, including its two commanders. Both commanders begin the game in the command zone.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.124c"><b>702.124c</b></a> A rule or effect that refers to your commander’s color identity refers to the combined color identities of your two commanders. See rule <a href="#cr903.4">903.4</a>.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.124d"><b>702.124d</b></a> Except for determining the color identity of your commander, the two commanders function independently. When casting a commander with partner, ignore how many times your other commander has been cast (see rule <a href="#cr903.8">903.8</a>). When determining whether a player has been dealt 21 or more combat damage by the same commander, consider damage from each of your two commanders separately (see rule <a href="#cr903.10a">903.10a</a>).</p>
<p><a id="cr702.124e"><b>702.124e</b></a> If an effect refers to your commander while you have two commanders, it refers to either one. If an effect causes you to perform an action on your commander and it could affect both, you choose which it refers to at the time the effect is applied.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.124f"><b>702.124f</b></a> “Partner with [name]” is a variant of the partner ability. “Partner with [name]” represents two abilities. One is a static ability that modifies the rules for deck construction. Rather than a single legendary creature card, you may designate two legendary creature cards as your commander if each has a “partner with [name]” ability with the other’s name. You can’t designate two legendary cards as your commander if one has a “partner with [name]” ability and the other isn’t the named card. The other ability represented by “partner with [name]” is a triggered ability that means “When this permanent enters the battlefield, target player may search their library for a card named [name], reveal it, put it into their hand, then shuffle their library.”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.124g"><b>702.124g</b></a> Friends forever is a variant of the partner ability. Friends forever modifies the rules for deck construction in the Commander variant, and it functions before the game begins. Rather than a single legendary creature card, you may designate two legendary creature cards as your commander if each has friends forever.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.125"><b>702.125.</b></a> Undaunted</p>
<p><a id="cr702.125a"><b>702.125a</b></a> Undaunted is a static ability that functions while the spell with undaunted is on the stack. Undaunted means “This spell costs {1} less to cast for each opponent you have.”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.125b"><b>702.125b</b></a> Players who have left the game are not counted when determining how many opponents you have.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.125c"><b>702.125c</b></a> If a spell has multiple instances of undaunted, each of them applies.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.126"><b>702.126.</b></a> Improvise</p>
<p><a id="cr702.126a"><b>702.126a</b></a> Improvise is a static ability that functions while the spell with improvise is on the stack. “Improvise” means “For each generic mana in this spell’s total cost, you may tap an untapped artifact you control rather than pay that mana.”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.126b"><b>702.126b</b></a> The improvise ability isn’t an additional or alternative cost and applies only after the total cost of the spell with improvise is determined.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.126c"><b>702.126c</b></a> Multiple instances of improvise on the same spell are redundant.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.127"><b>702.127.</b></a> Aftermath</p>
<p><a id="cr702.127a"><b>702.127a</b></a> Aftermath is an ability found on some split cards (see rule <a href="#cr709">709</a>, “Split Cards”). It represents three static abilities. “Aftermath” means “You may cast this half of this split card from your graveyard,” “This half of this split card can’t be cast from any zone other than a graveyard,” and “If this spell was cast from a graveyard, exile it instead of putting it anywhere else any time it would leave the stack.”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.128"><b>702.128.</b></a> Embalm</p>
<p><a id="cr702.128a"><b>702.128a</b></a> Embalm is an activated ability that functions while the card with embalm is in a graveyard. “Embalm [cost]” means “[Cost], Exile this card from your graveyard: Create a token that’s a copy of this card, except it’s white, it has no mana cost, and it’s a Zombie in addition to its other types. Activate only as a sorcery.”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.128b"><b>702.128b</b></a> A token is “embalmed” if it’s created by a resolving embalm ability.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.129"><b>702.129.</b></a> Eternalize</p>
<p><a id="cr702.129a"><b>702.129a</b></a> Eternalize is an activated ability that functions while the card with eternalize is in a graveyard. “Eternalize [cost]” means “[Cost], Exile this card from your graveyard: Create a token that’s a copy of this card, except it’s black, it’s 4/4, it has no mana cost, and it’s a Zombie in addition to its other types. Activate only as a sorcery.”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.130"><b>702.130.</b></a> Afflict</p>
<p><a id="cr702.130a"><b>702.130a</b></a> Afflict is a triggered ability. “Afflict N” means “Whenever this creature becomes blocked, defending player loses N life.”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.130b"><b>702.130b</b></a> If a creature has multiple instances of afflict, each triggers separately.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.131"><b>702.131.</b></a> Ascend</p>
<p><a id="cr702.131a"><b>702.131a</b></a> Ascend on an instant or sorcery spell represents a spell ability. It means “If you control ten or more permanents and you don’t have the city’s blessing, you get the city’s blessing for the rest of the game.”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.131b"><b>702.131b</b></a> Ascend on a permanent represents a static ability. It means “Any time you control ten or more permanents and you don’t have the city’s blessing, you get the city’s blessing for the rest of the game.”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.131c"><b>702.131c</b></a> The city’s blessing is a designation that has no rules meaning other than to act as a marker that other rules and effects can identify. Any number of players may have the city’s blessing at the same time.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.131d"><b>702.131d</b></a> After a player gets the city’s blessing, continuous effects are reapplied before the game checks to see if the game state or preceding events have matched any trigger conditions.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.132"><b>702.132.</b></a> Assist</p>
<p><a id="cr702.132a"><b>702.132a</b></a> Assist is a static ability that modifies the rules of paying for the spell with assist (see rules <a href="#cr601.2g">601.2g</a>-h). If the total cost to cast a spell with assist includes a generic mana component, before you activate mana abilities while casting it, you may choose another player. That player has a chance to activate mana abilities. Once that player chooses not to activate any more mana abilities, you have a chance to activate mana abilities. Before you begin to pay the total cost of the spell, the player you chose may pay for any amount of the generic mana in the spell’s total cost.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.133"><b>702.133.</b></a> Jump-Start</p>
<p><a id="cr702.133a"><b>702.133a</b></a> Jump-start appears on some instants and sorceries. It represents two static abilities: one that functions while the card is in a player’s graveyard and another that functions while the card is on the stack. “Jump-start” means “You may cast this card from your graveyard if the resulting spell is an instant or sorcery spell by discarding a card as an additional cost to cast it” and “If this spell was cast using its jump-start ability, exile this card instead of putting it anywhere else any time it would leave the stack.” Casting a spell using its jump-start ability follows the rules for paying additional costs in rules <a href="#cr601.2b">601.2b</a> and <a href="#cr601.2f">601.2f</a>–h.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.134"><b>702.134.</b></a> Mentor</p>
<p><a id="cr702.134a"><b>702.134a</b></a> Mentor is a triggered ability. “Mentor” means “Whenever this creature attacks, put a +1/+1 counter on target attacking creature with power less than this creature’s power.”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.134b"><b>702.134b</b></a> If a creature has multiple instances of mentor, each triggers separately.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.135"><b>702.135.</b></a> Afterlife</p>
<p><a id="cr702.135a"><b>702.135a</b></a> Afterlife is a triggered ability. “Afterlife N” means “When this permanent is put into a graveyard from the battlefield, create N 1/1 white and black Spirit creature tokens with flying.”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.135b"><b>702.135b</b></a> If a permanent has multiple instances of afterlife, each triggers separately.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.136"><b>702.136.</b></a> Riot</p>
<p><a id="cr702.136a"><b>702.136a</b></a> Riot is a static ability. “Riot” means “You may have this permanent enter the battlefield with an additional +1/+1 counter on it. If you don’t, it gains haste.”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.136b"><b>702.136b</b></a> If a permanent has multiple instances of riot, each works separately.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.137"><b>702.137.</b></a> Spectacle</p>
<p><a id="cr702.137a"><b>702.137a</b></a> Spectacle is a static ability that functions on the stack. “Spectacle [cost]” means “You may pay [cost] rather than pay this spell’s mana cost if an opponent lost life this turn.” Casting a spell for its spectacle cost follows the rules for paying alternative costs in rules <a href="#cr601.2b">601.2b</a> and <a href="#cr601.2f">601.2f</a>–h.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.138"><b>702.138.</b></a> Escape</p>
<p><a id="cr702.138a"><b>702.138a</b></a> Escape represents a static ability that functions while the card with escape is in a player’s graveyard. “Escape [cost]” means “You may cast this card from your graveyard by paying [cost] rather than paying its mana cost.” Casting a spell using its escape ability follows the rules for paying alternative costs in rules <a href="#cr601.2b">601.2b</a> and <a href="#cr601.2f">601.2f</a>–h.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.138b"><b>702.138b</b></a> A spell or permanent “escaped” if that spell or the spell that became that permanent as it resolved was cast from a graveyard with an escape ability.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.138c"><b>702.138c</b></a> An ability that reads “[This permanent] escapes with [one or more of a kind of counter]” means “If this permanent escaped, it enters the battlefield with [those counters]” That ability may have a triggered ability linked to it that triggers “When it enters the battlefield this way.” (See rule <a href="#cr603.11">603.11</a>.) Such a triggered ability triggers when that permanent enters the battlefield after its replacement effect was applied, even if that replacement effect had no effect.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.138d"><b>702.138d</b></a> An ability that reads “[This permanent] escapes with [ability]” means “If this permanent escaped, it has [ability].”</p>
<p><a href="#comCompanion"><b>★</b></a> <a id="cr702.139"><b>702.139.</b></a> Companion</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.139a"><b>702.139a</b></a> Companion is a keyword ability that functions outside the game. It’s written as “Companion—[Condition].”</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.139b"><b>702.139b</b></a> First mate is a keyword ability and a variant of the companion ability that functions outside the game. It’s written as “First mate—[Condition].”</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.139c"><b>702.139c</b></a> Before the game begins, you may reveal one card you own from outside the game with a companion ability whose condition is fulfilled by your starting deck. (See rule <a href="#cr103.2b">103.2b</a>.) This card is called your “chosen companion.”</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.139d"><b>702.139d</b></a> Cards with companion abilities will have a method to enter the game that is dependent on the variant of the ability that they have. That method is only applicable to cards with that variant, and no others.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.139e"><b>702.139e</b></a> For cards with Companion, once during the game, any time you have priority and the stack is empty, but only during a main phase of your turn, you may pay {3} and put your chosen companion into your hand. This is a special action that doesn’t use the stack (see rule <a href="#cr116.2g">116.2g</a>). This is a change from previous rules.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.139f"><b>702.139f</b></a> For cards with First mate, once the mulligan process is complete, a player may exchange a card in their hand and their chosen companion. The card put outside the game is not made public to other players.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.140"><b>702.140.</b></a> Mutate</p>
<p><a id="cr702.140a"><b>702.140a</b></a> Mutate appears on some creature cards. It represents a static ability that functions while the spell with mutate is on the stack. “Mutate [cost]” means “You may pay [cost] rather than pay this spell’s mana cost. If you do, it becomes a mutating creature spell and targets a non-Human creature with the same owner as this spell.” Casting a spell using its mutate ability follows the rules for paying alternative costs (see 601.2b and <a href="#cr601.2f">601.2f</a>–h).</p>
<p><a id="cr702.140b"><b>702.140b</b></a> As a mutating creature spell begins resolving, if its target is illegal, it ceases to be a mutating creature spell and continues resolving as a creature spell and will be put onto the battlefield under the control of the spell’s controller.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.140c"><b>702.140c</b></a> As a mutating creature spell resolves, if its target is legal, it doesn’t enter the battlefield. Rather, it merges with the target creature and becomes one object represented by more than one card or token (see rule <a href="#cr723">723</a>, “Merging with Permanents”). The spell’s controller chooses whether the spell is put on top of the creature or on the bottom. The resulting permanent is a mutated permanent.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.140d"><b>702.140d</b></a> An ability that triggers whenever a creature mutates triggers when a spell merges with a creature as a result of a resolving mutating creature spell.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.140e"><b>702.140e</b></a> A mutated permanent has all abilities of each card and token that represents it. Its other characteristics are derived from the topmost card or token.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.140f"><b>702.140f</b></a> Any effect that refers to or modifies the mutating creature spell refers to or modifies the mutated permanent it merges with as it resolves.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.141"><b>702.141.</b></a> Encore</p>
<p><a id="cr702.141a"><b>702.141a</b></a> Encore is an activated ability that functions while the card with encore is in a graveyard. “Encore [cost]” means “[Cost], Exile this card from your graveyard: For each opponent, create a token that’s a copy of this card that attacks that opponent this turn if able. The tokens gain haste. Sacrifice them at the beginning of the next end step. Activate only as a sorcery.”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.142"><b>702.142.</b></a> Boast</p>
<p><a id="cr702.142a"><b>702.142a</b></a> A boast ability is a special kind of activated ability. “Boast — [Cost]: [Effect]” means “[Cost]: [Effect]. Activate only if this creature attacked this turn and only once each turn.”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.142b"><b>702.142b</b></a> Effects may refer to boast abilities. If an effect refers to a creature boasting, it means its boast ability being activated.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.143"><b>702.143.</b></a> Foretell</p>
<p><a id="cr702.143a"><b>702.143a</b></a> Foretell is a keyword that functions while the card with foretell is in a player’s hand. Any time a player has priority during their turn, that player may pay {2} and exile a card with foretell from their hand face down. That player may look at that card as long as it remains in exile. They may cast that card after the current turn has ended by paying any foretell cost it has rather than paying that spell’s mana cost.
