Casting a spell this way follows the rules for paying alternative costs in rules <a href="#cr601.2b">601.2b</a> and <a href="#cr601.2f">601.2f</a>–h.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.143b"><b>702.143b</b></a> Exiling a card using its foretell ability is a special action, which doesn’t use the stack. See rule <a href="#cr116">116</a>, “Special Actions.”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.143c"><b>702.143c</b></a> If an effect refers to foretelling a card, it means performing the special action associated with a foretell ability. If an effect refers to a card or spell that was foretold, it means a card put in the exile zone as a result of the special action associated with a foretell ability, or a spell that was a foretold card before it was cast, even if it was cast for a cost other than a foretell cost.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.143d"><b>702.143d</b></a> If an effect states that a card in exile becomes foretold, that card becomes a foretold card. That effect may give the card a foretell cost. That card may be cast for any foretell cost it has after the turn it became a foretold card has ended, even if the resulting spell doesn’t have foretell.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.143e"><b>702.143e</b></a> If a player owns multiple foretold cards in exile, they must ensure that those cards can be easily differentiated from each other and from any other face-down cards in exile which that player owns. This includes knowing both the order in which those cards were put into exile and any foretell costs other than their printed foretell costs those cards may have.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.143f"><b>702.143f</b></a> If a player leaves the game, all face-down foretold cards that player owns must be revealed to all players. At the end of each game, all face-down foretold cards must be revealed to all players.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.144"><b>702.144.</b></a> Demonstrate</p>
<p><a id="cr702.144a"><b>702.144a</b></a> Demonstrate is a triggered ability. “Demonstrate” means “When you cast this spell, you may copy it and you may choose new targets for the copy. If you copy the spell, choose an opponent. That player copies the spell and may choose new targets for that copy.”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.145"><b>702.145.</b></a> Daybound and Nightbound</p>
<p><a id="cr702.145a"><b>702.145a</b></a> Daybound and nightbound are found on opposite faces of some transforming double-faced cards (see rule <a href="#cr712">712</a>, “Double-Faced Cards”).</p>
<p><a id="cr702.145b"><b>702.145b</b></a> Daybound is found on the front faces of some transforming double-faced cards and represents three static abilities. “Daybound” means “If it is night, this permanent enters the battlefield transformed,” “As it becomes night, if this permanent is front face up, transform it,” and “This permanent can’t be transformed except by its daybound ability.” See rule <a href="#cr724">724</a>, “Day and Night.”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.145c"><b>702.145c</b></a> Any time a player controls a permanent that is front face up with daybound and it’s night, that player transforms that permanent. This happens immediately and isn’t a state-based action.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.145d"><b>702.145d</b></a> Any time a player controls a permanent with daybound, if it’s neither day nor night, it becomes day.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.145e"><b>702.145e</b></a> Nightbound is found on the back faces of some transforming double-faced cards and represents two static abilities. “Nightbound” means “As it becomes day, if this permanent is back face up, transform it” and “This permanent can’t be transformed except by its nightbound ability.”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.145f"><b>702.145f</b></a> Any time a player controls a permanent that is back face up with nightbound and it’s day, that player transforms that permanent. This happens immediately and isn’t a state-based action.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.145g"><b>702.145g</b></a> Any time a player controls a permanent with nightbound, if it’s neither day nor night and there are no permanents with daybound on the battlefield, it becomes night.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.146"><b>702.146.</b></a> Disturb</p>
<p><a id="cr702.146a"><b>702.146a</b></a> Disturb is an ability found on the front face of some transforming double-faced cards (see rule <a href="#cr712">712</a>, “Double-Faced Cards”). “Disturb [cost]” means “You may cast this card transformed from your graveyard by paying [cost] rather than its mana cost.” See rule <a href="#cr712.4b">712.4b</a>.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.146b"><b>702.146b</b></a> A resolving transforming double-faced spell that was cast using its disturb ability enters the battlefield with its back face up.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.147"><b>702.147.</b></a> Decayed</p>
<p><a id="cr702.147a"><b>702.147a</b></a> Decayed represents a static ability and a triggered ability. “Decayed” means “This creature can’t block” and “When this creature attacks, sacrifice it at end of combat.”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.148"><b>702.148.</b></a> Cleave</p>
<p><a id="cr702.148a"><b>702.148a</b></a> Cleave is a keyword that represents two static abilities that function while a spell with cleave is on the stack. “Cleave [cost]” means “You may cast this spell by paying [cost] rather than paying its mana cost” and “If this spell’s cleave cost was paid, change its text by removing all text found within square brackets in the spell’s rules text.” Casting a spell for its cleave cost follows the rules for paying alternative costs in rules <a href="#cr601.2b">601.2b</a> and <a href="#cr601.2f">601.2f</a>–h.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.148b"><b>702.148b</b></a> Cleave’s second ability is a text-changing effect. See rule <a href="#cr612">612</a>, “Text-Changing Effects.”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.149"><b>702.149.</b></a> Training</p>
<p><a id="cr702.149a"><b>702.149a</b></a> Training is a triggered ability. “Training” means “Whenever this creature and at least one other creature with power greater than this creature’s power attack, put a +1/+1 counter on this creature.”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.149b"><b>702.149b</b></a> If a creature has multiple instances of training, each triggers separately.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.149c"><b>702.149c</b></a> Some creatures with training have abilities that trigger when they train. “When this creature trains” means “When a resolving training ability puts a +1/+1 counter on this creature.”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.150"><b>702.150.</b></a> Compleated</p>
<p><a id="cr702.150a"><b>702.150a</b></a> Compleated is a static ability found on some planeswalker cards. Compleated means “If this permanent would enter the battlefield with one or more loyalty counters on it and the player who cast it chose to pay life for any part of its cost represented by Phyrexian mana symbols, it instead enters the battlefield with that many loyalty counters minus two for each of those mana symbols.”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.151"><b>702.151.</b></a> Reconfigure</p>
<p><a id="cr702.151a"><b>702.151a</b></a> Reconfigure represents two activated abilities. Reconfigure [cost] means “[Cost]: Attach this permanent to another target creature you control. Activate only as a sorcery” and “[Cost]: Unattach this permanent. Activate only if this permanent is attached to a creature and only as a sorcery.”</p>
<p><a id="cr702.151b"><b>702.151b</b></a> Attaching an Equipment with reconfigure to another creature causes the Equipment to stop being a creature until it becomes unattached from that creature.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.152"><b>702.152.</b></a> Blitz</p>
<p><a id="cr702.152a"><b>702.152a</b></a> Blitz represents three abilities: two static abilities that function while the card with blitz is on the stack, one of which may create a delayed triggered ability, and a static ability that functions while the object with blitz is on the battlefield. “Blitz [cost]” means “You may cast this card by paying [cost] rather than its mana cost,” “If this spell’s blitz cost was paid, sacrifice the permanent this spell becomes at the beginning of the next end step,” and “As long as this permanent’s blitz cost was paid, it has haste and ‘When this permanent is put into a graveyard from the battlefield, draw a card.’” Casting a spell for its blitz cost follows the rules for paying alternative costs in rules <a href="#cr601.2b">601.2b</a> and <a href="#cr601.2f">601.2f</a>–h.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.153"><b>702.153.</b></a> Casualty</p>
<p><a id="cr702.153a"><b>702.153a</b></a> Casualty is a keyword that represents two abilities. The first is a static ability that functions while the spell with casualty is on the stack. The second is a triggered ability that functions while the spell with casualty is on the stack. Casualty N means “As an additional cost to cast this spell, you may sacrifice a creature with power N or greater,” and “When you cast this spell, if a casualty cost was paid for it, copy it. If the spell has any targets, you may choose new targets for the copy.” Paying a spell’s casualty cost follows the rules for paying additional costs in rules <a href="#cr601.2b">601.2b</a> and <a href="#cr601.2f">601.2f</a>–h.</p>
<p><a id="cr702.153b"><b>702.153b</b></a> If a spell has multiple instances of casualty, each is paid separately and triggers based on the payments made for it, not any other instance of casualty.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.154"><b>702.154.</b></a> Alpha</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.154a"><b>702.154a</b></a> Alpha is a triggered ability of some creatures. “Alpha N-(cost)” means “At the beginning of your upkeep, you may (cost). If you do and you control no alpha creatures, put N +1/+1 counters on this creature and it becomes alpha.”</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.154b"><b>702.154b</b></a> Conditions that check if a permanent is “the alpha” are true if the permanent is alpha.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.154c"><b>702.154c</b></a> It is possible to control more than one alpha creature through control change effects or phasing. Each of those creatures is still “the alpha” for abilities that track it.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.155"><b>702.155.</b></a> Bleed</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.155a"><b>702.155a</b></a> Bleed is a static ability that functions while the card with bleed is on the stack. “Bleed (cost)” means “You may pay (cost) rather than pay this spell's mana cost as you cast this spell if an opponent lost life this turn.”</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.155b"><b>702.155b</b></a> Bleed only cares if an opponent lost life. If those opponents gained the life back, you can still cast a spell for its bleed cost. If your opponents have only lost glory counters and not life, you can't cast a spell for its bleed cost.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.156"><b>702.156.</b></a> Distorted</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.156a"><b>702.156a</b></a> Distorted is an evasion ability. A creature with distorted can't be blocked by untapped creatures. Tapped creatures can block creatures with distorted. This is an exception to rule <a href="#cr509.1a">509.1a</a>.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.156b"><b>702.156b</b></a> A creature with distorted can still only block creatures without distorted if it is untapped.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.157"><b>702.157.</b></a> Engorge</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.157a"><b>702.157a</b></a> Engorge is a static ability. “Engorge” means “As this creature enters the battlefield, put the top three cards of your library into your graveyard, then exile exactly one card put into your graveyard this way.”</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.157b"><b>702.157b</b></a> A creature with engorge may refer to the card exiled this way as “the card it engorged.”</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.158"><b>702.158.</b></a> Erratic</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.158a"><b>702.158a</b></a> Erratic is a triggered ability. “Erratic” means “When this creature dies, reveal the top four cards of your library. Put a creature card revealed this way whose mana value is less than this card's mana value onto the battlefield and the rest of the cards on the bottom of your library in any order.”</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.158b"><b>702.158b</b></a> This ability will trigger even if the permanent is not a creature when it is put into a graveyard from the battlefield.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.159"><b>702.159.</b></a> Experience</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.159a"><b>702.159a</b></a> Experience is a triggered ability. “Experience” means “Whenever this creature attacks, if it has two or fewer +1/+1 counters on it, put a +1/+1 counter on it.”</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.159b"><b>702.159b</b></a> If a creature with experience has three or more +1/+1 counters on it as the ability tries to resolve, it will have no effect.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.159c"><b>702.159c</b></a> Level experience is a variant of the experience ability. “Level experience” means “Whenever this creature attacks, if it has two or fewer level counters on it, put a level counter on it.”</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.160"><b>702.160.</b></a> Fabled</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.160a"><b>702.160a</b></a> Fabled appears on some instants and sorceries with a single target. It represents a static ability while the spell with fabled is on the stack and a spell ability. “Fabled (cost)” means “You may pay (cost) rather than pay this spell's mana cost as you cast this spell.” and “If this spell's fabled cost was paid, put this card onto the battlefield transformed and attach it to that creature, player, or planeswalker.”</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.160b"><b>702.160b</b></a> The Aura that spell becomes will always try to attach to the target of the first ability of the card.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.160c"><b>702.160c</b></a> If the targeted creature or player is an illegal target for the Aura side of a card with fabled, such as a creature with protection from enchantments, the card with fabled will not enter the battlefield and instead be put directly into its owner's graveyard from the stack.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.161"><b>702.161.</b></a> Infiltrate</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.161a"><b>702.161a</b></a> Infiltrate is a triggered ability. “Infiltrate” means “Whenever one or more creatures you control attack and aren't blocked, this creature gets +1/+1 until end of turn.”</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.161b"><b>702.161b</b></a> If a creature has multiple instances of infiltrate, each triggers separately.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.161c"><b>702.161c</b></a> The creature will get +1/+1 until end of turn even if it is not attacking.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.161d"><b>702.161d</b></a> Infiltrate and other 'attacks and isn't blocked' abilities only trigger after blockers have been declared.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.162"><b>702.162.</b></a> Inscribe</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.162a"><b>702.162a</b></a> Inscribe represents an activated ability that functions while the card with inscribe is in its owner's hand and a static ability that functions while the card with inscribe is in the exile zone. “Inscribe (cost)” means “(cost), Reveal this card from your hand: Exile this card from your hand inscribed on a creature you control. Activate this ability only at any time you could cast a sorcery.” and “For as long as this card is inscribed on that creature, that creature has 'Whenever this creature attacks, you may copy the inscribed card and you may cast the copy without paying its mana cost.'”</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.162b"><b>702.162b</b></a> Cards with this ability have the subtype Inscription.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.162c"><b>702.162c</b></a> If an inscribed card somehow leaves exile, it will no longer be inscribed on that creature.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.162d"><b>702.162d</b></a> If you copy an inscribe ability you control, only one of them will be able to exile the card from your hand and will the rest will do nothing.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.162e"><b>702.162e</b></a> If you gain control of or copy an inscribe ability of a card you don't own, you will be unable to exile the card and the ability will do nothing.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.163"><b>702.163.</b></a> Mirage</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.163a"><b>702.163a</b></a> Mirage represents two static abilities, one that functions while the card with mirage is on the stack, and one which may create a delayed triggered ability. “Mirage (cost)” means “You may cast this card as though it had flash by paying (cost) rather than its mana cost,” and “If this spell's mirage cost was paid, sacrifice the permanent this spell becomes at the beginning of the next cleanup step.”</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.163b"><b>702.163b</b></a> Permanents with mirage will leave the battlefield after damage is removed from permanents and 'until end of turn' and 'this turn' effects end.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.163c"><b>702.163c</b></a> If the triggered ability of mirage is countered, it will not trigger again.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.164"><b>702.164.</b></a> Motivate</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.164a"><b>702.164a</b></a> Motivate is a trigged ability. “MotivateN” means “When this creature enters the battlefield, you may put N +1/+1 counters on target creature with power less than this creature's power.”</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.164b"><b>702.164b</b></a> A creature with motivate “motivates a creature” and that creature “becomes motivated” when the controller of the motivate ability puts +1/+1 counters on a creature as that ability resolves.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.165"><b>702.165.</b></a> Prophecy</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.165a"><b>702.165a</b></a> Prophecy is a keyword that represents a static ability linked to a triggered ability. “Prophecy (cost)” means “As you reveal this card from a hidden zone, you may pay and exile it.” and “When you exile this card with its prophecy ability, you may cast it for (cost) rather than paying its mana cost as long as it remains exiled. If you cast it this way, it can't be countered.”</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.165b"><b>702.165b</b></a> You may pay for the using mana abilities (including triggered mana abilities) or floating mana, but not non-mana abilities.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.165c"><b>702.165c</b></a> When a card with prophecy is revealed, any relevant information about it is retained, but the card is exiled and becomes a new object.<br>Example Cursed Scroll will know the name of a card with prophecy, but it can't be put into a Fact or Fiction pile or chosen during the resolution of Gifts Ungiven.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.165d"><b>702.165d</b></a> A card can't be cast for its prophecy cost if it was exiled by an effect other than its prophecy ability.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.165e"><b>702.165e</b></a> If a card with prophecy is cast through a method other than its prophecy cost, such as from your hand, via suspend, or without paying its mana cost, it can be countered by spells and abilities.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.165f"><b>702.165f</b></a> The triggered ability that allows you to cast a card with prophecy from exile can be countered.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.166"><b>702.166.</b></a> Reprise</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.166a"><b>702.166a</b></a> Reprise is a static ability that functions while a card with reprise is in your graveyard. “Reprise (cost)” means “You may exile exactly one card with reprise from your graveyard as you cast an instant or sorcery spell. If you exile this card this way, copy this card's text box onto that spell and pay (cost) as an additional cost to cast that spell.”</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.166b"><b>702.166b</b></a> You can't choose to reprise a card if you can't make the required choices, such as targets, for that card's instructions.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.166c"><b>702.166c</b></a> You can't ever exile two or more cards with reprise for a single spell.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.167"><b>702.167.</b></a> Reverberate</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.167a"><b>702.167a</b></a> Reverberate is a keyword that represents a static ability and a triggered ability that function while the spell with reverberate is on the stack. “Reverberate (cost)” means “As an additional cost to cast this spell, you may pay (cost),” and “When you cast this spell, if you paid its reverberate cost, copy it. If the spell has any targets, you may choose new targets for the copy.”</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.167b"><b>702.167b</b></a> A spell is “reverberated” if it's a copy and it has reverberate.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.168"><b>702.168.</b></a> Revive</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.168a"><b>702.168a</b></a> Revive is an activated ability that functions while the card with revive is in a graveyard. “Revive (cost)” means “(cost), Exile this card from your graveyard: Create a token that’s a copy of this card, except it has no mana cost. Activate this ability only any time you could cast a sorcery.”</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.168b"><b>702.168b</b></a> Revive will create a token that's a copy of the card as it was in the graveyard, rather than it is in exile.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.169"><b>702.169.</b></a> Shimmer</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.169a"><b>702.169a</b></a> Shimmer is a triggered ability that may create one or more delayed triggered abilities. “Shimmer” means “Whenever this creature attacks, create a tapped and attacking token that’s a copy of it.” and “Exile that token at the beginning of the end step.”</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.169b"><b>702.169b</b></a> If a creature has multiple instances of shimmer, each triggers separately.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.169c"><b>702.169c</b></a> The delayed trigger will retrigger at every end step. If the trigger is countered, or avoided by ending the turn, the token will remain on the battlefield and the ability will trigger on the next end step.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.169d"><b>702.169d</b></a> Shimmer will only exile tokens created by its ability. Replacement effects such as Doubling Season cause shimmer to create two tokens, and both will be exiled. Effects that create a copy of those tokens, such as populate, will create a token will not attempt to be exiled every end step.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.169e"><b>702.169e</b></a> If shimmer creates multiple tokens, each one will have its own end step exile trigger.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.170"><b>702.170.</b></a> Trial</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.170a"><b>702.170a</b></a> Trial is a static ability that functions while a spell with trial is on the stack. “Trial N” means “As you cast this spell, an opponent of your choice may pay N life. If that player doesn't, they fail the trial.”</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.170b"><b>702.170b</b></a> Trials are paid or failed after targets have been chosen.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.170c"><b>702.170c</b></a> Objects with trial have conditional effects that check “if the trial was failed,” this condition is true if the opponent chosen as a result of the trial ability didn't pay life as specified by the object's trial ability.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.171"><b>702.171.</b></a> Winnow</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.171a"><b>702.171a</b></a> Winnow is a static ability.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.171b"><b>702.171b</b></a> Damage dealt to a creature with winnow causes that creature’s controller, or its owner if it has no controller, to lose that much life (in addition to any other results that damage causes). See rule <a href="#cr119.3">119.3</a></p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.171c"><b>702.171c</b></a> Multiple instances of winnow on the same object are redundant.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.172"><b>702.172.</b></a> Kindle</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.172a"><b>702.172a</b></a> Kindle is an activated ability that functions while the card with kindle is in a graveyard. “Kindle X—(cost)” means “(cost), Exile this card from your graveyard: Create X 1/1 colorless Elemental creature tokens. Activate this ability only any time you could cast a sorcery.”</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.173"><b>702.173.</b></a> Paranoia</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.173a"><b>702.173a</b></a> Paranoia is a static ability linked to a triggered ability that functions while the card with paranoia is in a player's hand or on the stack. “Paranoia (cost)” means “You may reveal this card from your hand as a permanent you control leaves the battlefield. When you reveal this card this way, you may cast it by paying (cost) rather than its mana cost.”</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.173b"><b>702.173b</b></a> Casting a spell with paranoia ignores all normal timing restrictions for the spell. Effects can still prevent players from casting the spell or increase the mana cost to cast it.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.173c"><b>702.173c</b></a> The triggered ability that allows you to cast a spell for its paranoia cost can be countered.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.173d"><b>702.173d</b></a> If a spell is cast for its paranoia cost, other alternate mana costs can't be paid, but other additional costs can be.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.173e"><b>702.173e</b></a> If a creature leaves the battlefield as part of a cost, unless it was to pay for a mana ability, paranoia will trigger before that spell or ability resolves.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.174"><b>702.174.</b></a> Engage</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.174a"><b>702.174a</b></a> Engage is a static ability of some creatures. “Engage” means “This creature must be blocked each combat if able.”</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.174b"><b>702.174b</b></a> This gets difficult when paired with menace. If there are multiple requirements on how creatures can block, the maximum amount of requirements must be obeyed.<br><b><i>Example:</b></i> Untouched Duelist has engage and menace. You attack with an Untouched Duelist and two creatures with engage. Your opponent has two creatures. Blocking only the Untouched Duelist would leave two unfilled requirements, while blocking the other two engage creatures would leave one unfilled requirement, so the other two engage creatures must be blocked.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.175"><b>702.175.</b></a> Heretic</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.175a"><b>702.175a</b></a> Heretic is a triggered ability of some creatures. “Heretic” means “Whenever you cast a spell that doesn't share a color with this creature, this creature gets +1/+1 until end of turn.”</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.175b"><b>702.175b</b></a> Heretic only checks the color of the creature and the spell when the spell is cast. If either changes color afterwards, it will be too late to gain or negate the effect.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.175c"><b>702.175c</b></a> Colorless spells will always trigger heretic, because they don't share a color with anything.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.176"><b>702.176.</b></a> Primal</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.176a"><b>702.176a</b></a> Primal is a static ability that functions while the spell with primal is on the stack. “Primal (cost)” means “During your turn, you may cast this spell for (cost) rather than pay this spell's mana cost. If you do, casting this spell also counts as playing a land.”</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.176b"><b>702.176b</b></a> The spell with primal is still cast. It is not a special action, it only counts as playing a land when determining if a player can play a land this turn.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.176c"><b>702.176c</b></a> A spell can be cast for its primal cost at any point during a player's turn, as long as the number of lands that player can play this turn is greater than the number of lands they have already played this turn, even if timing restrictions would normally prevent playing a land. This means a spell may be cast for its primal cost during its owner's upkeep or end step, but not during another player's turn, or during a turn where lands can't be played.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.176d"><b>702.176d</b></a> Additional land plays allow you to play additional cards for their primal cost in a turn if they have no requirements.<br>Example Verdant Expanse says “You may play an additional land on each of your turns.” It will allow you to cast two spells for their primal costs. Yngou the Snowbeast says “You may play any number of snow lands on each of your turns.” It will not allow you to cast multiple spells for their primal costs.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.177"><b>702.177.</b></a> Deception</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.177a"><b>702.177a</b></a> Deception is an activated ability that functions only while the card with deception is in a player's hand. “Deception (cost)” means “(cost), Reveal this card from your hand, Return an unblocked attacking creature you control to its owner’s hand: Put this card onto the battlefield from your hand tapped and attacking.”</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.177b"><b>702.177b</b></a> The card with deception remains revealed from the time the ability is announced until the ability leaves the stack.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.177c"><b>702.177c</b></a> A deception ability may be activated only while a creature on the battlefield is unblocked (after blockers are declared). The creature with deception is put onto the battlefield unblocked. It will be attacking the same player or planeswalker as the creature that was returned to its owner's hand.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.178"><b>702.178.</b></a> Quickdraw</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.178a"><b>702.178a</b></a> Quickdraw is a static ability linked to a triggered ability that functions while the card with quickdraw is in a player's hand or on the stack. “Quickdraw (cost)” means “You may reveal this card from your hand as a creature you control blocks or becomes blocked. When you reveal this card this way, you may cast it by paying (cost) rather than its mana cost.”</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.178b"><b>702.178b</b></a> Casting a spell with quickdraw ignores all normal timing restrictions for the spell. Effects can still prevent players from casting the spell or increase the mana cost to cast it.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.178c"><b>702.178c</b></a> The triggered ability that allows you to cast a spell for its quickdraw cost can be countered.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.178d"><b>702.178d</b></a> If a spell is cast for its quickdraw cost, other alternate mana costs can't be paid, but other additional costs can be.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.179"><b>702.179.</b></a> Vision</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.179a"><b>702.179a</b></a> Vision is a triggered ability of some permanents. “Vision” means “When this permanent or another creature enters the battlefield under your control, reveal the top card of your library. Then you may put that card into your graveyard.”</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.179b"><b>702.179b</b></a> Cards that are revealed this way are “envisioned” by the source of the vision ability that revealed them.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.179c"><b>702.179c</b></a> Putting the card into your graveyard has no effect on if the card is envisioned or not.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.179d"><b>702.179d</b></a> Type vision is a variant of the vision ability. “[Type] vision” means “When this permanent or another [type] permanent enters the battlefield under your control, reveal the top card of your library. Then you may put that card into your graveyard.”</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.180"><b>702.180.</b></a> Archive</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.180a"><b>702.180a</b></a> Archive is a static ability of Study enchantments. “Archive X” means “As this permanent enters the battlefield, shuffle the top X cards of your starting library into an additional, face up, library.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.180b"><b>702.180b</b></a> The additional library is referred to as “the archived library” by the Study with the archive ability that created it.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.180c"><b>702.180c</b></a> Whenever state-based actions are checked, if a Study enchantment has an archived library of zero cards, its controller sacrifices it.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.180d"><b>702.180d</b></a> If a card would be put into an archived library, that card is put in that library face up.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.180e"><b>702.180e</b></a> If a Study card with archive leaves the battlefield, the archived library remains, but is no longer affected by any effects the Study provided.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.180f"><b>702.180f</b></a> Cards are not revealed when they are put into a face up library. Cards can still become revealed even though the cards are already visible.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.180g"><b>702.180g</b></a> If another player gains control of a Study, they will control any effects of the Study, but will not own the archived library. This means cards from the archived library can't go into that player's hand, graveyard, or library, and cards that player owns can't be put into the archived library. Effects of the Study may still allow them to manipulate or play the cards in that library.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.181"><b>702.181.</b></a> Cadence</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.181a"><b>702.181a</b></a> Cadence is a triggered ability of some creatures. “Cadence” means “Whenever you cast a spell, if its mana value is greater than this creature's power, put a +1/+1 counter on this creature.”</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.181b"><b>702.181b</b></a> If a permanent with cadence isn't a creature, the cadence ability will trigger whenever you cast a spell with mana value greater than 0.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.182"><b>702.182.</b></a> Orchestrate</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.182a"><b>702.182a</b></a> Orchestrate represents a static ability of a card in your hand that creates a delayed triggered ability. “Orchestrate (cost)” means “At any time you could cast a sorcery, you may pay (cost) and exile this card from your hand. If you do, when you next resolve a spell, cast this card from exile without paying its mana cost.”</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.182b"><b>702.182b</b></a> Exiling a card for its orchestrate cost is a special action and can't be countered.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.182c"><b>702.182c</b></a> If the triggered ability created by orchestrate is countered, the card will remain in exile and the ability allowing you to cast it won't trigger anymore.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.183"><b>702.183.</b></a> Recite</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.183a"><b>702.183a</b></a> Recite represents a static ability that functions while the card with recite is in a graveyard, a triggered ability that functions on the battlefield, and a static ability that functions on the battlefield. “Recite (cost)” means “You may cast this card from your graveyard by paying (cost) rather than paying its mana cost.”, “When this permanent enters the battlefield, if its recite cost was paid, its controller exiles it.”, and “If this creature would leave the battlefield, if its recite cost was paid, exile it instead of putting it anywhere else.” Paying a card's recite cost follows the rules for paying alternative costs.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.184"><b>702.184.</b></a> Spirited</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.184a"><b>702.184a</b></a> Spirited is a triggered ability. “Spirited” means “When this permanent enters the battlefield, you may activate one of its abilities without paying that ability's cost.”</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.184b"><b>702.184b</b></a> If a creature has spirited, its activated abilities whose cost includes the tap symbol or the untap symbol can be activated by its spirited ability even if that creature hasn’t been controlled by that player continuously since their most recent turn began.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.184c"><b>702.184c</b></a> The ability that will be activated is chosen as the spirited ability resolves.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.184d"><b>702.184d</b></a> Multiple instances of spirited trigger separately.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.185"><b>702.185.</b></a> Embody</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.185a"><b>702.185a</b></a> Embody is a static ability of Persona Auras. It means “Enchanted creature is a copy of this Persona except for its types, supertypes, and subtypes.”</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.186"><b>702.186.</b></a> Harvest</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.186a"><b>702.186a</b></a> Harvest represents a static ability that functions while the spell with harvest is on the stack. “Harvest” means “As an additional cost to cast this spell, you may tap any number of untapped creatures you control. This spell costs less to cast, where X is the total power of creatures tapped this way.” Paying a spell's harvest cost follows the rules for paying additional costs in rules <a href="#cr601.2b">601.2b</a> and <a href="#cr601.2f">601.2f</a>-h.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.186b"><b>702.186b</b></a> You choose which creatures you will tap as you choose to pay a spell's harvest cost, and you tap those creatures as you pay the total cost.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.187"><b>702.187.</b></a> Puzzlebox</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.187a"><b>702.187a</b></a> Puzzlebox represents two abilities, a static ability that functions as a conspiracy card with puzzlebox is put into the command zone, and a static ability that functions while the conspiracy is face up in the command zone. “Puzzlebox” means “As you put this conspiracy card into the command zone, put a card you own from outside the game into the command zone face down and locked” and “As this puzzlebox becomes unlocked, turn the locked card face up.”</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.188"><b>702.188.</b></a> Sleight</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.188a"><b>702.188a</b></a> Sleight is a static ability that functions while a spell with sleight is being cast. “Sleight” means “You may cast this spell as though it had flash if you pay more to cast it.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.188b"><b>702.188b</b></a> The spell with sleight will not actually gain flash, you will just be able to cast it as though it did.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.189"><b>702.189.</b></a> Mark</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.189a"><b>702.189a</b></a> Mark is a triggered ability of some creatures. “Mark” means “Whenever this creature attacks, target creature becomes marked until end of turn.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.189b"><b>702.189b</b></a> Marked is a designation that has no rules meaning other than to act as a marker that spells and abilities can identify. Only permanents can be or become marked.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.190"><b>702.190.</b></a> Coalesce</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.190a"><b>702.190a</b></a> Coalesce appears on Revelation cards. It represents three static abilities: one that functions while the card is in a player's graveyard and two that function while the card is on the stack. “Coalesce (cost)” means “You may cast this card from your graveyard by paying (cost) rather than paying its mana cost” and “If the coalesce cost was paid, put this card onto the battlefield as a Horror creature. If it would leave the battlefield, exile it instead of putting it anywhere else,” and “If the coalesce cost was paid, exile this card instead of putting it anywhere else anytime it would leave the stack except being put onto the battlefield with its coalesce ability.”</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.190b"><b>702.190b</b></a> A copy of a spell cast for its coalesce cost is unable to enter the battlefield, as a token or otherwise. The spell effect of the copy will still happen as normal.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.191"><b>702.191.</b></a> Chosen one</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.191a"><b>702.191a</b></a> Chosen one is an activated ability of some permanents. “Chosen one” means “(W)(U)(B)(R)(G): Transform this permanent.”</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.192"><b>702.192.</b></a> Desecrate</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.192a"><b>702.192a</b></a> Desecrate is a triggered ability. “Desecrate” means “When this creature enters the battlefield, you may sacrifice an artifact or land.”</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.192b"><b>702.192b</b></a> A creature with desecrate “desecrates a permanent” when the controller of the desecrate ability sacrifices a permanent as that ability resolves.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.193"><b>702.193.</b></a> Bloodprice</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.193a"><b>702.193a</b></a> Bloodprice is a static ability that functions while the spell with bloodprice is on the stack. “Bloodprice (cost)” means “You may cast this spell by paying (cost) and sacrificing a creature rather than paying its mana cost.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.194"><b>702.194.</b></a> Defiance</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.194a"><b>702.194a</b></a> Defiance is a triggered ability of some creatures. “Defiance” means “Whenever this creature is dealt damage, if it isn't defiant, put a +1/+1 counter on it and it becomes defiant.”</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.195"><b>702.195.</b></a> Enspirit</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.195a"><b>702.195a</b></a> Enspirit represents two static abilities, one that functions while the spell with enspirit is on the stack and another that functions both while it's on the stack and while it's on the battlefield. “Enspirit” means “As an additional cost to cast this spell, you may exile a nonenchantment creature you control until this spell is put from the stack into a zone other than the battlefield or the permanent this spell becomes leaves the battlefield” and “If you chose to pay this spell's additional cost, its total cost is reduced by an amount of generic mana equal to the exiled card's mana value.” Paying a spell's enspirit cost follows the rules for paying additional costs in rules <a href="#cr601.2b">601.2b</a> and <a href="#cr601.2f">601.2f</a>–h.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.195b"><b>702.195b</b></a> The two abilities represented by enspirit are linked. The first ability may also be linked with any number of other abilities printed on the card with enspirit which refer either to “the exiled card” or to cards “exiled with [this object]”. See rule <a href="#cr607">607</a>, “Linked Abilities.”</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.195c"><b>702.195c</b></a> You choose which creature to exile as you choose to pay a spell's enspirit cost (see rule <a href="#cr601.2b">601.2b</a>), and you exile that creature as you pay the total cost (see rule <a href="#cr601.2h">601.2h</a>).</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.195d"><b>702.195d</b></a> A creature “becomes enspirited” when it's exiled to pay a spell's enspirit cost. Abilities that trigger when a creature becomes enspirited are leaves-the-battlefield abilities (see rule <a href="#cr603.6c">603.6c</a>).</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.196"><b>702.196.</b></a> Harmony</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.196a"><b>702.196a</b></a> A harmony ability is a special kind of triggered ability that only triggers when chosen as part of the harmonize keyword action (see rule <a href="#cr701.50">701.50</a>). “Harmony — [Effect]” means “Whenever you harmonize, if you choose this ability, [effect].”</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.197"><b>702.197.</b></a> Tithe</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.197a"><b>702.197a</b></a> Tithe is an ability of some cards. It behaves differently on permanent and nonpermanent cards.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.197b"><b>702.197b</b></a> On a permanent card, tithe is a triggered ability. “Tithe” on a permanent means “When this permanent enters the battlefield, you may tap three other untapped artifacts and/or creatures you control.” Tapping the three permanents is a cost (see rule <a href="#cr118">118</a>) and may be referred to as paying the permanent's tithe.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.197c"><b>702.197c</b></a> On an instant or sorcery card, tithe is a static ability that functions while the spell with tithe is on the stack. “Tithe” on an instant or sorcery spell means “As an additional cost to cast this spell, you may tap three untapped artifacts and/or creatures you control.” Paying an instant or sorcery spell's tithe cost follows the rules for paying additional costs in rules <a href="#cr601.2b">601.2b</a> and <a href="#cr601.2f">601.2f</a>–h. An instant or sorcery spell's tithe cost may also simply be referred to as its tithe.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.198"><b>702.198.</b></a> Eureka!</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.198a"><b>702.198a</b></a> Eureka! is a triggered ability of some permanents. “Eureka!” means “At the beginning of each end step, you get a research counter if you cast a spell this turn. Then if you have eight or more research couters, you lose all research counters, then create your choice of Cultivating Spheres, Mirror of Possibilities, and Thrice-Folded Lotus.”</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.198b"><b>702.198b</b></a> Cultivating Spheres is a colorless Masterpiece artifact token with “At the beginning of your draw step, draw an additional card” and “You may play an additional land on each of your turns.”</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.198c"><b>702.198c</b></a> Mirror of Possibilities is a colorless Masterpiece artifact token with “Whenever you cast an instant or sorcery spell, you may pay {3}. If you do, copy it. You may choose new targets for the copy” and “Whenever a nontoken creature enters the battlefield under your control, you may pay {3}. If you do, create a token that’s a copy of it.”</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.198d"><b>702.198d</b></a> Thrice-Folded Lotus is a colorless Masterpiece artifact token with “{T}: Add three mana of any one color” and “{3}, {T}: Thrice-Folded Lotus deals 3 damage to any target.”</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.198e"><b>702.198e</b></a> Eureka! checks if you cast a spell this turn when the ability resolves. This means you can cast a spell in response to the trigger to get a counter.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.199"><b>702.199.</b></a> Memento</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.199a"><b>702.199a</b></a> Memento appears on some double-faced cards. It represents three static abilities: one that functions while the card with memento is in a player's graveyard and two that function while the spell with memento is on the stack. “Memento (cost)” means “You may cast this card from your graveyard by paying (cost) rather than paying its mana cost,” “If this memento cost was paid, put this card onto the battlefield transformed. If it would leave the battlefield, exile it instead of putting it anywhere else,” and “If the memento cost was paid, exile this card instead of putting it anywhere else anytime it would leave the stack except being put onto the battlefield with its memento ability.”</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.200"><b>702.200.</b></a> Leitmotif</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.200a"><b>702.200a</b></a> Leitmotif appears on some instants and sorceries. It represents a static ability that functions while the spell is on the stack and may create a delayed triggered ability. “Leitmotif” means “If this spell was cast from your hand, instead of putting it into your graveyard as it resolves, exile it and, when you cast a spell that shares a color with this card, you may cast this card from exile without paying its mana cost.”</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.200b"><b>702.200b</b></a> Casting a spell as an effect of its leitmotif ability follows the rules for paying alternative costs in rules <a href="#cr601.2b">601.2b</a> and <a href="#cr601.2f">601.2f</a>–h.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.200c"><b>702.200c</b></a> Multiple instances of leitmotif on the same spell are redundant.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.200d"><b>702.200d</b></a> Type leitmotif is a variant of the leitmotif ability. “Type leitmotif” means “If this spell was cast from your hand, instead of putting it into your graveyard as it resolves, exile it and, when you cast a spell that shares a type with this card, you may cast this card from exile without paying its mana cost.”</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.201"><b>702.201.</b></a> Embellish</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.201a"><b>702.201a</b></a> Embellish represents a static ability that functions while the card with embellish is on the stack and a triggered ability that functions on the battlefield, and one which may create a delayed triggered ability. “Embellish (cost)” means “You may cast this card as by paying (cost) rather than its mana cost,” and “When this permanent enters the battlefield, if its embellish cost was paid, create a 1/1 blue Thopter artifact creature token with flying.” Casting a spell for its embellish cost follows the rules for paying alternative costs in rules <a href="#cr601.2b">601.2b</a> and <a href="#cr601.2f">601.2f</a>–h.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.202"><b>702.202.</b></a> Encourage</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.202a"><b>702.202a</b></a> Encourage is an activated ability. “Encourage” means “{T}: Another target creature you control gets +1/+1 until end of turn. Activate this ability only any time you could cast a sorcery.”</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.202b"><b>702.202b</b></a> A creature with encourage “encourages a creature” and that creature “becomes encouraged” as the encourage ability resolves.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.203"><b>702.203.</b></a> Tether</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.203a"><b>702.203a</b></a> Tether appears on some instants and sorceries. It represents two abilities. The first is a spell ability that functions while the spell with tether is on the stack. The second is a static ability that functions while the card with tether is in the exile zone. “Tether” means “If this spell is represented by a card, you may exile this card tethered to a creature you control” and “When the creature this card is tethered to dies, you may cast this card from exile without paying its mana cost.”</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.203b"><b>702.203b</b></a> The term “tethered” describes the relationship between the card with tether while in the exile zone and the creature chosen when the spell represented by that card resolves.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.203c"><b>702.203c</b></a> The card with tether remains tethered to the chosen creature as long as the card with tether remains exiled and the creature remains on the battlefield. The card remains tethered to that object even if it changes controller or stops being a creature, as long as it remains on the battlefield.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.203d"><b>702.203d</b></a> If the permanent is put into a graveyard while not a creature, the 'dies' trigger of tether will still trigger.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.203e"><b>702.203e</b></a> Tether to type is a variant of the tether ability. “Tether to [type]” means “If this spell is represented by a card, you may exile this card tethered to a [type] you control” and “When the permanent this card is tethered to is put into a graveyard from the battlefield, you may cast this card from exile without paying its mana cost.”</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.204"><b>702.204.</b></a> Assault</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.204a"><b>702.204a</b></a> Assault is a triggered ability of some creatures. “Assault (cost)” means “Whenever this creatures attacks, if it has no +1/+1 counters on it, you may pay (cost). If you do, put a +1/+1 counter on it.”</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.204b"><b>702.204b</b></a> A creature “assaults” whenever its assault cost is paid.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.205"><b>702.205.</b></a> Gestalt</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.205a"><b>702.205a</b></a> Gestalt represents two triggered abilities. “Gestalt” means “When this creature enters the battlefield, you may merge it with a another creature you control. It becomes a gestalt permanent. Move any counters from this creature to the gestalt permanent and attach any cards attached to this creature to the gestalt permanent.” and “When another creature enters the battlefield under your control, you may merge it with this permanent. It becomes a gestalt permanent. Move any counters from that creature to the gestalt permanent and attach any cards attached to that creature to the gestalt permanent.”</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.205b"><b>702.205b</b></a> A gestalt permanent has all abilities of each card and token that represents it. Its other characteristics are derived from the topmost card or token.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.206"><b>702.206.</b></a> Harness</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.206a"><b>702.206a</b></a> “Harness” means “As an additional cost to cast this spell, you may tap an untapped creature you control. This spell costs {X} less to cast, where X is that creature's power.”</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.206b"><b>702.206b</b></a> The creature tapped this way “harnesses” that spell.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.207"><b>702.207.</b></a> Pressure</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.207a"><b>702.207a</b></a> Pressure is a static ability that functions while the spell with surge is on the stack. “Pressure (cost)” means “You may pay (cost) rather than pay this spell’s mana cost as you cast this spell if there are seven or more cards in your graveyard.”</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.207b"><b>702.207b</b></a> The final cost of a spell is locked in before costs are paid, meaning a spell can be cast for its pressure cost while also having an additional cost that exiles cards from its controller's graveyard that would result in having fewer than seven cards in it.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.208"><b>702.208.</b></a> Slipstream</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.208a"><b>702.208a</b></a> Slipstream is an evasion ability. A creature with slipstream can't be blocked as long as each attacking creature has slipstream.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.208b"><b>702.208b</b></a> If creatures with and without slipstream are attacking and then each attacking creature without slipstream is removed from combat, creatures with slipstream can't be blocked. However, if blockers have already been declared, those creatures will still be blocked.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.209"><b>702.209.</b></a> Beckon</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.209a"><b>702.209a</b></a> Beckon is an activated ability of Deity permanents. “Beckon (type)—(cost)” means “(Cost): If this permanent isn't a creature, it becomes a (type) creature in addition to its other types.”</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.209b"><b>702.209b</b></a> A beckon effect lasts indefinitely.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.209c"><b>702.209c</b></a> If a Deity somehow becomes a noncreature again, its beckon ability can be reactivated.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.209d"><b>702.209d</b></a> If a Deity is a creature, its beckon ability will have no affect, even if it's not the creature type it would become.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.210"><b>702.210.</b></a> Mimic</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.210a"><b>702.210a</b></a> Mimic is an activated ability. “Mimic (cost)” means “(Cost): Choose a number. Activate only as a sorcery.”</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.210b"><b>702.210b</b></a> Any number can be chosen. If the permanent does not have a shape associated with that number, it will only have its base characteristics.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.211"><b>702.211.</b></a> Glitch</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.211a"><b>702.211a</b></a> Glitch represents two static abilities that function while the spell with glitch is on the stack. “Glitch [cost]” means “You may pay an additional [cost] any number of times as you cast this spell” and “For each time you chose to pay this spell's glitch cost, change its text by removing one instance of text in [] brackets.” Paying a spell’s glitch cost(s) follows the rules for paying additional costs in rules <a href="#cr601.2b">601.2b</a> and <a href="#cr601.2f">601.2f</a>–h.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.211b"><b>702.211b</b></a> If a spell’s controller declares the intention to pay any of that spell’s glitch costs, that spell is “glitched.”</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.211c"><b>702.211c</b></a> If a glitched spell is copied, the choice of which instances of bracketed text were removed will be copied as well.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.211d"><b>702.211d</b></a> Persistent glitch is an activated ability and variant of the glitch ability found on permanents. “Persistent glitch [cost]” means “[Cost]: Change the text of this permanent by removing one instance of text in [] brackets.”</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.212"><b>702.212.</b></a> Respawn</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.212a"><b>702.212a</b></a> Respawn is a triggered ability. “Respawn” means “When this creature dies, if it attacked this turn, return it to its owner's hand.”</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.213"><b>702.213.</b></a> Align</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.213a"><b>702.213a</b></a> Align is a static ability that functions while the spell or ability with align is on the stack. “Align X” means “Choose any number of modes with total ⭐ value X or less. You may choose the same mode more than once.”</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.213b"><b>702.213b</b></a> Each mode of a spell or ability with align has a number of stars printed before its text. The number of stars is that mode's ⭐ value.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.214"><b>702.214.</b></a> Ascend</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.214a"><b>702.214a</b></a> Ascend is an activated ability. “Ascend (cost)” means “(cost): Exile this creature, then return it to the battlefield transformed. Activate only any time you could cast a sorcery.”</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.215"><b>702.215.</b></a> Acquiesce</p>
<p><a id="cr702.216"><b>702.216.</b></a> </p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.216a"><b>702.216a</b></a> Acquiesce appears on some instants and sorceries. It represents two abilities. The first is a spell ability that functions while the spell with acquiesce is on the stack. The second is a triggered ability that functions while the card with acquiesce is in the exile zone. “Acquiesce” means “If you cast this spell from your hand, exile it” and “Whenever one or more creatures you control deal combat damage to an opponent, you may cast this card from exile without paying its mana cost.”</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.216b"><b>702.216b</b></a> An exiled card with acquiesce does not need to be cast at the first opportunity. If it is not, the ability will still trigger the next time combat damage is dealt.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.217"><b>702.217.</b></a> Monument</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.217a"><b>702.217a</b></a> Monument is an ability found on the front face of some transforming double-faced cards (see rule <a href="#cr712">712</a>, “Double-Faced Cards”). “Monument [cost]” means “You may cast this card transformed from your graveyard by paying [cost] rather than its mana cost. If this spell would leave the battlefield other than being put onto the battlefied, or the permanent it becomes would leave the battlefield, exile it instead.” See rule <a href="#cr712.4b">712.4b</a>.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.217b"><b>702.217b</b></a> A resolving transforming double-faced spell that was cast using its monument ability enters the battlefield with its back face up.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.218"><b>702.218.</b></a> Successor</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.218a"><b>702.218a</b></a> Successor is an activated ability that functions while the card with successor is in a graveyard. “Successor (cost)” means “(cost), Exile this card from your graveyard: Create a token that’s a copy of this card, except it has no mana cost and it has base power and toughness 1/1. Activate only any time you could cast a sorcery.”</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.218b"><b>702.218b</b></a> Successor will create a token that's a copy of the card as it was in the graveyard, rather than it is in exile.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.219"><b>702.219.</b></a> Infamy</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.219a"><b>702.219a</b></a> Infamy is a triggered ability. “Infamy N” means “When this creature deals combat damage to a player, if it isn’t infamous, put N +1/+1 counters on it and it becomes infamous.”</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.219b"><b>702.219b</b></a> Infamous is a designation that has no rules meaning other than to act as a marker that the infamy ability and other spells and abilities can identify. Only permanents can be or become infamous. Once a permanent becomes infamous, it stays infamous until it leaves the battlefield. Infamous is neither an ability nor part of the permanent’s copiable values.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.219c"><b>702.219c</b></a> If a creature has multiple instances of infamy, each triggers separately. The first such ability to resolve will cause the creature to become infamous, and subsequent abilities will have no effect. (See rule <a href="#cr603.4">603.4</a>)</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.220"><b>702.220.</b></a> Overclock</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.220a"><b>702.220a</b></a> Overclock is a keyword that represents two triggered abilities. “Overclock” means “When this creature enters the battlefield, if you control both this creature and another artifact, you may overclock another artifact you control for as long as both remain permanents on the battlefield under your control or until this creature overclocks another artifact” and “Whenever an artifact enters the battlefield under your control, if you control both that artifact and this creature, you may overclock this artifact for as long as both remain creatures on the battlefield under your control or until that creature overclocks another artifact.”</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.220b"><b>702.220b</b></a> An artifact becomes “overclocked” with another as the result of a overclock ability. Abilities may refer to an overclocked artifact, the artifact a creature overclocks, or whether an artifact is overclocked.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.220c"><b>702.220c</b></a> A creature can only overclock one artifact, however an artifact may be overclocked by multiple creatures.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.220d"><b>702.220d</b></a> An overclocked artifact stops being overclocked if any of the following occur: another player gains control of it or the creature overclocking it; it or the creature overclocking it leaves the battlefield; or the creature overclocking it overclocks another artifact.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.221"><b>702.221.</b></a> Simulacrum</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.221a"><b>702.221a</b></a> Simulacrum is a triggered ability. “Simulacrum” means “When this permanent is put into a graveyard from the battlefield, exile it from your graveyard. If you do, create a token that's a copy of this card, except it's colorless, it's 1/1, it has no mana cost, and it's a Crystal artifact in addition to its other types.”</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.221b"><b>702.221b</b></a> If a permanent with simulacrum is controlled by a player other than its owner when it dies, that player will be unable to exile it from their graveyard, and won't create the token copy.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.222"><b>702.222.</b></a> Improve</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.222a"><b>702.222a</b></a> Improve is an activated ability of some permanents. “Impove <cost>” means “<cost>: Put a +1/+1 counter on this permanent. This ability costs (1) more to activate for each +1/+1 counter on this permanent. Improve only as a sorcery.”</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.223"><b>702.223.</b></a> Ride</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.223a"><b>702.223a</b></a> Ride is an activated ability of some double-faced cards. “Ride <cost>” means “<cost>: Transform this creature and attach it to target creature you control that doesn't have a Mount enchantment attached to it. As long as this card remains attached to a permanent, you may pay <cost> any time you could cast a sorcery to unattach it from that permanent. Ride only as a sorcery.”</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.223b"><b>702.223b</b></a> If a Mount is on the battlefield not attached to a permanent, it transforms rather than being put into its owner's graveyard if able. (This is a state-based action. See rule <a href="#cr704.">704.</a>)</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr702.223c"><b>702.223c</b></a> The creature a Mount card enchants may be referred to as its “rider”. Effects that refer to a Mount's rider are identical to those that would refer to enchanted creature.</p>
<p><a id="cr703"><b>703. Turn-Based Actions</b></a></p>
<p><a id="cr703.1"><b>703.1.</b></a> Turn-based actions are game actions that happen automatically when certain steps or phases begin, or when each step and phase ends. Turn-based actions don’t use the stack.</p>
<p><a id="cr703.1a"><b>703.1a</b></a> Abilities that watch for a specified step or phase to begin are triggered abilities, not turn-based actions. (See rule <a href="#cr603">603</a>, “Handling Triggered Abilities.”)</p>
<p><a id="cr703.2"><b>703.2.</b></a> Turn-based actions are not controlled by any player.</p>
<p><a id="cr703.3"><b>703.3.</b></a> Whenever a step or phase begins, if it’s a step or phase that has any turn-based action associated with it, those turn-based actions are automatically dealt with first. This happens before state-based actions are checked, before triggered abilities are put on the stack, and before players receive priority.</p>
<p><a id="cr703.4"><b>703.4.</b></a> The turn-based actions are as follows:</p>
<p><a id="cr703.4a"><b>703.4a</b></a> Immediately after the untap step begins, all phased-in permanents with phasing that the active player controls phase out, and all phased-out permanents that the active player controlled when they phased out phase in. This all happens simultaneously. See rule <a href="#cr502.1">502.1</a>.</p>
<p><a id="cr703.4b"><b>703.4b</b></a> Immediately after the phasing action has been completed during the untap step, if the game has either the day or night designation, it checks to see whether that designation should change. If it’s neither day nor night, this check doesn’t happen. See rule <a href="#cr502.2">502.2</a>.</p>
<p><a id="cr703.4c"><b>703.4c</b></a> Immediately after the game checks to see if its day or night designation should change during the untap step or, if the game doesn’t have a day or night designation, immediately after the phasing action has been completed during the untap step, the active player determines which permanents they control will untap. Then they untap them all simultaneously. See rule <a href="#cr502.3">502.3</a>.</p>
<p><a id="cr703.4d"><b>703.4d</b></a> Immediately after the draw step begins, the active player draws a card. See rule <a href="#cr504.1">504.1</a>.</p>
<p><a id="cr703.4e"><b>703.4e</b></a> In an Archenemy game (see rule <a href="#cr904">904</a>), immediately after the archenemy’s precombat main phase begins, that player sets the top card of their scheme deck in motion. See rule <a href="#cr701.25">701.25</a>.</p>
<p><a id="cr703.4f"><b>703.4f</b></a> Immediately after a player’s precombat main phase begins, that player puts a lore counter on each Saga enchantment they control. In an Archenemy game, this happens after the archenemy’s scheme action. See rule <a href="#cr715">715</a>, “Saga Cards.”</p>
<p><a id="cr703.4g"><b>703.4g</b></a> Immediately after the beginning of combat step begins, if the game being played is a multiplayer game in which the active player’s opponents don’t all automatically become defending players, the active player chooses one of their opponents. That player becomes the defending player. See rule <a href="#cr507.1">507.1</a>.</p>
<p><a id="cr703.4h"><b>703.4h</b></a> Immediately after the declare attackers step begins, the active player declares attackers. See rule <a href="#cr508.1">508.1</a>.</p>
<p><a id="cr703.4i"><b>703.4i</b></a> Immediately after the declare blockers step begins, the defending player declares blockers. See rule <a href="#cr509.1">509.1</a>.</p>
<p><a id="cr703.4j"><b>703.4j</b></a> Immediately after blockers have been declared during the declare blockers step, for each attacking creature that’s become blocked by multiple creatures, the active player announces the damage assignment order among the blocking creatures. See rule <a href="#cr509.2">509.2</a>.</p>
<p><a id="cr703.4k"><b>703.4k</b></a> Immediately after the active player has announced damage assignment orders (if necessary) during the declare blockers step, for each creature that’s blocking multiple creatures, the defending player announces the damage assignment order among the attacking creatures. See rule <a href="#cr509.3">509.3</a>.</p>
<p><a id="cr703.4m"><b>703.4m</b></a> Immediately after the combat damage step begins, each player in APNAP order announces how each attacking or blocking creature they control assigns its combat damage. See rule <a href="#cr510.1">510.1</a>.</p>
<p><a id="cr703.4n"><b>703.4n</b></a> Immediately after combat damage has been assigned during the combat damage step, all combat damage is dealt simultaneously. See rule <a href="#cr510.2">510.2</a>.</p>
<p><a id="cr703.4p"><b>703.4p</b></a> Immediately after the cleanup step begins, if the active player’s hand contains more cards than their maximum hand size (normally seven), they discard enough cards to reduce their hand size to that number. See rule <a href="#cr514.1">514.1</a>.</p>
<p><a id="cr703.4q"><b>703.4q</b></a> Immediately after the active player has discarded cards (if necessary) during the cleanup step, all damage is removed from permanents and all “until end of turn” and “this turn” effects end. These actions happen simultaneously. See rule <a href="#cr514.2">514.2</a>.</p>
<p><a id="cr703.4r"><b>703.4r</b></a> When each step or phase ends, any unused mana left in a player’s mana pool empties. See rule <a href="#cr500.4">500.4</a>.</p>
<p><a id="cr704"><b>704. State-Based Actions</b></a></p>
<p><a id="cr704.1"><b>704.1.</b></a> State-based actions are game actions that happen automatically whenever certain conditions (listed below) are met. State-based actions don’t use the stack.</p>
<p><a id="cr704.1a"><b>704.1a</b></a> Abilities that watch for a specified game state are triggered abilities, not state-based actions. (See rule <a href="#cr603">603</a>, “Handling Triggered Abilities.”)</p>
<p><a id="cr704.2"><b>704.2.</b></a> State-based actions are checked throughout the game and are not controlled by any player.</p>
<p><a id="cr704.3"><b>704.3.</b></a> Whenever a player would get priority (see rule <a href="#cr117">117</a>, “Timing and Priority”), the game checks for any of the listed conditions for state-based actions, then performs all applicable state-based actions simultaneously as a single event. If any state-based actions are performed as a result of a check, the check is repeated; otherwise all triggered abilities that are waiting to be put on the stack are put on the stack, then the check is repeated. Once no more state-based actions have been performed as the result of a check and no triggered abilities are waiting to be put on the stack, the appropriate player gets priority. This process also occurs during the cleanup step (see rule <a href="#cr514">514</a>), except that if no state-based actions are performed as the result of the step’s first check and no triggered abilities are waiting to be put on the stack, then no player gets priority and the step ends.</p>
<p><a id="cr704.4"><b>704.4.</b></a> Unlike triggered abilities, state-based actions pay no attention to what happens during the resolution of a spell or ability.<br><b><i>Example:</b></i> A player controls a creature with the ability “This creature’s power and toughness are each equal to the number of cards in your hand” and casts a spell whose effect is “Discard your hand, then draw seven cards.” The creature will temporarily have toughness 0 in the middle of the spell’s resolution but will be back up to toughness 7 when the spell finishes resolving. Thus the creature will survive when state-based actions are checked. In contrast, an ability that triggers when the player has no cards in hand goes on the stack after the spell resolves, because its trigger event happened during resolution.</p>
<p><a id="cr704.5"><b>704.5.</b></a> The state-based actions are as follows:</p>
<p><a id="cr704.5a"><b>704.5a</b></a> If a player has 0 or less life, that player loses the game.</p>
<p><a id="cr704.5b"><b>704.5b</b></a> If a player attempted to draw a card from a library with no cards in it since the last time state-based actions were checked, that player loses the game.</p>
<p><a id="cr704.5c"><b>704.5c</b></a> If a player has ten or more poison counters, that player loses the game. Ignore this rule in Two-Headed Giant games; see rule <a href="#cr704.6b">704.6b</a> instead.</p>
<p><a id="cr704.5d"><b>704.5d</b></a> If a token is in a zone other than the battlefield, it ceases to exist.</p>
<p><a id="cr704.5e"><b>704.5e</b></a> If a copy of a spell is in a zone other than the stack, it ceases to exist. If a copy of a card is in any zone other than the stack or the battlefield, it ceases to exist.</p>
<p><a id="cr704.5f"><b>704.5f</b></a> If a creature has toughness 0 or less, it’s put into its owner’s graveyard. Regeneration can’t replace this event.</p>
<p><a id="cr704.5g"><b>704.5g</b></a> If a creature has toughness greater than 0, it has damage marked on it, and the total damage marked on it is greater than or equal to its toughness, that creature has been dealt lethal damage and is destroyed. Regeneration can replace this event.</p>
<p><a id="cr704.5h"><b>704.5h</b></a> If a creature has toughness greater than 0, and it’s been dealt damage by a source with deathtouch since the last time state-based actions were checked, that creature is destroyed. Regeneration can replace this event.</p>
<p><a id="cr704.5i"><b>704.5i</b></a> If a planeswalker has loyalty 0, it’s put into its owner’s graveyard.</p>
<p><a id="cr704.5j"><b>704.5j</b></a> If a player controls two or more legendary permanents with the same name, that player chooses one of them, and the rest are put into their owners’ graveyards. This is called the “legend rule.”</p>
<p><a id="cr704.5k"><b>704.5k</b></a> If two or more permanents have the supertype world, all except the one that has had the world supertype for the shortest amount of time are put into their owners’ graveyards. In the event of a tie for the shortest amount of time, all are put into their owners’ graveyards. This is called the “world rule.”</p>
<p><a id="cr704.5m"><b>704.5m</b></a> If an Aura is attached to an illegal object or player, or is not attached to an object or player, that Aura is put into its owner’s graveyard.</p>
<p><a id="cr704.5n"><b>704.5n</b></a> If an Equipment or Fortification is attached to an illegal permanent or to a player, it becomes unattached from that permanent or player. It remains on the battlefield.</p>
<p><a id="cr704.5p"><b>704.5p</b></a> If a creature is attached to an object or player, it becomes unattached and remains on the battlefield. Similarly, if a permanent that’s neither an Aura, an Equipment, nor a Fortification is attached to an object or player, it becomes unattached and remains on the battlefield.</p>
<p><a id="cr704.5q"><b>704.5q</b></a> If a permanent has both a +1/+1 counter and a -1/-1 counter on it, N +1/+1 and N -1/-1 counters are removed from it, where N is the smaller of the number of +1/+1 and -1/-1 counters on it.</p>
<p><a id="cr704.5r"><b>704.5r</b></a> If a permanent with an ability that says it can’t have more than N counters of a certain kind on it has more than N counters of that kind on it, all but N of those counters are removed from it.</p>
<p><a id="cr704.5s"><b>704.5s</b></a> If the number of lore counters on a Saga permanent is greater than or equal to its final chapter number and it isn’t the source of a chapter ability that has triggered but not yet left the stack, that Saga’s controller sacrifices it. See rule <a href="#cr715">715</a>, “Saga Cards.”</p>
<p><a id="cr704.5t"><b>704.5t</b></a> If a player’s venture marker is on the bottommost room of a dungeon card, and that dungeon card isn’t the source of a room ability that has triggered but not yet left the stack, the dungeon card’s owner removes it from the game. See rule <a href="#cr309">309</a>, “Dungeons.”</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr704.5u"><b>704.5u</b></a> If an Aura is attached to an illegal object or player, or is not attached to an object or player, that Aura transforms if it is a Mount represented by a double-faced card that has not transformed since the last time state-based actions were checked, otherwise it is put into its owner's graveyard.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr704.5v"><b>704.5v</b></a> If a player has ten or more glory counters, they win the game. Ignore this rule in Two-Headed Giant games; see rule C704.5b instead.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr704.5w"><b>704.5w</b></a> If a Study permanent has a nonexistent archived library, that Study's controller sacrifices it.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr704.5x"><b>704.5x</b></a> If a mystery card has one or more mystery abilities and each of those abilities is decoded, it transforms.</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr704.5y"><b>704.5y</b></a> If the number of quest counters on a Quest permanent is greater than or equal to its final quest number and it isn't the source of a quest ability that has triggered but not yet left the stack, that Quest's controller sacrifices it. See rule <a href="#cr728">728</a>, “Quest Cards.”</p>
<p><a id="cr704.6"><b>704.6.</b></a> Some variant games include additional state-based actions that aren’t normally applicable:</p>
<p><a id="cr704.6a"><b>704.6a</b></a> In a Two-Headed Giant game, if a team has 0 or less life, that team loses the game. See rule <a href="#cr810">810</a>, “Two-Headed Giant Variant.”</p>
<p><a id="cr704.6b"><b>704.6b</b></a> In a Two-Headed Giant game, if a team has fifteen or more poison counters, that team loses the game. See rule <a href="#cr810">810</a>, “Two-Headed Giant Variant.”</p>
<p><a id="cr704.6c"><b>704.6c</b></a> In a Commander game, a player who’s been dealt 21 or more combat damage by the same commander over the course of the game loses the game. See rule <a href="#cr903">903</a>, “Commander.”</p>
<p><a id="cr704.6d"><b>704.6d</b></a> In a Commander game, if a commander is in a graveyard or in exile and that object was put into that zone since the last time state-based actions were checked, its owner may put it into the command zone. See rule <a href="#cr903">903</a>, “Commander.” </p>
<p><a id="cr704.6e"><b>704.6e</b></a> In an Archenemy game, if a non-ongoing scheme card is face up in the command zone, and no triggered abilities of any scheme are on the stack or waiting to be put on the stack, that scheme card is turned face down and put on the bottom of its owner’s scheme deck. See rule <a href="#cr904">904</a>, “Archenemy.”</p>
<p><a id="cr704.6f"><b>704.6f</b></a> In a Planechase game, if a phenomenon card is face up in the command zone, and it isn’t the source of a triggered ability that has triggered but not yet left the stack, the planar controller planeswalks. See rule <a href="#cr901">901</a>, “Planechase.”</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr704.6g"><b>704.6g</b></a> In a Two-Headed Giant game, if a team has fifteen or more glory counters, that team wins the game. See rule <a href="#cr810">810</a>, “Two-Headed Giant Variant.”</p>
<p><a id="cr704.7"><b>704.7.</b></a> If multiple state-based actions would have the same result at the same time, a single replacement effect will replace all of them.<br><b><i>Example:</b></i> You control Lich’s Mirror, which says “If you would lose the game, instead shuffle your hand, your graveyard, and all permanents you own into your library, then draw seven cards and your life total becomes 20.” There’s one card in your library and your life total is 1. A spell causes you to draw two cards and lose 2 life. The next time state-based actions are checked, you’d lose the game due to rule <a href="#cr704.5a">704.5a</a> and rule <a href="#cr704.5b">704.5b</a>. Instead, Lich’s Mirror replaces that game loss and you keep playing.</p>
<p><a id="cr704.8"><b>704.8.</b></a> If a state-based action results in a permanent leaving the battlefield at the same time other state-based actions were performed, that permanent’s last known information is derived from the game state before any of those state-based actions were performed.<br><b><i>Example:</b></i> You control Young Wolf, a 1/1 creature with undying, and it has a +1/+1 counter on it. A spell puts three -1/-1 counters on Young Wolf. Before state-based actions are performed, Young Wolf has one +1/+1 counter and three -1/-1 counters on it. After state-based actions are performed, Young Wolf is in the graveyard. When it was last on the battlefield, it had a +1/+1 counter on it, so undying will not trigger.</p>
