<p><a id="cr809.6a"><b>809.6a</b></a> Each general’s range of influence should be the minimum number that allows one general from an opposing team to begin the game within their range of influence. Each emperor’s range of influence should be the minimum number that allows two generals from opposing teams to begin the game within their range of influence. Players should be seated such that no emperor begins the game within the range of influence of another emperor.<br><b><i>Example:</b></i> In an Emperor game between two teams of four players each, the player configuration (either clockwise or counterclockwise around the table) should be: Team A general 1, Team A emperor, Team A general 2, Team A general 3, Team B general 1, Team B emperor, Team B general 2, Team B general 3. Each emperor has range of influence 3. Each general 2 has range of influence 2. Each general 1 and general 3 has range of influence 1.</p>
<p><a id="cr809.7"><b>809.7.</b></a> In the Emperor variant, a team’s resources (cards in hand, mana, and so on) are not shared. Teammates may review each other’s hands and discuss strategies at any time. Teammates can’t manipulate each other’s cards or permanents.</p>
<p><a id="cr810"><b>810. Two-Headed Giant Variant</b></a></p>
<p><a id="cr810.1"><b>810.1.</b></a> Two-Headed Giant games are played with two teams of two players each.</p>
<p><a id="cr810.2"><b>810.2.</b></a> The Two-Headed Giant variant uses the shared team turns option. (See rule <a href="#cr805.">805.</a>)</p>
<p><a id="cr810.3"><b>810.3.</b></a> Each team sits together on one side of the table. Each team decides the order in which its players sit.</p>
<p><a id="cr810.4"><b>810.4.</b></a> Each team has a shared life total, which starts at 30 life.</p>
<p><a id="cr810.5"><b>810.5.</b></a> With the exception of life total and poison counters, a team’s resources (cards in hand, mana, and so on) are not shared in the Two-Headed Giant variant. Teammates may review each other’s hands and discuss strategies at any time. Teammates can’t manipulate each other’s cards or permanents.</p>
<p><a id="cr810.6"><b>810.6.</b></a> The team who plays first skips the draw step of its first turn.</p>
<p><a id="cr810.7"><b>810.7.</b></a> The Two-Headed Giant variant uses the combat rules for the shared team turns option (see rule <a href="#cr805.10">805.10</a>). This is a change from previous rules.</p>
<p><a id="cr810.8"><b>810.8.</b></a> The Two-Headed Giant variant uses the normal rules for winning or losing the game (see rule <a href="#cr104">104</a>), with the following additions and specifications.</p>
<p><a id="cr810.8a"><b>810.8a</b></a> Players win and lose the game only as a team, not as individuals. If either player on a team loses the game, the team loses the game. If either player on a team wins the game, the entire team wins the game. If an effect says that a player can’t win the game, that player’s team can’t win the game. If an effect says that a player can’t lose the game, that player’s team can’t lose the game.<br><b><i>Example:</b></i> In a Two-Headed Giant game, a player controls Transcendence, which reads, in part, “You don’t lose the game for having 0 or less life.” If that player’s team’s life total is 0 or less, that team doesn’t lose the game.<br><b><i>Example:</b></i> In a Two-Headed Giant game, a player attempts to draw a card while there are no cards in that player’s library. That player loses the game, so that player’s entire team loses the game.<br><b><i>Example:</b></i> In a Two-Headed Giant game, a player controls Platinum Angel, which reads, “You can’t lose the game and your opponents can’t win the game.” Neither that player nor their teammate can lose the game while Platinum Angel is on the battlefield, and neither player on the opposing team can win the game.</p>
<p><a id="cr810.8b"><b>810.8b</b></a> If a player concedes, their team leaves the game immediately. That team loses the game.</p>
<p><a id="cr810.8c"><b>810.8c</b></a> If a team’s life total is 0 or less, the team loses the game. (This is a state-based action. See rule <a href="#cr704.">704.</a>)</p>
<p><a id="cr810.8d"><b>810.8d</b></a> If a team has fifteen or more poison counters, that team loses the game. (This is a state-based action. See rule <a href="#cr704.">704.</a>)</p>
<p><b>★</b> <a id="cr810.8e"><b>810.8e</b></a> If a team has fifteen or more glory counters, that team wins the game. (This is a state-based action. See rule <a href="#cr704.">704.</a>)</p>
<p><a id="cr810.9"><b>810.9.</b></a> Damage, loss of life, and gaining life happen to each player individually. The result is applied to the team’s shared life total.<br><b><i>Example:</b></i> In a Two-Headed Giant game, a player casts Flame Rift, which reads, “Flame Rift deals 4 damage to each player.” Each team is dealt a total of 8 damage.</p>
<p><a id="cr810.9a"><b>810.9a</b></a> If a cost or effect needs to know the value of an individual player’s life total, that cost or effect uses the team’s life total instead.<br><b><i>Example:</b></i> In a Two-Headed Giant game, a player on a team that has 17 life is targeted by Beacon of Immortality, which reads, in part, “Double target player’s life total.” That player gains 17 life, so the team winds up at 34 life.<br><b><i>Example:</b></i> In a Two-Headed Giant game, a player controls Test of Endurance, an enchantment that reads, “At the beginning of your upkeep, if you have 50 or more life, you win the game.” At the beginning of that player’s upkeep, the player’s team wins the game if their team’s life total is 50 or more.<br><b><i>Example:</b></i> In a Two-Headed Giant game, a player on a team that has 11 life controls Lurking Evil, an enchantment that reads, “Pay half your life, rounded up: Lurking Evil becomes a 4/4 Horror creature with flying.” To activate the ability, that player must pay 6 life. The team winds up at 5 life.</p>
<p><a id="cr810.9b"><b>810.9b</b></a> If a cost or effect allows both members of a team to pay life simultaneously, the total amount of life they pay may not exceed their team’s life total. (Players can always pay 0 life.)</p>
<p><a id="cr810.9c"><b>810.9c</b></a> If an effect sets a single player’s life total to a specific number, the player gains or loses the necessary amount of life to end up with the new total. The team’s life total is adjusted by the amount of life that player gained or lost.<br><b><i>Example:</b></i> In a Two-Headed Giant game, a player on a team that has 25 life is targeted by an ability that reads, “Target player’s life total becomes 10.” That player’s life total is considered to be 25, so that player loses 15 life. The team winds up at 10 life.</p>
<p><a id="cr810.9d"><b>810.9d</b></a> If an effect would set the life total of each player on a team to a number, that team chooses one of its members. On that team, only that player is affected.<br><b><i>Example:</b></i> In a Two-Headed Giant game, one team has 7 life and the other team has 13 life. A player casts Repay in Kind, which reads, “Each player’s life total becomes the lowest life total among all players.” Each team chooses one of its members to be affected. The result is that the chosen player on the team that has 13 life loses 6 life, so that team’s life total winds up at 7.</p>
<p><a id="cr810.9e"><b>810.9e</b></a> A player can’t exchange life totals with their teammate. If an effect would cause that to occur, the exchange won’t happen.</p>
<p><a id="cr810.9f"><b>810.9f</b></a> If an effect instructs a player to redistribute any number of players’ life totals, that player may not affect more than one member of each team this way.</p>
<p><a id="cr810.9g"><b>810.9g</b></a> If an effect says that a player can’t gain life, no player on that player’s team can gain life.</p>
<p><a id="cr810.9h"><b>810.9h</b></a> If an effect says that a player can’t lose life, no player on that player’s team can lose life or pay any amount of life other than 0.</p>
<p><a id="cr810.10"><b>810.10.</b></a> Effects that cause players to get poison counters happen to each player individually. The poison counters are shared by the team.</p>
<p><a id="cr810.10a"><b>810.10a</b></a> If an effect needs to know how many poison counters an individual player has, that effect uses the number of poison counters that player’s team has. If an effect needs to know how many poison counters a player’s opponents have, that effect uses the number of poison counters opposing teams have.</p>
<p><a id="cr810.10b"><b>810.10b</b></a> If an effect says that a player loses poison counters, that player’s team loses that many poison counters.</p>
<p><a id="cr810.10c"><b>810.10c</b></a> If an effect says that a player can’t get poison counters, no player on that player’s team can get poison counters.</p>
<p><a id="cr810.10d"><b>810.10d</b></a> If a rule or effect needs to know what kinds of counters an individual player has, that effect uses the kinds of counters that player has and the kinds of counters that player’s team has. A player is “poisoned” if that player’s team has one or more poison counters.</p>
<p><a id="cr810.11"><b>810.11.</b></a> The Two-Headed Giant variant can also be played with equally sized teams of more than two players. For each player a team has beyond the second, that team’s starting life total is increased by 15 and the number of poison counters required for the team to lose is increased by five. (These variants are called Three-Headed Giant, Four-Headed Giant, and so on.)</p>
<p><a id="cr811"><b>811. Alternating Teams Variant</b></a></p>
<p><a id="cr811.1"><b>811.1.</b></a> Alternating Teams games are played with two or more teams of equal size.</p>
<p><a id="cr811.2"><b>811.2.</b></a> Any multiplayer options used are determined before play begins. The Alternating Teams variant uses the following default options.</p>
<p><a id="cr811.2a"><b>811.2a</b></a> The recommended range of influence is 2. See rule <a href="#cr801">801</a>, “Limited Range of Influence Option.”</p>
<p><a id="cr811.2b"><b>811.2b</b></a> Exactly one of the attack left, attack right, and attack multiple players options must be used. See rule <a href="#cr803">803</a>, “Attack Left and Attack Right Options,” and rule <a href="#cr802">802</a>, “Attack Multiple Players Option.”</p>
<p><a id="cr811.2c"><b>811.2c</b></a> The deploy creatures option isn’t normally used in the Alternating Teams variant.</p>
<p><a id="cr811.3"><b>811.3.</b></a> At the start of the game, players are seated so that no one is next to a teammate and each team is equally spaced out.<br><b><i>Example:</b></i> In an Alternating Teams game with three teams, A, B, and C, the seating around the table at the start of the game is A1, B1, C1, A2, B2, C2, A3, B3, C3, and so on.</p>
<p><a id="cr811.4"><b>811.4.</b></a> A player can’t attack opponents who aren’t seated next to them.</p>
<p><a id="cr811.5"><b>811.5.</b></a> In the Alternating Teams variant, a team’s resources (cards in hand, mana, and so on) are not shared. Teammates can’t review each other’s hands unless they are sitting next to each other. Teammates may discuss strategies at any time. Teammates can’t manipulate each other’s cards or permanents.</p>
<a id="cr9"><b>9. Casual Variants</b></a><p><a id="cr900"><b>900. General</b></a></p>
<p><a id="cr900.1"><b>900.1.</b></a> This section contains additional optional rules that can be used for certain casual game variants. It is by no means comprehensive.</p>
<p><a id="cr900.2"><b>900.2.</b></a> The casual variants detailed here use supplemental zones, rules, cards, and other game implements not used in traditional Magic games.</p>
<p><a id="cr901"><b>901. Planechase</b></a></p>
<p><a id="cr901.1"><b>901.1.</b></a> In the Planechase variant, plane cards and phenomenon cards add additional abilities and randomness to the game. The Planechase variant uses all the normal rules for a Magic game, with the following additions.</p>
<p><a id="cr901.2"><b>901.2.</b></a> A Planechase game may be a two-player game or a multiplayer game. The default multiplayer setup is the Free-for-All variant with the attack multiple players option and without the limited range of influence option. See rule <a href="#cr806">806</a>, “Free-for-All Variant.”</p>
<p><a id="cr901.3"><b>901.3.</b></a> In addition to the normal game materials, each player needs a planar deck of at least ten plane and/or phenomenon cards and the game needs one planar die. No more than two cards in a planar deck can be phenomenon cards. Each card in a planar deck must have a different English name. (See rule <a href="#cr310">310</a>, “Planes,” and rule <a href="#cr311">311</a>, “Phenomena.”)</p>
<p><a id="cr901.3a"><b>901.3a</b></a> A planar die is a six-sided die. One face has the Planeswalker symbol {PW}. One face has the chaos symbol {CHAOS}. The other faces are blank.</p>
<p><a id="cr901.4"><b>901.4.</b></a> At the start of the game, each player shuffles their planar deck so that the cards are in a random order. Each deck is placed face down next to its owner’s library. All plane and phenomenon cards remain in the command zone throughout the game, both while they’re part of a planar deck and while they’re face up.</p>
<p><a id="cr901.5"><b>901.5.</b></a> Once all players have kept their opening hands and used the abilities of cards that allow them to take an action with those cards from their opening hands, the starting player moves the top card of their planar deck off that planar deck and turns it face up. If it’s a phenomenon card, the player puts that card on the bottom of their planar deck and repeats this process until a plane card is turned face up. (See rule <a href="#cr103.6">103.6</a>.) No abilities of any card turned face up this way trigger during this process. The face-up plane card becomes the starting plane.</p>
<p><a id="cr901.6"><b>901.6.</b></a> The owner of a plane or phenomenon card is the player who started the game with it in their planar deck. The controller of a face-up plane or phenomenon card is the player designated as the planar controller. Normally, the planar controller is whoever the active player is. However, if the current planar controller would leave the game, instead the next player in turn order that wouldn’t leave the game becomes the planar controller, then the old planar controller leaves the game. The new planar controller retains that designation until they leave the game or a different player becomes the active player, whichever comes first.</p>
<p><a id="cr901.7"><b>901.7.</b></a> Any abilities of a face-up plane card or phenomenon card in the command zone function from that zone. The card’s static abilities affect the game, its triggered abilities may trigger, and its activated abilities may be activated.</p>
<p><a id="cr901.7a"><b>901.7a</b></a> A face-up plane card or phenomenon card that’s turned face down becomes a new object.</p>
<p><a id="cr901.8"><b>901.8.</b></a> Planechase games have an inherent triggered ability known as the “planeswalking ability.” The full text of this ability is “Whenever you roll {PW}, planeswalk.” (See rule <a href="#cr701.24">701.24</a>, “Planeswalk.”) This ability has no source and is controlled by the player whose planar die roll caused it to trigger. This is an exception to rule <a href="#cr113.8">113.8</a>.</p>
<p><a id="cr901.9"><b>901.9.</b></a> Any time the active player has priority and the stack is empty, but only during a main phase of their turn, that player may roll the planar die. Taking this action costs a player an amount of mana equal to the number of times they have previously taken this action on that turn. This is a special action and doesn’t use the stack. Note that this number won’t be equal to the number of times the player has rolled the planar die that turn if an effect has caused the player to roll the planar die that turn. (See rule <a href="#cr116.2i">116.2i</a>.)</p>
<p><a id="cr901.9a"><b>901.9a</b></a> If the die roll is a blank face, nothing happens. The active player gets priority.</p>
<p><a id="cr901.9b"><b>901.9b</b></a> If the die roll is the chaos symbol {CHAOS}, any ability of a face-up plane that starts “When you roll {CHAOS}” triggers and is put on the stack. The active player gets priority.</p>
<p><a id="cr901.9c"><b>901.9c</b></a> If the die roll is the Planeswalker symbol {PW}, the “planeswalking ability” triggers and is put on the stack. The active player gets priority. (See rule <a href="#cr901.8">901.8</a>.)</p>
<p><a id="cr901.9d"><b>901.9d</b></a> Rolling the planar die will cause any ability that triggers whenever a player rolls one or more dice to trigger. However, any effect that refers to a numerical result of a die roll, including ones that compare the results of that roll to other rolls or to a given number, ignores the rolling of the planar die. See 706, “Rolling a Die.”</p>
<p><a id="cr901.10"><b>901.10.</b></a> When a player leaves the game, all objects owned by that player except abilities from phenomena leave the game. (See rule <a href="#cr800.4a">800.4a</a>.) If that includes a face-up plane card or phenomenon card, the planar controller turns the top card of their planar deck face up. This is not a state-based action. It happens as soon as the player leaves the game.</p>
<p><a id="cr901.10a"><b>901.10a</b></a> If a plane leaves the game while a “planeswalking ability” is on the stack, that ability ceases to exist.</p>
<p><a id="cr901.10b"><b>901.10b</b></a> Abilities from phenomena owned by a player who left the game remain on the stack controlled by the new planar controller.</p>
<p><a id="cr901.11"><b>901.11.</b></a> After the game has started, if a player moves the top card of their planar deck off that planar deck and turns it face up, that player has “planeswalked.” Continuous effects with durations that last until a player planeswalks end. Abilities that trigger when a player planeswalks trigger. See rule <a href="#cr701.24">701.24</a>.</p>
<p><a id="cr901.11a"><b>901.11a</b></a> A player may planeswalk as the result of the “planeswalking ability” (see rule <a href="#cr901.8">901.8</a>), because the owner of a face-up plane card or phenomenon card leaves the game (see rule <a href="#cr901.10">901.10</a>), or because a phenomenon’s triggered ability leaves the stack (see rule <a href="#cr704.6f">704.6f</a>). Abilities may also instruct a player to planeswalk.</p>
<p><a id="cr901.11b"><b>901.11b</b></a> The plane card that’s turned face up is the plane the player planeswalks to. The plane card or phenomenon card that’s turned face down, or that leaves the game, is the plane or phenomenon the player planeswalks away from.</p>
<p><a id="cr901.11c"><b>901.11c</b></a> If a player planeswalks when there is more than one face-up plane card, that player planeswalks away from all such planes.</p>
<p><a id="cr901.12"><b>901.12.</b></a> A Two-Headed Giant Planechase game uses all the rules for the Two-Headed Giant multiplayer variant and all the rules for the Planechase casual variant, with the following additions.</p>
<p><a id="cr901.12a"><b>901.12a</b></a> Each player has their own planar deck.</p>
<p><a id="cr901.12b"><b>901.12b</b></a> The planar controller is normally the primary player of the active team. However, if the current planar controller’s team would leave the game, instead the primary player of the next team in turn order that wouldn’t leave the game becomes the planar controller, then the old planar controller’s team leaves the game. The new planar controller retains that designation until they leave the game or a different team becomes the active team, whichever comes first.</p>
<p><a id="cr901.12c"><b>901.12c</b></a> Even though the face-up plane or phenomenon is controlled by just one player, any ability of that plane or phenomenon that refers to “you” applies to both members of the planar controller’s team.</p>
<p><a id="cr901.12d"><b>901.12d</b></a> Since each member of the active team is an active player, each of them may roll the planar die. Each player’s cost to roll the planar die is based on the number of times that particular player has already rolled the planar die that turn.</p>
<p><a id="cr901.13"><b>901.13.</b></a> In multiplayer formats other than Grand Melee, plane cards and phenomenon cards are exempt from the limited range of influence option. Their abilities, and the effects of those abilities, affect all applicable objects and players in the game. (See rule <a href="#cr801">801</a>, “Limited Range of Influence Option.”)</p>
<p><a id="cr901.14"><b>901.14.</b></a> In Grand Melee Planechase games, multiple plane cards or phenomenon cards may be face up at the same time.</p>
<p><a id="cr901.14a"><b>901.14a</b></a> Before the first turn of the game of the game, each player who will start the game with a turn marker sets a starting plane (see rule <a href="#cr901.5">901.5</a>). Each of them is a planar controller.</p>
<p><a id="cr901.14b"><b>901.14b</b></a> If a player would leave the game and that player leaving the game would reduce the number of turn markers in the game, that player first ceases to be a planar controller (but no other player becomes a planar controller), then that player leaves the game. Each face-up plane card or phenomenon card that player controlled is put on the bottom of its owner’s planar deck. No player is considered to have planeswalked.</p>
<p><a id="cr901.15"><b>901.15.</b></a> Single Planar Deck Option</p>
<p><a id="cr901.15a"><b>901.15a</b></a> As an alternative option, a Planechase game may be played with just a single communal planar deck. In that case, the number of cards in the planar deck must be at least forty or at least ten times the number of players in the game, whichever is smaller. The planar deck can’t contain more phenomenon cards than twice the number of players in the game. Each card in the planar deck must have a different English name.</p>
<p><a id="cr901.15b"><b>901.15b</b></a> In a Planechase game using the single planar deck option, the planar controller is considered to be the owner of all cards in the planar deck.</p>
<p><a id="cr901.15c"><b>901.15c</b></a> If any rule or ability refers to a player’s planar deck, the communal planar deck is used.</p>
<p><a id="cr902"><b>902. Vanguard</b></a></p>
<p><a id="cr902.1"><b>902.1.</b></a> In the Vanguard variant, a vanguard card allows each player to play the role of a famous character. Each player will have one face-up vanguard card whose abilities and other characteristics affect the game. The Vanguard variant uses all the normal rules for a Magic game, with the following additions.</p>
<p><a id="cr902.2"><b>902.2.</b></a> A Vanguard game may be a two-player game or a multiplayer game.</p>
<p><a id="cr902.3"><b>902.3.</b></a> In addition to the normal game materials, each player needs a vanguard card. Each vanguard card is placed face up next to its owner’s library before the game begins. All vanguard cards remain in the command zone throughout the game.</p>
<p><a id="cr902.4"><b>902.4.</b></a> Each player’s starting life total is 20 plus or minus the life modifier of their vanguard card.<br><b><i>Example:</b></i> The life modifier of a player’s vanguard card is -3. That player’s starting life total is 17.</p>
<p><a id="cr902.5"><b>902.5.</b></a> Each player’s starting hand size is seven cards, as modified by the hand modifier of their vanguard card.</p>
<p><a id="cr902.5a"><b>902.5a</b></a> If a player takes a mulligan in a Vanguard game, just like in a normal game, that player shuffles their hand back into their library, then draws a new hand equal to their starting hand size. (In a multiplayer game, a player’s first mulligan is for the same number of cards as they had before.) See rule <a href="#cr103.4">103.4</a>.<br><b><i>Example:</b></i> The hand modifier of a player’s vanguard card is +2. That player starts the game with a hand of 9 cards. If the player takes a mulligan three times before keeping, they draw a new hand of nine cards and put three of those on the bottom of their library.</p>
<p><a id="cr902.5b"><b>902.5b</b></a> A player’s maximum hand size is seven, as modified by the hand modifier of their vanguard card.<br><b><i>Example:</b></i> The hand modifier of a player’s vanguard card is -1. That player’s maximum hand size is six. If that player has more than six cards in their hand as their cleanup step begins, they will discard all but six of them.</p>
<p><a id="cr902.6"><b>902.6.</b></a> The owner of a vanguard card is the player who started the game with it in the command zone. The controller of a face-up vanguard card is its owner.</p>
<p><a id="cr902.7"><b>902.7.</b></a> Any abilities of a face-up vanguard card in the command zone function from that zone. The card’s static abilities affect the game, its triggered abilities may trigger, and its activated abilities may be activated.</p>
<p><a id="cr903"><b>903. Commander</b></a></p>
<p><a id="cr903.1"><b>903.1.</b></a> In the Commander variant, each deck is led by a legendary creature designated as that deck’s commander. The Commander variant was created and popularized by fans; an independent rules committee maintains additional resources at MTGCommander.net. The Commander variant uses all the normal rules for a Magic game, with the following additions.</p>
<p><a id="cr903.2"><b>903.2.</b></a> A Commander game may be a two-player game or a multiplayer game. The default multiplayer setup is the Free-for-All variant with the attack multiple players option and without the limited range of influence option. See rule <a href="#cr806">806</a>, “Free-for-All Variant.”</p>
<p><a id="cr903.3"><b>903.3.</b></a> Each deck has a legendary creature card designated as its commander. This designation is not a characteristic of the object represented by the card; rather, it is an attribute of the card itself. The card retains this designation even when it changes zones.<br><b><i>Example:</b></i> A commander that’s been turned face down (due to Ixidron’s effect, for example) is still a commander. A commander that’s copying another card (due to Cytoshape’s effect, for example) is still a commander. A permanent that’s copying a commander (such as a Body Double, for example, copying a commander in a player’s graveyard) is not a commander.</p>
<p><a id="cr903.3a"><b>903.3a</b></a> Some cards have an ability that states the card can be your commander. This ability modifies the rules for deck construction, and it functions before the game begins. See also rule <a href="#cr113.6n">113.6n</a>.</p>
<p><a id="cr903.3b"><b>903.3b</b></a> If a player’s commander is a meld card and it’s melded with the other member of its meld pair, the resulting melded permanent is that player’s commander.</p>
<p><a id="cr903.3c"><b>903.3c</b></a> If a player’s commander is a component of a merged permanent, the resulting merged permanent is that player’s commander.</p>
<p><a id="cr903.3d"><b>903.3d</b></a> If an effect refers to controlling a commander, it refers to a permanent on the battlefield that is a commander. If an effect refers to casting a commander, it refers to a spell that is a commander. If an effect refers to a commander in a specific zone, it refers to a card in that zone that is a commander.</p>
<p><a id="cr903.4"><b>903.4.</b></a> The Commander variant uses color identity to determine what cards can be in a deck with a certain commander. The color identity of a card is the color or colors of any mana symbols in that card’s mana cost or rules text, plus any colors defined by its characteristic-defining abilities (see rule <a href="#cr604.3">604.3</a>) or color indicator (see rule <a href="#cr204">204</a>).<br><b><i>Example:</b></i> Bosh, Iron Golem is a legendary artifact creature with mana cost {8} and the ability “{3}{R}, Sacrifice an artifact: Bosh, Iron Golem deals damage equal to the sacrificed artifact’s mana value to any target.” Bosh’s color identity is red.</p>
<p><a id="cr903.4a"><b>903.4a</b></a> Color identity is established before the game begins.</p>
<p><a id="cr903.4b"><b>903.4b</b></a> If a commander has a static ability that causes a player to choose its color before the game begins, that choice applies during deck construction and throughout the game, even as the commander changes zones. That choice affects the commander’s color identity. The player reveals that choice as they put their commander into the command zone before the game begins. See rules <a href="#cr103.2c">103.2c</a> and <a href="#cr607.2p">607.2p</a>.</p>
<p><a id="cr903.4c"><b>903.4c</b></a> Reminder text is ignored when determining a card’s color identity. See rule <a href="#cr207.2">207.2</a>.</p>
<p><a id="cr903.4d"><b>903.4d</b></a> The back face of a double-faced card (see rule <a href="#cr712">712</a>) is included when determining a card’s color identity. This is an exception to rule <a href="#cr712.4a">712.4a</a>.<br><b><i>Example:</b></i> Civilized Scholar is the front face of a double-faced card with mana cost {2}{U}. Homicidal Brute is the back face of that double-faced card and has a red color indicator. The card’s color identity is blue and red.</p>
<p><a id="cr903.4e"><b>903.4e</b></a> If an ability refers to the colors or number of colors in a commander’s color identity, that quality is undefined if that player doesn’t have a commander. That part of the ability won’t do anything. Costs that refer to that quality are unpayable.</p>
<p><a id="cr903.5"><b>903.5.</b></a> Each Commander deck is subject to the following deck construction rules.</p>
<p><a id="cr903.5a"><b>903.5a</b></a> Each deck must contain exactly 100 cards, including its commander. In other words, the minimum deck size and the maximum deck size are both 100.</p>
<p><a id="cr903.5b"><b>903.5b</b></a> Other than basic lands, each card in a Commander deck must have a different English name. For the purposes of deck construction, cards with interchangeable names have the same English name (see rule <a href="#cr201.3">201.3</a>).</p>
<p><a id="cr903.5c"><b>903.5c</b></a> A card can be included in a Commander deck only if every color in its color identity is also found in the color identity of the deck’s commander.<br><b><i>Example:</b></i> Wort, the Raidmother is a legendary creature with mana cost {4}{R/G}{R/G}. Wort’s color identity is red and green. Each card in a Wort Commander deck must be only red, only green, both red and green, or have no color. Each mana symbol in the mana cost or rules text of a card in this deck must be only red, only green, both red and green, or have no color.</p>
<p><a id="cr903.5d"><b>903.5d</b></a> A card with a basic land type may be included in a Commander deck only if each color of mana it could produce is included in the commander’s color identity.<br><b><i>Example:</b></i> Wort, the Raidmother’s color identity is red and green. A Wort Commander deck may include land cards with the basic land types Mountain and/or Forest. It can’t include any land cards with the basic land types Plains, Island, or Swamp.</p>
<p><a id="cr903.6"><b>903.6.</b></a> At the start of the game, each player puts their commander from their deck face up into the command zone. Then each player shuffles the remaining 99 cards of their deck so that the cards are in a random order. Those cards become the player’s library.</p>
<p><a id="cr903.7"><b>903.7.</b></a> Once the starting player has been determined, each player sets their life total to 40 and draws a hand of seven cards.</p>
<p><a id="cr903.8"><b>903.8.</b></a> A player may cast a commander they own from the command zone. A commander cast from the command zone costs an additional {2} for each previous time the player casting it has cast it from the command zone that game. This additional cost is informally known as the “commander tax.”</p>
<p><a id="cr903.9"><b>903.9.</b></a> A commander may return to the command zone during a Commander game.</p>
<p><a id="cr903.9a"><b>903.9a</b></a> If a commander is in a graveyard or in exile and that object was put into that zone since the last time state-based actions were checked, its owner may put it into the command zone. This is a state-based action. See rule <a href="#cr704.">704.</a></p>
<p><a id="cr903.9b"><b>903.9b</b></a> If a commander would be put into its owner’s hand or library from anywhere, its owner may put it into the command zone instead. This replacement effect may apply more than once to the same event. This is an exception to rule <a href="#cr614.5">614.5</a>.</p>
<p><a id="cr903.9c"><b>903.9c</b></a> If a commander is a melded permanent or a merged permanent and its owner chooses to put it into the command zone using the replacement effect described in rule <a href="#cr903.9b">903.9b</a>, that permanent and each component representing it that isn’t a commander are put into the appropriate zone, and the card that represents it and is a commander is put into the command zone.</p>
<p><a id="cr903.10"><b>903.10.</b></a> The Commander variant includes the following specification for winning and losing the game. All other rules for ending the game also apply. (See rule <a href="#cr104.">104.</a>)</p>
<p><a id="cr903.10a"><b>903.10a</b></a> A player who’s been dealt 21 or more combat damage by the same commander over the course of the game loses the game. (This is a state-based action. See rule <a href="#cr704.">704.</a>)</p>
<p><a id="cr903.11"><b>903.11.</b></a> If a player is allowed to bring a card from outside the game into a Commander game, that player can’t bring a card into the game this way if it has the same name as a card that player had in their starting deck, if it has the same name as a card that the player owns in the current game, or if any color in its color identity isn’t in the color identity of the player’s commander.</p>
<p><a id="cr903.12"><b>903.12.</b></a> Brawl Option</p>
<p><a id="cr903.12a"><b>903.12a</b></a> Brawl is an option for a different style of Commander game. Brawl games use the normal rules for the Commander variant with the following modifications.</p>
<p><a id="cr903.12b"><b>903.12b</b></a> Brawl decks are usually constructed using cards from the Standard format.</p>
<p><a id="cr903.12c"><b>903.12c</b></a> A player designates either a legendary planeswalker or a legendary creature as their commander.</p>
<p><a id="cr903.12d"><b>903.12d</b></a> A player’s deck must contain exactly 60 cards, including its commander. In other words, the minimum deck size and the maximum deck size are both 60.</p>
<p><a id="cr903.12e"><b>903.12e</b></a> If a player’s commander has no colors in its color identity, that player’s deck may contain any number of basic lands of one basic land type of their choice. This is an exception to rule <a href="#cr903.5d">903.5d</a>.</p>
<p><a id="cr903.12f"><b>903.12f</b></a> In a two-player Brawl game, each player’s starting life total is 25. In a multiplayer Brawl game, each player’s starting life total is 30.</p>
<p><a id="cr903.12g"><b>903.12g</b></a> In any Brawl game, the first mulligan a player takes doesn’t count toward the number of cards that player will put on the bottom of their library or the number of mulligans that player may take. Subsequent mulligans are counted toward these numbers as normal.</p>
<p><a id="cr903.12h"><b>903.12h</b></a> Brawl games do not use the state-based action described in rule <a href="#cr704.6c">704.6c</a>, which causes a player to lose the game if they’ve been dealt 21 or more combat damage by a commander.</p>
<p><a id="cr903.13"><b>903.13.</b></a> Commander Draft</p>
<p><a id="cr903.13a"><b>903.13a</b></a> Commander Draft is an option for a different style of Commander game. It consists of a draft (a style of limited play where players choose cards from sealed booster packs to build their decks) followed by a multiplayer game. The Commander Draft option uses Commander Legends booster packs by default.</p>
<p><a id="cr903.13b"><b>903.13b</b></a> A draft typically consists of three draft rounds. In each draft round, each player opens a booster pack, drafts two cards by placing them in a face-down pile in front of them, then passes the remaining cards to the next player. Each player then drafts two cards from the booster pack passed to them and passes the remaining cards. This procedure continues until all cards in that draft round have been drafted.</p>
<p><a id="cr903.13c"><b>903.13c</b></a> In the first and third draft rounds, booster packs are passed to each player’s left. In the second draft round, booster packs are passed to each player’s right.</p>
<p><a id="cr903.13d"><b>903.13d</b></a> During the draft, a player can look only at cards in the booster pack they are currently drafting from and cards they have already drafted. A player may not reveal drafted cards to other players unless an ability instructs them to.</p>
<p><a id="cr903.13e"><b>903.13e</b></a> After the draft is complete, the cards a player drafted become that player’s card pool. A player may add up to two cards named The Prismatic Piper to their card pool, but only if those cards are used as the player’s commander(s).</p>
<p><a id="cr903.13f"><b>903.13f</b></a> Commander Draft deck construction follows the same rules as Commander deck construction (see rule <a href="#cr903.5">903.5</a>) with two exceptions: (1) A player’s deck must contain at least 60 cards. There is no maximum deck size. (2) A player’s deck may include any number of cards from that player’s card pool with the same name.</p>
<p><a id="cr903.13g"><b>903.13g</b></a> Commander Draft games follow the same rules as Commander games. See rules <a href="#cr903.6">903.6</a>–903.11.</p>
<p><a id="cr904"><b>904. Archenemy</b></a></p>
<p><a id="cr904.1"><b>904.1.</b></a> In the Archenemy variant, a team of players faces off against a single opponent strengthened with powerful scheme cards. The Archenemy variant uses all the normal rules for a Magic game, with the following additions.</p>
<p><a id="cr904.2"><b>904.2.</b></a> The default setup for an Archenemy game is the Team vs. Team multiplayer variant (see rule <a href="#cr808">808</a>) involving exactly two teams. The attack multiple players option (see rule <a href="#cr802">802</a>) and the shared team turns option (see rule <a href="#cr805">805</a>) are used; no other multiplayer options are used.</p>
<p><a id="cr904.2a"><b>904.2a</b></a> One of the teams consists of exactly one player, who is designated the archenemy.</p>
<p><a id="cr904.2b"><b>904.2b</b></a> The other team consists of any number of players.</p>
<p><a id="cr904.3"><b>904.3.</b></a> In addition to the normal game materials, the archenemy needs a scheme deck of at least twenty scheme cards. A scheme deck may contain no more than two of any card with a particular English name. (See rule <a href="#cr313">313</a>, “Schemes.”)</p>
<p><a id="cr904.4"><b>904.4.</b></a> At the start of the game, the archenemy shuffles their scheme deck so that the cards are in a random order. The scheme deck is placed face down next to the archenemy’s library. All scheme cards remain in the command zone throughout the game, both while they’re part of a scheme deck and while they’re face up.</p>
<p><a id="cr904.5"><b>904.5.</b></a> The archenemy’s starting life total is 40. Each other player’s starting life total is 20.</p>
<p><a id="cr904.6"><b>904.6.</b></a> Rather than a randomly determined player, the archenemy takes the first turn of the game.</p>
<p><a id="cr904.7"><b>904.7.</b></a> The owner of a scheme card is the player who started the game with it in the command zone. The controller of a face-up scheme card is its owner.</p>
<p><a id="cr904.8"><b>904.8.</b></a> Any abilities of a face-up scheme card in the command zone function from that zone. The card’s static abilities affect the game, its triggered abilities may trigger, and its activated abilities may be activated.</p>
<p><a id="cr904.9"><b>904.9.</b></a> Immediately after the archenemy’s precombat main phase begins during each of their turns, that player moves the top card of their scheme deck off that scheme deck and turns it face up. This is called “setting that scheme in motion.” (See rule <a href="#cr701.25">701.25</a>.) This turn-based action doesn’t use the stack. Abilities of that scheme card that trigger “When you set this scheme in motion” trigger.</p>
<p><a id="cr904.10"><b>904.10.</b></a> If a non-ongoing scheme card is face up in the command zone, and no triggered abilities of any scheme are on the stack or waiting to be put on the stack, that scheme card is turned face down and put on the bottom of its owner’s scheme deck the next time a player would receive priority. (This is a state-based action. See rule <a href="#cr704.">704.</a>)</p>
<p><a id="cr904.11"><b>904.11.</b></a> Once an ongoing scheme card is set in motion, it remains face up in the command zone until an ability causes it to be abandoned (see rule <a href="#cr701.26">701.26</a>).</p>
<p><a id="cr904.12"><b>904.12.</b></a> Supervillain Rumble Option</p>
<p><a id="cr904.12a"><b>904.12a</b></a> As an alternative option, players may play a Free-for-All game in which each player has their own scheme deck. The attack multiple players option (see rule <a href="#cr802">802</a>) is used; no other multiplayer options are used.</p>
<p><a id="cr904.12b"><b>904.12b</b></a> Each player in this game is an archenemy.</p>
<p><a id="cr904.12c"><b>904.12c</b></a> As in a normal Free-for-All game, the starting player is randomly determined. All other rules that apply to the archenemy in an Archenemy game apply to each player in a Supervillain Rumble game.</p>
<p><a id="cr905"><b>905. Conspiracy Draft</b></a></p>
<p><a id="cr905.1"><b>905.1.</b></a> The Conspiracy Draft variant consists of a draft (a style of limited play where players choose cards from sealed booster packs to build their decks) followed by a multiplayer game. The Conspiracy Draft variant uses Magic: The Gathering—Conspiracy™ and/or Conspiracy: Take the Crown™ booster packs by default.</p>
<p><a id="cr905.1a"><b>905.1a</b></a> A draft typically consists of three draft rounds. In each draft round, each player opens a booster pack, drafts one card by placing that card in a face-down pile in front of the player, then passes the remaining cards to the next player. Each player then drafts a card from the booster pack passed to them and passes the remaining cards. This procedure continues until all cards in that draft round have been drafted.</p>
<p><a id="cr905.1b"><b>905.1b</b></a> In the first and third draft rounds, booster packs are passed to each player’s left. In the second draft round, booster packs are passed to each player’s right.</p>
<p><a id="cr905.1c"><b>905.1c</b></a> During the draft, a player can look only at cards in the booster pack they are currently drafting from, cards they have already drafted, cards that are currently revealed as described in rule <a href="#cr905.2b">905.2b</a>, and cards that have been drafted face up as described in rule <a href="#cr905.2c">905.2c</a>. A player may not reveal drafted cards to other players unless an ability instructs them to.</p>
<p><a id="cr905.1d"><b>905.1d</b></a> After the draft and all actions that may be taken during or after the draft, all the cards a player has drafted become that player’s card pool. The player builds their deck from only these cards and any number of basic land cards. See rules <a href="#cr100.2b">100.2b</a> and <a href="#cr100.4b">100.4b</a>.</p>
<p><a id="cr905.2"><b>905.2.</b></a> Some cards have abilities that function during the draft.</p>
<p><a id="cr905.2a"><b>905.2a</b></a> During a draft, there is no active player or system of priority. If multiple players wish to take an action at the same time during the draft and can’t agree on an order, those actions are taken in a random order.</p>
<p><a id="cr905.2b"><b>905.2b</b></a> Some cards instruct players to reveal them as they’re drafted and then note some information, such as a number or color. This information can be referred to by other abilities during the game. Any player can look at this information at any time during the draft or game. After the information is noted, the drafted card is turned face down and added to the player’s drafted cards pile.</p>
<p><a id="cr905.2c"><b>905.2c</b></a> Some cards instruct players to draft them face up. Each such card remains face up until the draft is complete, an effect instructs the person who drafted it to turn it face down, or the card leaves that player’s drafted cards pile. While the card is face up, all players may look at it.</p>
<p><a id="cr905.3"><b>905.3.</b></a> A Conspiracy Draft game is a multiplayer game. The default multiplayer setup is the Free-for-All variant with the attack multiple players option and without the limited range of influence option. See rule <a href="#cr806">806</a>, “Free-for-All Variant.”</p>
<p><a id="cr905.4"><b>905.4.</b></a> At the start of the game, before decks are shuffled, each player may put any number of conspiracy cards from their sideboard into the command zone.</p>
<p><a id="cr905.4a"><b>905.4a</b></a> Conspiracy cards with hidden agenda are put into the command zone face down. Any time a player has priority, they may turn a face-down conspiracy card they control face up. See rule <a href="#cr702.106">702.106</a>, “Hidden Agenda.”</p>
<p><a id="cr905.5"><b>905.5.</b></a> The owner of a conspiracy card is the player who put it into the command zone at the start of the game. The controller of a conspiracy card is its owner.</p>
<p><a id="cr905.6"><b>905.6.</b></a> Once the starting player has been determined, each player sets their life total to 20 and draws a hand of seven cards.</p>
<a id="glossary">Glossary</a><br>
<b><a id="glosAPNAP Order">APNAP Order</a></b><br>
See <a href="#glosActive Player Nonactive Player Order">Active Player, Nonactive Player Order</a>.<br>
<br><b><a id="glosAbandon">Abandon</a></b><br>
To turn a face-up ongoing scheme card face down and put it on the bottom of its owner’s scheme deck. See rule <a href="#cr701.26">701.26</a>, “Abandon.”<br>
<br><b><a id="glosAbility">Ability</a></b><br>
1. Text on an object that explains what that object does or can do.<br>2. An activated or triggered ability on the stack. This kind of ability is an object.<br>See rule <a href="#cr113">113</a>, “Abilities,” and <a href="#cr6">section 6</a>, “Spells, Abilities, and Effects.”<br>
<br><b><a id="glosAbility Word">Ability Word</a></b><br>
An italicized word with no rules meaning that ties together abilities on different cards that have similar functionality. See rule <a href="#cr207.2c">207.2c</a>.<br>
<br><b><a id="glosAbound">Abound</a></b><br>
A keyword action that allows a player to cast a spell without paying its mana cost if it costs less than the abounding source. See rule <a href="#cr701.57">701.57</a>, “Abound.”<br>
<br><b><a id="glosAbsorb">Absorb</a></b><br>
A keyword ability that prevents damage. See rule <a href="#cr702.64">702.64</a>, “Absorb.”<br>
<br><b><a id="glosActivate">Activate</a></b><br>
To put an activated ability onto the stack and pay its costs, so that it will eventually resolve and have its effect. See rule <a href="#cr602">602</a>, “Activating Activated Abilities.”<br>
<br><b><a id="glosActivated Ability">Activated Ability</a></b><br>
A kind of ability. Activated abilities are written as “[Cost]: [Effect.] [Activation instructions (if any).]” See rule <a href="#cr113">113</a>, “Abilities,” and rule <a href="#cr602">602</a>, “Activating Activated Abilities.”<br>
<br><b><a id="glosActivation Cost">Activation Cost</a></b><br>
Everything that appears before the colon in an activated ability’s text. It must be paid to activate the ability. See rule <a href="#cr118">118</a>, “Costs,” and rule <a href="#cr602">602</a>, “Activating Activated Abilities.”<br>
<br><b><a id="glosActive Player">Active Player</a></b><br>
The player whose turn it is. See rule <a href="#cr102.1">102.1</a>.<br>
<br><b><a id="glosActive Player Nonactive Player Order">Active Player Nonactive Player Order</a></b><br>
A system that determines the order by which players make choices if multiple players are instructed to make choices at the same time. See rule <a href="#cr101.4">101.4</a>. This rule is modified for games using the shared team turns option; see rule <a href="#cr805.6">805.6</a>.<br>
<br><b><a id="glosActive Team">Active Team</a></b><br>
The team whose turn it is in a game using the shared team turns option. See rule <a href="#cr805.4a">805.4a</a>.<br>
<br><b><a id="glosAdapt">Adapt</a></b><br>
A keyword action that puts +1/+1 counters on a creature that doesn’t have any yet. See rule <a href="#cr701.43">701.43</a>, “Adapt.”<br>
<br><b><a id="glosAdditional Cost">Additional Cost</a></b><br>
A cost a spell may have that its controller may pay (or, in some cases, must pay) in addition to its mana cost to cast that spell. See rule <a href="#cr118">118</a>, “Costs,” and rule <a href="#cr601">601</a>, “Casting Spells.”<br>
<br><b><a id="glosAdditional library">Additional library, Archive</a></b><br>
A keyword ability that creates additional libraries. See rule <a href="#cr702.155">702.155</a>, “Archive” and rule <a href="#cr727">727</a>, “Additional Libraries.”<br>
<br><b><a id="glosAdjudicate">Adjudicate</a></b><br>
A keyword action that creates an Aura enchantment token with enchant creature and “Sacrifice this Aura: Untap enchanted creature.” See rule <a href="#cr701.48">701.48</a>, “Adjudicate.”<br>
<br><b><a id="glosAdventurer Card">Adventurer Card</a></b><br>
Cards with a two-part card frame (one part of which is inset on the left) on a single card. See rule <a href="#cr716">716</a>, “Adventurer Cards.”<br>Affinity<br>A keyword ability that reduces how much mana you need to spend to cast a spell. See rule <a href="#cr702.41">702.41</a>, “Affinity.”<br>
<br><b><a id="glosAetherize">Aetherize</a></b><br>
A keyword action that creates a token copy of an object, then immediately exiles the token. See rule <a href="#cr701.64">701.64</a>, “Aetherize.”<br>
<br><b><a id="glosAfflict">Afflict</a></b><br>
A keyword ability that makes the defending player lose life for blocking. See rule <a href="#cr702.130">702.130</a>, “Afflict.”<br>
<br><b><a id="glosAfterlife">Afterlife</a></b><br>
A keyword ability that leaves behind Spirit creature tokens when certain creatures die. See rule <a href="#cr702.135">702.135</a>, “Afterlife.”<br>
<br><b><a id="glosAftermath">Aftermath</a></b><br>
A keyword ability that lets a player cast one half of a split card only from their graveyard. See rule <a href="#cr702.127">702.127</a>, “Aftermath.”<br>
<br><b><a id="glosAlign">Align</a></b><br>
A keyword ability that allows a player to choose a certain value of modes. See rule C702.213, “Align.”<br>
<br><b><a id="glosAlpha">Alpha</a></b><br>
A keyword ability that allows one creature to become larger for a cost. See rule <a href="#cr702.154">702.154</a>, “Alpha.”<br>
<br><b><a id="glosAlternate Name">Alternate Name</a></b><br>
A different name used on promotional or alternate-art versions of some cards. This name has no rules meaning. See rule <a href="#cr201.6">201.6</a>.<br>
<br><b><a id="glosAlternating Teams Variant">Alternating Teams Variant</a></b><br>
A multiplayer variant played among two or more teams of equal size. See rule <a href="#cr811">811</a>, “Alternating Teams Variant.”<br>
<br><b><a id="glosAlternative Cost">Alternative Cost</a></b><br>
A cost a spell may have that its controller can pay rather than paying its mana cost. See rule <a href="#cr118">118</a>, “Costs,” and rule <a href="#cr601">601</a>, “Casting Spells.”<br>
<br><b><a id="glosAmass">Amass</a></b><br>
A keyword action than gives you a Zombie Army creature token or grows an Army you already have. See rule <a href="#cr701.44">701.44</a>, “Amass.”<br>
<br><b><a id="glosAmplify">Amplify</a></b><br>
A keyword ability than can have a creature enter the battlefield with +1/+1 counters on it. See rule <a href="#cr702.38">702.38</a>, “Amplify.”<br>
<br><b><a id="glosAnchor Word">Anchor Word</a></b><br>
A word that precedes one of two abilities a permanent may enter the battlefield with. See rule <a href="#cr614.12b">614.12b</a>.<br>
<br><b><a id="glosAnimus">Animus</a></b><br>
A land subtype. Animus can become land creatures. See rule <a href="#cr305.10">305.10</a>, “Animus.”<br>
<br><b><a id="glosAnnihilator">Annihilator</a></b><br>
A keyword ability that can make a creature particularly brutal when it attacks. See rule <a href="#cr702.86">702.86</a>, “Annihilator.”<br>
<br><b><a id="glosAnte">Ante</a></b><br>
1. A zone used only when playing “for keeps.”<br>2. To put a card into the ante zone.<br>See rule <a href="#cr407">407</a>, “Ante.”<br>
<br><b><a id="glosAny Target">Any Target</a></b><br>
A spell or ability may require “any target.” “Any target” is the same as “target creature, player, or planeswalker.” See rule <a href="#cr115.4">115.4</a>.<br>
<br><b><a id="glosAquiesce">Aquiesce</a></b><br>
A keyword abilty that allows a spell to be cast a second time after a creature deals combat damage to a player. See rule C702.216.<br>
<br><b><a id="glosArchenemy">Archenemy</a></b><br>
1. A casual variant in which a team of players faces off against a single opponent strengthened with powerful scheme cards. See rule <a href="#cr904">904</a>, “Archenemy.”<br>2. A player in an Archenemy game who is playing with a scheme deck.<br>
<br>
<b><a id="glosArm">Arm</a></b><br>
A keyword action that creates an Equipment artifact token with equip {2} and “Equipped creature gets +1/+0.” See rule <a href="#cr701.55">701.55</a>, “Arm.”<br>
<br><b><a id="glosArtifact">Artifact</a></b><br>
A card type. An artifact is a permanent. See rule <a href="#cr301">301</a>, “Artifacts.”<br>
<br><b><a id="glosArtifact Creature">Artifact Creature</a></b><br>
A combination of artifact and creature that’s subject to the rules for both. See rule <a href="#cr301">301</a>, “Artifacts,” and rule <a href="#cr302">302</a>, “Creatures.”<br>
<br><b><a id="glosArtifact Land">Artifact Land</a></b><br>
A combination of artifact and land that’s subject to the rules for both. Artifact lands can only be played as lands, not cast as spells. See rule <a href="#cr301">301</a>, “Artifacts,” and rule <a href="#cr305">305</a>, “Lands.”<br>
<br><b><a id="glosArtifact Type">Artifact Type</a></b><br>
A subtype that’s correlated to the artifact card type. See rule <a href="#cr301">301</a>, “Artifacts.” See rule <a href="#cr205.3g">205.3g</a> for the list of artifact types.<br>
<br><b><a id="glosAs Though">As Though</a></b><br>
Text used to indicate that the game, for some specific purpose, treats a condition as true even though it’s not. See rule <a href="#cr609.4">609.4</a>.<br>
<br><b><a id="glosAscend">Ascend</a></b><br>
A keyword ability that allows a creature to be exiled and return to the battlefield transformed. See rule C702.214, “Ascend.”<br>
<br><b><a id="glosAssault">Assault</a></b><br>
A keyword ability that allows +1/+1 counters to be put on a creature when it attacks once. See rule <a href="#cr702.204">702.204</a>, “Assault.”<br>
<br><b><a id="glosAssemble">Assemble</a></b><br>
Assemble is a keyword action in the Unstable set that puts Contraptions onto the battlefield. Cards and mechanics from the Unstable set aren’t included in these rules.<br>
<br><b><a id="glosAssign Combat Damage">Assign Combat Damage</a></b><br>
To determine how an attacking or blocking creature will deal its combat damage. See rule <a href="#cr510">510</a>, “Combat Damage Step.”<br>
<br><b><a id="glosAssist">Assist</a></b><br>
A keyword ability that lets another player help you pay for a spell. See rule <a href="#cr702.132">702.132</a>, “Assist.”<br>
<br><b><a id="glosAt End of Turn (Obsolete)">At End of Turn (Obsolete)</a></b><br>
A trigger condition printed on abilities that triggered at the beginning of the end step (which is not the last thing to happen in the turn). Cards that were printed with that text have received errata in the Oracle card reference to say “at the beginning of the end step” or “at the beginning of the next end step.” See rule <a href="#cr513">513</a>, “End Step.”<br>
<br><b><a id="glosAttach">Attach</a></b><br>
To move an Aura, Equipment, or Fortification onto another object or player. See rule <a href="#cr701.3">701.3</a>, “Attach.”<br>
<br><b><a id="glosAttack">Attack</a></b><br>
To send a creature into combat offensively. A creature can attack a player or a planeswalker. See rule <a href="#cr508">508</a>, “Declare Attackers Step.”<br>
<br><b><a id="glosAttack Alone">Attack Alone</a></b><br>
A creature “attacks alone” if it’s the only creature declared as an attacker during the declare attackers step. A creature “is attacking alone” if it’s attacking but no other creatures are. See rule <a href="#cr506.5">506.5</a>.<br>
<br><b><a id="glosAttack Left Option">Attack Left Option, Attack Right Option</a></b><br>
An option that may be used in certain multiplayer variants. See rule <a href="#cr803">803</a>, “Attack Left and Attack Right Options.”<br>
<br><b><a id="glosAttack Multiple Players Option">Attack Multiple Players Option</a></b><br>
An option that may be used in certain multiplayer variants. See rule <a href="#cr802">802</a>, “Attack Multiple Players Option.”<br>
<br>
<b><a id="glosAttacking Creature">Attacking Creature</a></b><br>
A creature that has either been declared as part of a legal attack during the combat phase (once all costs to attack, if any, have been paid), or a creature that has been put onto the battlefield attacking. It remains an attacking creature until it’s removed from combat or the combat phase ends, whichever comes first. See rule <a href="#cr508">508</a>, “Declare Attackers Step.”<br>
<br><b><a id="glosAttacking Team">Attacking Team</a></b><br>
The team who can attack during the combat phase of a multiplayer game using the shared team turns option. See rule <a href="#cr805">805</a>, “Shared Team Turns Option.”<br>
<br><b><a id="glosAttacks and Isn’t Blocked">Attacks and Isn’t Blocked</a></b><br>
An ability that triggers when a creature “attacks and isn’t blocked” triggers when the creature becomes an unblocked attacking creature. See rule <a href="#cr509.1h">509.1h</a>.<br>
<br><b><a id="glosAura">Aura</a></b><br>
An enchantment subtype. Aura spells target objects or players, and Aura permanents are attached to objects or players. See rule <a href="#cr303">303</a>, “Enchantments,” and rule <a href="#cr702.5">702.5</a>, “Enchant.”<br>
<br><b><a id="glosAura Swap">Aura Swap</a></b><br>
A keyword ability that lets you exchange an Aura on the battlefield with one in your hand. See rule <a href="#cr702.65">702.65</a>, “Aura Swap.”<br>
<br><b><a id="glosAutocrat">Autocrat</a></b><br>
A keyword action that puts +1/+1 counters on a creature and makes it an autocrat. See rule C701.78 “Autocrat.”<br>
<br><b><a id="glosAwaken">Awaken</a></b><br>
A keyword ability that lets you turn a land you control into a creature. See rule <a href="#cr702.113">702.113</a>, “Awaken.”<br>
<br><b><a id="glosBanding">Banding, Bands with Other</a></b><br>
Banding is a keyword ability that modifies the rules for declaring attackers and assigning combat damage. “Bands with other” is a specialized version of the ability. See rule <a href="#cr702.22">702.22</a>, “Banding.”<br>
<br>
<b><a id="glosBase Power">Base Power, Base Toughness</a></b><br>
Effects that change the base power and/or base toughness of a creature set one or both of those values to a specific number. See rule <a href="#cr613">613</a>, “Interaction of Continuous Effects.”<br>
<br>
<b><a id="glosBasic">Basic</a></b><br>
A supertype that’s normally relevant on lands. Any land with this supertype is a basic land. See rule <a href="#cr205.4">205.4</a>, “Supertypes.”<br>
<br><b><a id="glosBasic Land Type">Basic Land Type</a></b><br>
There are five “basic land types”: Plains, Island, Swamp, Mountain, and Forest. Each one has a mana ability associated with it. See rule <a href="#cr305">305</a>, “Lands.”<br>
<br><b><a id="glosBasic Landcycling">Basic Landcycling, Forestcycling, Islandcycling, Mountaincycling, Plainscycling, Slivercycling, Swampcycling, Wizardcycling</a></b><br>
See <a href="#glosTypecycling">Typecycling</a>.<br>
<br><b><a id="glosBattle Cry">Battle Cry</a></b><br>
A keyword ability that makes other attacking creatures better in combat. See rule <a href="#cr702.91">702.91</a>, “Battle Cry.”<br>
<br><b><a id="glosBattlefield">Battlefield</a></b><br>
A zone. The battlefield is the zone in which permanents exist. It used to be known as the “in-play” zone. See rule <a href="#cr403">403</a>, “Battlefield.”<br>
<br><b><a id="glosBeckon">Beckon</a></b><br>
A keyword ability of Deities that allows them to become a creature. See rule <a href="#cr702.209">702.209</a>, “Beckon.”<br>
<br><b><a id="glosBecomes">Becomes</a></b><br>
A word used in some trigger events to indicate a change in status or characteristics. See rule <a href="#cr603.2f">603.2f</a>.<br>
<br><b><a id="glosBeginning Phase">Beginning Phase</a></b><br>
Part of the turn. This phase is the first phase of the turn. See rule <a href="#cr501">501</a>, “Beginning Phase.”<br>
<br><b><a id="glosBeginning of Combat Step">Beginning of Combat Step</a></b><br>
Part of the turn. This step is the first step of the combat phase. See rule <a href="#cr507">507</a>, “Beginning of Combat Step.”<br>
<br><b><a id="glosBestow">Bestow</a></b><br>
A keyword ability that lets a creature card be cast as an Aura. See rule <a href="#cr702.103">702.103</a>, “Bestow.”<br>
<br><b><a id="glosBlitz">Blitz</a></b><br>
A keyword ability found on creature cards that allows them to be cast for an alternative cost. See rule <a href="#cr702.152">702.152</a>, “Blitz.”<br>
<br><b><a id="glosBlock">Block</a></b><br>
To send a creature into combat defensively. A creature can block an attacking creature. See rule <a href="#cr509">509</a>, “Declare Blockers Step.”<br>
<br><b><a id="glosBlock Alone">Block Alone</a></b><br>
A creature “blocks alone” if it’s the only creature declared as a blocker during the declare blockers step. A creature “is blocking alone” if it’s blocking but no other creatures are. See rule <a href="#cr506.5">506.5</a>.<br>
<br><b><a id="glosBlocked Creature">Blocked Creature</a></b><br>
An attacking creature that another creature blocks or that an effect causes to become blocked. It remains a blocked creature until it’s removed from combat, an effect says that it becomes unblocked, or the combat phase ends, whichever comes first. See rule <a href="#cr509">509</a>, “Declare Blockers Step.”<br>
<br><b><a id="glosBlocking Creature">Blocking Creature</a></b><br>
A creature that has either been declared as part of a legal block during the combat phase (once all costs to block, if any, have been paid), or a creature that has been put onto the battlefield blocking. It remains a blocking creature until it’s removed from combat or the combat phase ends, whichever comes first. See rule <a href="#cr509">509</a>, “Declare Blockers Step.”<br>
<br><b><a id="glosBlood Token">Blood Token</a></b><br>
A Blood token is a colorless artifact token with “{1}, {T}, Discard a card, Sacrifice this artifact: Draw a card.” For more information about predefined tokens, see rule <a href="#cr111.10">111.10</a>.<br>
<br><b><a id="glosBloodprice">Bloodprice</a></b><br>
A keyword ability that allows certain spells to be cast for an alternative cost by sacrificing a creature. See rule <a href="#cr702.157">702.157</a>, “Bloodprice.”<br>
<br><b><a id="glosBloodthirst">Bloodthirst</a></b><br>
A keyword ability that can have a creature enter the battlefield with +1/+1 counters on it. See rule <a href="#cr702.54">702.54</a>, “Bloodthirst.”<br>
<br><b><a id="glosBoast">Boast</a></b><br>
A special kind of activated ability that can be activated only once each turn if the creature with the boast ability attacked that turn. See rule <a href="#cr702.142">702.142</a>, “Boast.”<br>
<br><b><a id="glosBolster">Bolster</a></b><br>
A keyword action that puts +1/+1 counters on the weakest creature a player controls. See rule <a href="#cr701.33">701.33</a>, “Bolster.”<br>
<br><b><a id="glosBooster Pack">Booster Pack</a></b><br>
A group of unopened Magic cards from a particular expansion. Booster packs are used in Limited formats. See rule <a href="#cr100.2b">100.2b</a>.<br>
<br><b><a id="glosBrawl">Brawl</a></b><br>
An option for the Commander casual variant. See rule <a href="#cr903.12">903.12</a>, “Brawl Option.”<br>
<br><b><a id="glosBury (Obsolete)">Bury (Obsolete)</a></b><br>
A term that meant “put [a permanent] into its owner’s graveyard.” In general, cards that were printed with the term “bury” have received errata in the Oracle card reference to read, “Destroy [a permanent]. It can’t be regenerated,” or “Sacrifice [a permanent].”<br>
<br><b><a id="glosBushido">Bushido</a></b><br>
A keyword ability that can make a creature better in combat. See rule <a href="#cr702.45">702.45</a>, “Bushido.”<br>
<br><b><a id="glosBuyback">Buyback</a></b><br>
A keyword ability of instants and sorceries that can let the spell return to its owner’s hand as it resolves. See rule <a href="#cr702.27">702.27</a>, “Buyback.”<br>
<br><b><a id="glosCackle">Cackle</a></b><br>
A keyword action that causes the cackling creature to get a menace counter or deal 1 damage to each opponent. See rule <a href="#cr701.73">701.73</a>, “Cackle.”<br>
<br><b><a id="glosCadence">Cadence</a></b><br>
A keyword ability that gives a creature +1/+1 counters when its controller casts a spell with mana value greater than its power. See rule <a href="#cr702.181">702.181</a>, “Cadence.”<br>
<br><b><a id="glosCard">Card</a></b><br>
The standard component of the game. Magic cards may be traditional or nontraditional. Tokens aren’t considered cards. In the text of spells or abilities, the term “card” is used only to refer to a card that’s not on the battlefield or on the stack, such as a creature card in a player’s hand. See rule <a href="#cr108">108</a>, “Cards.”<br>
<br><b><a id="glosCard Pool">Card Pool</a></b><br>
In a Limited format, the cards a player may use, in addition to basic land cards, to build their deck.<br>
<br><b><a id="glosCard Type">Card Type</a></b><br>
A characteristic. Except for abilities on the stack, each object has a card type, even if that object isn’t a card. Each card type has its own rules. See rule <a href="#cr205">205</a>, “Type Line,” and <a href="#cr3">section 3</a>, “Card Types.”<br>
<br><b><a id="glosCascade">Cascade</a></b><br>
A keyword ability that may let a player cast a random extra spell for no cost. See rule <a href="#cr702.85">702.85</a>, “Cascade.”<br>
<br><b><a id="glosCast">Cast</a></b><br>
To take a card from where it is (usually the hand), put it on the stack, and pay its costs, so that it will eventually resolve and have its effect. See rule <a href="#cr601">601</a>, “Casting Spells.”<br>
<br><b><a id="glosCaster (Obsolete)">Caster (Obsolete)</a></b><br>
An obsolete term that referred to the player who cast a spell. In general, cards that were printed with the term “caster” have received errata in the Oracle card reference to say “controller.”<br>
<br><b><a id="glosCasting Cost (Obsolete)">Casting Cost (Obsolete)</a></b><br>
An obsolete term for mana cost. Cards printed with this text have received errata in the Oracle card reference.<br>
<br><b><a id="glosCasualty">Casualty</a></b><br>
A keyword ability that allows you to sacrifice a creature to create a copy of a spell. See 702.153, “Casualty.”<br>
<br><b><a id="glosCatalyze">Catalyze</a></b><br>
A keyword action that makes the next spell you cast cost {1} less to cast. See rule <a href="#cr701.49">701.49</a>, “Catalyze.”<br>
<br><b><a id="glosChampion">Champion, Championed</a></b><br>
“Champion” is a keyword ability that lets one creature temporarily replace another. A permanent is “championed” by another permanent if the latter exiles the former as the direct result of a champion ability. See rule <a href="#cr702.72">702.72</a>, “Champion.”<br>
<br>
<b><a id="glosChange a Target">Change a Target</a></b><br>
To choose a new, legal target for a spell or ability. See rule <a href="#cr115.7">115.7</a>.<br>
<br><b><a id="glosChangeling">Changeling</a></b><br>
A characteristic-defining ability that grants the object it’s on every creature type. See rule <a href="#cr702.73">702.73</a>, “Changeling.”<br>
<br><b><a id="glosChaos Ability">Chaos Ability</a></b><br>
An ability of a plane card that triggers “Whenever you roll {CHAOS}” on the planar die in the Planechase casual variant. See rule <a href="#cr310.7">310.7</a>.<br>
<br><b><a id="glosChaos Symbol">Chaos Symbol</a></b><br>
The chaos symbol {CHAOS} appears on the planar die and in some triggered abilities of plane cards in the Planechase casual variant. See rule <a href="#cr107.12">107.12</a>.<br>
<br><b><a id="glosCharacteristic-Defining Ability">Characteristic-Defining Ability</a></b><br>
A kind of static ability that conveys information about an object’s characteristics that would normally be found elsewhere on that object (such as in its mana cost, type line, or power/toughness box). See rule <a href="#cr604.3">604.3</a>.<br>
<br><b><a id="glosCharacteristics">Characteristics</a></b><br>
Information that defines an object. See rule <a href="#cr109.3">109.3</a>.<br>
<br><b><a id="glosChoose X">Choose X</a></b><br>
Casting a spell has been modified to allow for choosing a number of modes that may not be defined until partway through the casting a spell. See rule <a href="#cr601.2b">601.2b</a>.<br>
<br><b><a id="glosChosen one">Chosen one</a></b><br>
A keyword ability that allows certain permanents to transform by paying {W}{U}{B}{R}{G}. See rule <a href="#cr702.191">702.191</a>, “Chosen one.”<br>
<br><b><a id="glosCipher">Cipher</a></b><br>
A keyword ability that allows you to encode a card on a creature and cast that card whenever that creature deals combat damage to a player. See rule <a href="#cr702.99">702.99</a>, “Cipher.”<br>
<br><b><a id="glosCity’s Blessing">City’s Blessing</a></b><br>
A designation a player can have. The ascend keyword causes a player to get this designation once they control ten permanents. See rule <a href="#cr702.131">702.131</a>, “Ascend.”<br>
<br><b><a id="glosClash">Clash</a></b><br>
To have a mini-contest involving the top cards of players’ libraries. See rule <a href="#cr701.23">701.23</a>, “Clash.”<br>
<br><b><a id="glosClass">Class</a></b><br>
An enchantment subtype. Classes have a number of class level abilities that increase their level and grant them new abilities. See rule <a href="#cr717">717</a>, “Class Cards.”<br>
<br><b><a id="glosCleanup Step">Cleanup Step</a></b><br>
Part of the turn. This step is the second and final step of the ending phase. See rule <a href="#cr514">514</a>, “Cleanup Step.”<br>
<br><b><a id="glosCleave">Cleave</a></b><br>
A keyword ability that allows you to pay an alternative cost to remove some of a spell’s text. See rule <a href="#cr702.148">702.148</a>, “Cleave.”<br>
<br><b><a id="glosClue Token">Clue Token</a></b><br>
A Clue token is a colorless artifact token with “{2}, Sacrifice this artifact: Draw a card.” For more information about predefined tokens, see rule <a href="#cr111.10">111.10</a>.<br>
<br><b><a id="glosCoalesce">Coalesce</a></b><br>
A keyword ability that allows certain spells to be cast from a graveyard for an alternative cost, and then enter the battlefield as a creature. See rule <a href="#cr702.190">702.190</a>, “Coalesce.”<br>
<br><b><a id="glosCollector Number">Collector Number</a></b><br>
A number printed on most cards that has no effect on game play. See rule <a href="#cr212">212</a>, “Information Below the Text Box.”<br>
<br><b><a id="glosColor">Color</a></b><br>
1. A characteristic of an object. See rule <a href="#cr105">105</a>, “Colors,” and rule <a href="#cr202">202</a>, “Mana Cost and Color.”<br>2. An attribute mana may have. See rule <a href="#cr106">106</a>, “Mana.”<br>
<br><b><a id="glosColor Identity">Color Identity</a></b><br>
A set of colors that determines what cards may be included in a deck for the Commander casual variant. See rule <a href="#cr903.4">903.4</a>.<br>
<br><b><a id="glosColor Indicator">Color Indicator</a></b><br>
A characteristic of an object. See rule <a href="#cr105">105</a>, “Colors,” and rule <a href="#cr204">204</a>, “Color Indicator.”<br>
<br><b><a id="glosColorless">Colorless</a></b><br>
1. An object with no color is colorless. Colorless is not a color. See rule <a href="#cr105">105</a>, “Colors,” and rule <a href="#cr202">202</a>, “Mana Cost and Color.”<br>2. A type of mana. See rule <a href="#cr106">106</a>, “Mana,” and rule <a href="#cr107.4c">107.4c</a>.<br>
<br><b><a id="glosCombat Damage">Combat Damage</a></b><br>
Damage dealt during the combat damage step by attacking creatures and blocking creatures as a consequence of combat. See rule <a href="#cr510">510</a>, “Combat Damage Step.”<br>
<br><b><a id="glosCombat Damage Step">Combat Damage Step</a></b><br>
Part of the turn. This step is the fourth step of the combat phase. See rule <a href="#cr510">510</a>, “Combat Damage Step.”<br>
<br><b><a id="glosCombat Phase">Combat Phase</a></b><br>
Part of the turn. This phase is the third phase of the turn. See rule <a href="#cr506">506</a>, “Combat Phase.”<br>
<br><b><a id="glosCommand">Command</a></b><br>
A zone for certain specialized objects that have an overarching effect on the game, yet are not permanents and cannot be destroyed. See rule <a href="#cr408">408</a>, “Command.”<br>
<br><b><a id="glosCommander">Commander</a></b><br>
1. A casual variant in which each deck is led by a legendary creature. See rule <a href="#cr903">903</a>, “Commander.”<br>2. A designation given to one legendary creature card in each player’s deck in the Commander casual variant.<br>
<br><b><a id="glosCommander Draft">Commander Draft</a></b><br>
A casual variant in which players participate in a booster draft and then play multiplayer games. See rule <a href="#cr903.13">903.13</a>, “Commander Draft.”<br>
<br><b><a id="glosCommander Ninjutsu">Commander Ninjutsu</a></b><br>
A variant of the ninjutsu ability. See rule <a href="#cr702.49">702.49</a>, “Ninjutsu.”<br>
<br><b><a id="glosCommander Tax">Commander Tax</a></b><br>
Informal term for the additional cost to cast a commander based on the number of times a player has cast it previously this game. See rule <a href="#cr903.8">903.8</a>.<br>
<br><b><a id="glosCompanion">Companion</a></b><br>
A keyword ability that allows a player to choose one creature card from outside the game as a companion if the restriction of that card’s companion ability is met. Once a player has chosen a companion, that player may pay {3} to put it into their hand once during the game. See rule <a href="#cr702.139">702.139</a>, “Companion.”<br>
<br><b><a id="glosCompleated">Compleated</a></b><br>
A keyword ability that causes a planeswalker to enter the battlefield with fewer loyalty counters if a player chose to pay life for Phyrexian mana symbols in its cost. See rule <a href="#cr702.150">702.150</a>, “Compleated.”<br>
<br><b><a id="glosComplete a Dungeon">Complete a Dungeon</a></b><br>
To remove a dungeon card from the game after reaching that dungeon card’s bottommost room. See rule <a href="#cr309">309</a>, “Dungeons.”<br>
<br><b><a id="glosConcede">Concede</a></b><br>
To quit the game. Conceding a game immediately causes that player to leave that game and lose that game. See rule <a href="#cr104">104</a>, “Ending the Game.”<br>
<br><b><a id="glosConjure">Conjure</a></b><br>
A keyword action that brings a card into the game. See rule <a href="#cr701.59">701.59</a>, “Conjure.”<br>
<br><b><a id="glosConnive">Connive</a></b><br>
A keyword action that causes a player to draw a card, discard a card, and then to put a +1/+1 counter on a creature if a nonland card was discarded this way. See rule <a href="#cr701.47">701.47</a>, “Connive.”<br>
<br><b><a id="glosConspiracy">Conspiracy</a></b><br>
A card type used in Limited formats such as Conspiracy Draft. A conspiracy card is not a permanent. See rule <a href="#cr314">314</a>, “Conspiracies.”<br>
<br><b><a id="glosConspiracy Draft">Conspiracy Draft</a></b><br>
A casual variant in which players participate in a booster draft and then play multiplayer games. See rule <a href="#cr905">905</a>, “Conspiracy Draft.”<br>
<br><b><a id="glosConspire">Conspire</a></b><br>
A keyword ability that creates a copy of a spell. See rule <a href="#cr702.78">702.78</a>, “Conspire.”<br>
<br><b><a id="glosConstructed">Constructed</a></b><br>
A way of playing in which each player creates their own deck ahead of time. See rule <a href="#cr100.2a">100.2a</a>.<br>
<br><b><a id="glosConsume">Consume</a></b><br>
A keyword action where a creature is sacrificed or a creature card in a graveyard is exiled for some effect. See rule <a href="#cr701.69">701.69</a>, “Consume.”<br>
<br><b><a id="glosContinuous Artifact (Obsolete)">Continuous Artifact (Obsolete)</a></b><br>
An obsolete term that appeared on the type line of artifacts without activated abilities. Cards printed with this text have received errata in the Oracle card reference to simply say “Artifact.”<br>
<br><b><a id="glosContinuous Effect">Continuous Effect</a></b><br>
An effect that modifies characteristics of objects, modifies control of objects, or affects players or the rules of the game, for a fixed or indefinite period. See rule <a href="#cr611">611</a>, “Continuous Effects.”<br>
<br><b><a id="glosControl">Control, Controller</a></b><br>
“Control” is the system that determines who gets to use an object in the game. An object’s “controller” is the player who currently controls it. See rule <a href="#cr108.4">108.4</a>.<br>
<br><b><a id="glosControl Another Player">Control Another Player</a></b><br>
To make all choices and decisions that player is allowed to make, or is told to make, by rules or by any objects. See rule <a href="#cr718">718</a>, “Controlling Another Player.”<br>
<br>
<b><a id="glosConverted Mana Cost (Obsolete)">Converted Mana Cost (Obsolete), Total Casting Cost (Obsolete)</a></b><br>
An obsolete term for mana value. Cards printed with this term have received errata in the Oracle card reference.<br>
<br><b><a id="glosConvoke">Convoke</a></b><br>
A keyword ability that lets you tap creatures rather than pay mana to cast a spell. See rule <a href="#cr702.51">702.51</a>, “Convoke.”<br>
<br><b><a id="glosCopiable Values">Copiable Values</a></b><br>
Values of an object’s characteristics that are checked by copy effects. See rules <a href="#cr613.2">613.2</a>, 707.2, and <a href="#cr707.3">707.3</a>.<br>
<br><b><a id="glosCopy">Copy</a></b><br>
1. To create a new object whose copiable values have been set to those of another object.<br>2. An object whose copiable values have been set to those of another object.<br>See rule <a href="#cr707">707</a>, “Copying Objects.”<br>
<br><b><a id="glosCost">Cost</a></b><br>
An action or payment necessary to take another action or to stop another action from taking place. See rule <a href="#cr118">118</a>, “Costs.”<br>
<br><b><a id="glosCounter">Counter</a></b><br>
1. To cancel a spell or ability so it doesn’t resolve and none of its effects occur. See rule <a href="#cr701.5">701.5</a>, “Counter.”<br>2. A marker placed on an object or player that modifies its characteristics or interacts with a rule or ability. See rule <a href="#cr122">122</a>, “Counters.”<br>
<br><b><a id="glosCounts As (Obsolete)">Counts As (Obsolete)</a></b><br>
Some older cards were printed with text stating that the card “counts as” something. Cards printed with this text have received errata in the Oracle card reference to state that the card actually is that thing.<br>
<br><b><a id="glosCreate">Create</a></b><br>
